div.p: Orang-Outang, ive Homo Sylvetris: OR, THE ANATOMY OF A PYGMIE Compared with that of a Monkey, an Ape, and a Man.
To which is added, A PHILOLOGICAL ESSAY Concerning the Pygmies, the Cynocephali, the Satyrs, and Sphinges of the ANCIENTS.
Wherein it will appear that they are all either APES or MONKEYS, and not MEN, as formerly pretended.
By EDWARD TYSON M. D. Fellow of the Colledge of Phyicians, and the Royal Society: Phyician to the Hopital of Bethlem, and Reader of Anatomy at Chirurgeons-Hall.

LONDON: Printed for Thomas Bennet at the Half-Moon in St. Paul's Church-yard; and Daniel Brown at the Blach Swan and Bible without Temple-Bar and are to be had of Mr. Hunt at the Repoitory in Greham-Colledge.
• DC XCIX.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE JOHN Lord Sommers, Baron of EVESHAM, Lord High Chancellor OF ENGLAND, One of the Lords of his MAJESTIES mot Honourable PRIVY COUNCIL, And Preident of the ROYAL SOCIETY.
div.p:
THE great Variety of weighty and important Affairs, in which your Lordhip is engaged; one would think, did o entirely engros your Time, that you could not have a Minute left to betow on the Mues. Your unwearied and uccesful Application to
the Buines of the State, in the nicet Conjunctions, that perhaps England ever aw; as well as your inexpreible Labours in ditributing Jutice, in your High Station; have been attended with niveral Applaue; and have convinced all the World, how much the Honour of his Majety's Government, and the Happines of his People, depend on the Capacity and Integrity of his Miniters. You have not uffered, even neceary Refrehments to interrupt your Contant Cares for the Publick. To erve your Country, you have defranded your elf both of Meat, and Rest; which, my Lord, is the only Act of Injutice, that was ever charged upon you. Your immoderate Labours make daily Encroachments upon your Health; or at leat 'tis the fear of every good Man, that they hould. And yet your Lordhip, notwithtanding all Diwaions, pereveres inflexible; as if, animated by the Noble Spirit of an Old Roman, you were reolved to Sacrifice your Life, for the Good of your Country.

And yet, my Lord, amidt uch a multiplicity of the greatest Affairs, to which you pay a contant Attendance; you have not only found Time, to apply your Thoughts to all kinds of Literature, o as to become a great Mater in all; But you have likewie extended your Care to the Interets of Learning, and to the Encouraging of thoe, who tudy the Advancement of it. Among many other Intances, your Lordhip has lately condecended, to Preide over the Royal Society;
that was intituted, for the Improvement of Natural Experimental Philoophy; and you have taken care, to Expres your great Zeal and Readines, to contribute every thing in your Power, to Protect their Interets, and Promote their Reputation. And under your Lordhip's enlivening Influence, there is all the Reaon in the World to expect, that Learning will again flourih there, as well as among other Orders of Men.

This, my Lord, has o embolden'd me, humbly to preent this Performance to your Lordhip. For ince o Great a Patron of Letters is rien in the midt of us; we think we have a ort of Right to his Countenance and Protection. I wih the Preent I preume to make you, was more worthy of your Lordhip: All that I can ay to recommend it, is, that the Subject is Novel, and that Care has been taken to give it a jut Decription; which, I may ay, without vanity, never yet appeared in Publick.

'Tis a true Remark, which we cannot make without Admiration; That from Minerals, to Plants; from Plants, to Animals; and from Animals, to Men; the Tranition is o gradual, that there appears a very great Similitude, as well between the meanet Plant, and ome Minerals; as between the lowet Rank of Men, and the highet kind of Animals. The Animal of which I have given the Anatomy, coming nearet to Mankind; eems the Nexus of the Animal and Rational, as your Lordhip and thoe of your High Rank and Order for Knowledge
and Widom, approaching nearet to that kind of Beings which is next above us; Connect the Viible, and Inviible World.

If this Performance hall Promote the Deign of the Society, of which I have the Honour to be a Member, and which your Lordhip is pleaed to Preide over; by improving the Natural Hitory of Animals, and affording the Reader any Delightful and eful Intructions; I hall look on my Time and Pains, well rewarded. I am

closer.signed: Your Lordhip's mot humble and mot obedient Servant EDWARD TYSON.

div.head: THE PREFACE
div.p: LEAST this Dicoure hould be rejected meerly for the Title's ake, as if 'twere intended only to divert the Reader, with the Recital of the Fabulous and Romantick Stories, which have been related on the Subjects I have propoed to treat of: I think it neceary to premie, that as my chief Deign in this Undertaking is the Improvement of the Natural Hitory of Animals, o I have made it my Buines more, to find out the Truth, than to enlarge in the Mythology; to inform the Judgment, than to pleae the Phancy, And the Orang-Outang (whoe Anatomy I here give) being a Creature o very remarkable, and rare; and not only in its External Shape, but much more in the Conformation of a great many of the inward Vicera, o much reembling a Man; I thought I could not be too particular, in my Decription of it; though to ome, who have not a Tat of thee Matters, I may eem prolix and tedious.

To render this Diquiition more ueful, I have made a Comparative Survey of this Animal, with a Monkey, an Ape, and a Man. By viewing the ame Parts of all thoe together, we may the better oberve Nature's Gradation in the Formation of Animal Bodies, and the Tranitions made from one to another; than which, nothing can more conduce to the
Attainment of the true Knowledge, both of the Fabrick and es of the Parts. By following Nature's Clew in this wonderful Labyrinth of the Creation, we may be more eaily admitted into her Secret Recees, which Thread if we mis, we mut needs err and be bewilder'd.

In drawing up this Comparion, I have made ue of the Anatomy which is given of Apes and Monkeys by other Authors; and very frequently have quoted their own words, which has render'd my Dicoure much longer: For not having thee Animals by me to diect and compare, I thought it but jut to let the Reader ee, upon what Authorities I went. And though a hort Reference might be eteemed ufficient, without this tedious and unfahionable way of inerting the whole Text; yet if any one will give himelf the trouble of Examining the Evidences I have produced, I think I have dealt more kindly by him, in making him a Judge himelf; than in leaving him barely to trut to my Report. For there are none, who have been converant with Books, but mut acknowledge, that they have been often impoed upon, for want of this fair dealing, as I have my elf Experienced in this preent Enquiry. To avoid therefore this Error, my Caution it may be has lead me into another, which I hope the Reader will pardon, if he judges it uch.

Galen formerly diected Apes and Monkeys, and recommended to his Scholars the frequent Anatomizing them, as ueful for the attaining the Knowledge of the Structure of the Parts in Humane Bodies. Had he met with our Animal, it had erved his turn much better: Nor had he been liable to ome Mitakes, which Vealius charges him with, ince in o many Parts, the Orang-Outang imitates a Man, more than Apes and Monkeys do. Not only Galen, but the greatet Anatomits we have had in this lat Age, have exercied their Pens about them; as plainly appears in the enuing Dicoure, which ufficiently jutifies me for engaging in this Argument: I wih I had o good an Apology for my Performance.

This great Agreement, which I oberved between the Orang-Outang, and a Man, put me upon conidering, whether it might not afford the Occaion to the Ancients, of inventing the many Relations, which they have given us of everal orts of Men, which are no where to be met with but in their Writings. For I could not but think, there might be ome Real Foundation for their Mythology; which made me more trictly enquire into their Records; and examining them, I always found omething new, that inenibly lead me on far beyond what at firt I intended: and if I do not deceive my elf, I have at lat gained a clearer Light in thee Matters, than any that has hitherto appeared.

For what created the greatet difficulty, was their calling them Men, but yet with an Epithet for ditinction ake; as the < in non-Latin alphabet > ; o the < in non-Latin alphabet > , &c. i. e. the Wild Men, the Little Men, the Pygmaean Men, the Black Men, the Men with Dogs Faces, &c. yet at the ame time I find that they made them < in non-Latin alphabet > , Wild Beats; and if o, no doubt but they were of the Quadru-manus kind; i. e. either Apes or Monkeys. And uch were likewie the Satyrs, the Fauni, Pan, AEgipan, Sylvanus, Silenus, and the Nymphae, as alo the Sphinges of the Ancients.

But o many Romances have been made about them, that not only Strabo formerly, but the mot noted Men of Learning of late, have looked upon them as meer Fictions of the Poets, and have utterly denied them any real Being. Homer's Geranomachia therefore, or Fight of the Cranes and Pygmies I have rendered a probable Story. Aritotle's aertion of the being of Pygmies, I have vindicated from the fale Gloes of others. The Conjectures of other Learned Men about them, I have examined: And by what I have aid in the following Philological Eay, I think I have fully proved, that there were uch Animals as the Ancients called Pygmies, Cynocephali, Satyrs, and Sphinges; and that they were only Apes and Monkeys.

Had my Leiure been greater, I had contracted the whole, and taken more care both in the Method, and Expreion. But mot of the vacant Hours from the neceary Attendance on the Buines of my Profeion, being taken up in Collecting Materials; to gratiie the Importunity of my Friends, who contantly urged the Publication, I ent my Papers Sheet by Sheet to the Pres, as I had time to trancribe them; o that I had not a view of them together, till they were printed. If I have dicovered the Truth, 'twas what I aimed at, which always appears bet, when leat diguied, and it has been my chief Care in this Undertaking to pull off thoe Vails and Masks, wherewith the Poets and Poetical Hitorians have hitherto obcured it.

div.head: Orang-Outang ive Homo Sylvetris: OR, THE ANATOMY OF A PYGMIE.
div.p:
THAT the Pygmies of the Antients were a ort of Apes, and not of Humane Race, I hall endeavour to prove in the following Eay. And if the Pygmies were only Apes, then in all probability our Ape may be a Pygmies; a ort of Animal o much reembling Man, that both the Antients and the Moderns have reputed it to be a Puny Race of Mankind, call'd to this day, Homo Sylvetris, The Wild Man; Orang-Outang, or a Man of the Woods; by the Africans Quoias Morron; by others Baris, or Barris, and by the Portugee, the Salvage. But oberving that under thee Names, they decribe different Animals; for Ditinction-ake, and to avoid Equivocation, I hall call the Subject, of which I am about to give the Anatomy, a Pygmie, from its Stature; which I find to be jut the ame with the Stature of the Pygmies of the Antients. Tulpius 'tis true, and Bontius, and Dapper do call it, Satyrus. And tho' I am of Opinion, that the Satyrs of the Antients were of the Ape, or rather Monkey-kind; yet for the Reaons alledged in the following Eay, I cannot think our Animal a Satyr. The Baris or Barris, which they decribe to be much taller than our Animal, probably may be what we call a Drill. But I mut confes, there is o great Confuion in the Decription of this ort of Creature, which I find is a very large Family (there being numerous Species of them) that in Trancribing the Authors that have wrote about them, 'tis almot impossible but to make mitakes; from the want of their well ditinguihing them. I hall endeavour therefore in my Account of this, o to
dicriminate it, that it may be eaily known again, where-ever 'tis met with. Not that I think in a ingle Obervation I can be o exact, but that I may be liable to make Errors my elf, how careful oever I have been.

I will not urge any thing more here, why I call it a Pygmie: 'Tis neceary to give it a Name; and if what I offer in the enuing Eay, does not ufficiently Account for the Denomination, I leave it to others to give it one more proper. What I hall mot of all aim at in the following Dicoure, will be to give as particular an Account as I can, of the formation and tructure of all the Parts of this wonderful Animal; and to make a Comparative Survey of them, with the ame Parts in a Humane Body, as likewie in the Ape and Monkey-kind. For tho' I own it to be of the Ape kind, yet, as we hall oberve, in the Organization of abundance of its Parts, it more approaches to the Structure of the ame in Men: But where it differs from a Man, there it reembles plainly the Common Ape, more than any other Animal.

And tho' I may eem too tedious in dicouring o long upon a ingle ubject, yet I have this to offer, that if we had an accurate and particular Hitory of any one Species of Animal, it might in a great meaure erve for the whole kind. Wherein they differ, might eaily be taken notice of, and there would be no need of repeating any thing, wherein they all agreed. So formerly diecting a Young Lion and a Cat at the ame time, I wondred to find o very great Reemblance of all the Parts, both in the one and the other; that the Anatomy of the one might erve for the other, allowing for the Magnitude of the Parts, with very little other alteration: And not only for this, but for everal other Animals, that belong to the ame Family. I could have wihed I had had the like Opportunity, when I was diecting our Pygmie, of comparing the ame Parts with thoe of an Ape and a Monkey: For want of it, I have referred all along to the Accounts given us of the Anatomy of thee Creatures by other Authors; which, tho' it renders my Dicoure more prolix, yet I thought it would not be unacceptable to the Curious. But I hall take care to draw up in a horter view, wherein our Pygmie more reembled a Man, than an Ape and Monkey, and wherein it differ'd.

Now notwithtanding our Pygmie does o much reemble a Man in many of its Parts, more than any of the Ape-kind, or any other Animal in the World that I know of: Yet by no means do I look upon it as the Product of a mixt Generation; 'tis a Brute-Animal ui generis, and a particular Species of Ape. For when I was diecting it, ome Sea-Captains and Merchants who came to my Houe to ee it, aured me, that they had een a great many of them in Borneo, Sumatra, and other Parts, tho' this was brought from Angola in Africa; but was firt taken a great deal higher up in the Country, and in Company with it there was a Female of the ame kind.

I hall have, hereafter occaion to make my Remarks on everal Particulars, relating to it's way of Living, it's Sagacity, Actions, and the
like. I hall now therefore firt of all decribe its outward hape and figure; then look within, and oberve the Mechanim there. But meeting with a Text in Aritotle, wherein he gives a general Decription of the Ape-kind, I think it not amis to Trancribe it; and by Commenting upon it, to hew wherein our preent Subject agrees with or differs from it; and what I have beides to Remark, I hall afterwards take notice of, and then proceed to the Anatomy of the Inward Parts.

Aritotle's Aritot. Hit. d • Animal. lib. 2. cap. 13. Ex Edit. Sealige • . <> p. 197, &c. Text is this, which I hall give with Jul. Cae. Scaliger's Latin Tranlation: And as you may oberve by the Letters of Reference, I have rendred each Paragraph into Englih, adding my Obervations thereon.

q.p:
(a)INter hominem, quadrupedúmque genus natura quaedam media, atque utrique communis et. Quales, imia, cebus, caniceps. (b) Et autem cebus imia caudata. (c) Caniceps communem cum imia formam habet: nii quod & major & robutior et: faciémque habet caninae propiorem. Tum moribus exitunt efferatioribus. Dentes quoque caniniores, atque firmiores. (d) Simiae partes quae coelum pectant, ut piloae unt: Proptereà quòd quadrupedum generi acribuntur: Ita quae ad terram devergunt quoque: quia hominis peciem referunt. Nam in homine, & quadrupedibus hoc contrario e habere modo upra dictum et. Caeterùm imiis craus pilus, ac praedenus utraque in parte et. (e) Fjus verò facies multis modis humanae imilis. Quippe tum nares, tum auriculae: Item dentes tam primores, quàm maxillares unt propemodum tales, quales & homini. (f) Quinetiam quadrupedes caeterae • ùm in utraque gena neutiquam palpebr • s habeant: ipa habet, ed tenues admodum: t • nuiores verò inferiores, atque perpuillos: quibus carent quadrupedes aliae. (g) Ei unt in pectore papillae du • parvarum mammarum. (h) Ad hae • ,
hominis brachia, nii hirta eent. Quae etiam icut & crura hominis modo inflectat. Nam & horum, & illorum curvaluras inter e habet contrarias. (i) Tum manus, digitos, ungues, quai humanos. Verùm haec omnia ferinam ad naturam potiùs vergunt. (k) Suus quidam modus pedibus, ac peculiaris. Etenim quai manus quaedam magnae unt. Quippe & digiti in iis, veluti manuum, medio longiimo. Et planta manui imilis, quanquam porrectior ad extremum uque, icuti vola. (l) Cujus potremum calloius et: inepta, atque inexplanata calcanei imilitudine. Pedum uus, & pro manibus, & pro pedibus: flectit enim eos manuum modo. (m) Superior brachij pars, & coxa, breves: i ad ulnae, & tibiae magnitudinem referantur. (n) mbilicus non prominet: ed durum quiddam ibi invenias. (o) Superae partes inferis majores: quai i quinarium cum ternario conferas. Hoc autem tum ex quadrupedum natura: tum proptereà quòd pedes & manibus imiles habet, & quai ex pedum, manuùmque contitutione compoitos. Nam calcanei potrema pedem, caeterae partes manum repraeentant. Habent enim digiti id, quod volam appellamus, (p) Quadrupedis habitu frequentiore et. (q) Proque co nates non habet: neque caudam, quoniam bipes. Sed perpuillam omnino illam, & notae tantúm gratia, (r) Foeminae genitale muliebri pecie et: maribus canina potius, quàm humana. (s) Cebi, icuti diximus, caudati unt. rtivero generi vicera imilia humanis.

div.p: (a) Arit. Some Animals are of an intermediate Nature, between a Man and Quadrupeds, as Apes, the Cebi, and Cynocephali.

< in non-Latin alphabet >
Theodorus Gaza thus renders this Paage: Sunt quae natura ancipite, partim hominem, partim Quadrupedem imitentur, icut imiae, &c. Not that an Ape is part a Man, and part a Quadruped; inter Hominem & non Hominem non datur medium; The Terms being contradictory, one mut be fale. The Philoopher's meaning mut therefore be, that in the formation of the Parts of the Body, the Ape, the Cebus, and Cynocephalus, are intermediate Species between a Man and other Quadrupeds, having everal Parts of the Body formed like Brutes; others more reembling thoe of Men. Scaliger ibid. in Com, pag.201. Scaliger, a little after, hath this Remark; Ad eum namque modum ummus Opifex Rerum eriem concatenavit a Planta ad Hominem; ut quai ine ullo cohaereant intervallo, ie < in non-Latin alphabet > cum Plantis Bruta conjungunt; ic cum homine imia Quadrupedes. Itaque in hominis quoque pecie inveniamus Divinos, Humanos, feros. This Climax or Gradation can't but be taken notice of, by any that are curious in oberving the Wonders of the Creation; and the more he oberves it, the more venerable Idea's 'twill give him of the great Creator; and it would be the Perfection of Natural Hitory, could it be attained, to enumerate and remark all the different Species, and their Gradual Perfections from one to another. Thus in the Ape and Monkey-kind, Aritotle's Cebus I look upon to be a degree above his Cynocephalus; and his Pithecus or Ape above his Cebus, and our Pygmie a higher degree above any of them, we yet know, and more reembling a Man: But at the ame time I take him to be wholly a Brute, tho' in the formation of the Body, and in the Senitive or Brutal Soul, it may be, more reembling a Man, than any other Animal; o that in this Chain of the Creation, as an intermediate Link between an Ape and a Man, I would place our Pygmie.

< in non-Latin alphabet > , &c. The Philoopher here does not enumerate all the everal Species that are contained under the Ape and Monkey-kind; they are a very numerous and a large Clais of Animals. Scaliger upon the Place mentions everal he had oberved of both kinds; and all our Zoographers, and mot Journals of Travels give a Decription of a great many orts of them. But for want of well ditinguihing them, and ranging them into a Methodical Series, their Hitory as yet is very confued and perplext. Mr. Ray Raij Synopis Animal. pag.1 • 8. places thee Animals under this general Title, Animalia Pede unguiculato Multiido,
< in non-Latin alphabet > & < in non-Latin alphabet > 'Tis call'd Pithecus,
< in non-Latin alphabet > , quia facilè ab homine peruadeatur; and oftentimes this word is taken as a Genus which includes the whole; when trictly taken, it igniies an Ape without a Tail, and in Latin is call'd Simia; that which hath a Tail is call'd Cercopithecus, in Englih a Monkey. Thus Material. Epig ••• lib. 14. Epigr. 202. Martial.
Callidus emias eludere Simius Hatas,
Si mihi Cauda foret, Cercopithecus eram.
(b) Arit The Cebus is an Ape having a Tail.

Hit. de Quadruped. l. 1. p. 857. Conradus Gener thinks, that this Cebus of Aritotle, which he decribes only as having a Tail, mut be the Cercopithecus or Common Monkey, ince he mentions not the Cebus any where ele, and the Cercopithecus no where. Plinij Hit. Nat. lib. 8. cap. 19. cum Interpret. & Notis Jo. Harduini, p. 167. Harduinus, in his Notes on Pliny, advies not to mitake the Cepus in Pliny, for the Cebus in Aritotle. (6) Pliny's words are thee; Pompeij Magni primum Ludi otenderunt Chama, quem Galli Ruium vocabant, Eigie Lupi, Pardorum maculis. Iidem ex AEthiopia quas vocant
< in non-Latin alphabet >
quarum Pedes poteriores, Pedibus humanis & cruribus, priores manibus uere imiles, hoc Animal potea Roma non vidit. And therefore becaue it was o uncommon as to be een at Rome but once, it could not be the common Monkey. Geograph. lib. 16. P. 533. Strabo, out of Artemidorus, decribes the Cepus thus: < in non-Latin alphabet > . That the Cepus hath the Face of a Lion, the ret of the Body like a Panther, and is of the bignes of a Dorcas or Roe-Buck. Diodor, Sicul. Biblioth. Hit. l. 3. p.m. 168. Diodorus Siculus hath much the ame Decription, < in non-Latin alphabet > . Which Laurentius Rodomanus thus renders. Cepus, i. e. Hortus (quem vocant) à totius Corporis decore & taturae venutate nomen accepit, facie Leonem imitatur, & reliquo Pantheram, praeter magnitudinem, qua Dorcadi par et.AElian. de Animal. lib. 17. cap. 8. p. 474.
AElian hath given a Decription of the ame Animal from Pythagoras, from whom, 'tis thought, it firt received this Name; and he is more particular. His Account, tho' omewhat long; I will give in P. Gillius's Tranlation, becaue I am apt to think this Animal is till in being. Terrenum quoddam Animal Pythagoras cribit ecundùm Mare Rubrum procreari & Cepum, hoc et Hortum appoitè idcircò nominari, quòd tanquam Hortus variis coloribus ditinguatur. Cùm exitit confirmata aetate, pari magnitudine et cum Herythrienibus Canibus. Jam porro ejus Colorum varietatem, icut ille cribit, animus nobis et explicare. Ejus caput & poticas partes ad caudam uque prorus valde igneo colore unt, tum aurei quidam Pili dieminati pectantur, tum album rotrum, inde ad Collum aureae vittae pertinent, Colli inferiores partes ad Pectus, & anteriores Pedes omnino albi, Mammae duae manum implentes caeruleo colore viuntur, venter candidus, Pedes poteriores nigri unt, Rotri formae Cynocephalo recte
comparari potet. The Cepus therefore of Pliny, Strabo, Diodorus Siculus, and AElian, in all probability mut be different from the Cebus of Aritotle. Joh. Caius our Country-man ent Gener a Decription of a Mamomet or Marmoet he had oberved, which Gener thinks might be a ort of Cepus; but the Colours were different, as likewie the Magnitude.

(c) Arit. The Cynocephali have the ame hape with Monkeys, but they are bigger, and Stronger, and they have a Face liker a Dogs's, and are of a fiercer Nature, and they have Teeth liker a Dog's, and tronger.

I hall have occaion to Dicoure of thee Cynocephali in the enuing Eay. For tho' the Philoopher makes them only a ort of Ape or Monkey, yet there have been thoe, that would impoe them on the World for a Race of Men; and by AElian. Hit. de Anim. lib. 10. cap. 26. in Edit. P. Gillij. in aliis cap. 25. AElian they are call'd < in non-Latin alphabet > ; tho' Galen. <>
minitr. Anat. l. 1. cap. 2. Galen tells us, they are much les like a Man, than an Ape is: For they can carce tand upright, much les walk or run o. Philotorgij Hit. Eccleiat. lib. 3. cap. 11. p.41. Philotorgius mentions the Aegopithecus, the Arctopithecus, the Leontopithecus, as well as the Cynocephalus, and then adds, < in non-Latin alphabet > . That there is the Goat-Ape, the Bear-Ape, the Lion-Ape, the Dog-Ape; and that the Ape-kind have a reemblance to a great many other Animals; o large and numerous is this Clais of Animals, that perhaps there is none that is more; and that are o different from one another. The iercenes of the Cynocephali is taken notice of by all; our Pygmie was quite of another temper, the mot gentle and loving Creature that could be. Thoe that he knew a Ship-board he would come and embrace with the greatet tendernes, opening their Booms, and claping his Hands about them; and as I was informed, tho' there were Monkeys aboard, yet 'twas oberved he would never aociate with them, and as if nothing a-kin to them, would always avoid their Company. The Teeth of the Cynocephali are like a Dog's; thoe of our Pygmie exactly reembled a Man's, as I hall hew in the Oteology.

(d) Arit. Apes are hairy on their Backs, as they are Quadrupeds, and on their Bellies, as they are like Men: For in a Man and a Beat this hairines is quite contrary, as was aid before. So that Apes are very hairy in both Places, their Hair being trong or coure, and thick, et.

The Place that Aritotle refers to, is this. Arit. Hit. de Animal. lib. 2. c. 5. p. 160. Edit. Scalig.
< in non-Latin alphabet > . i. e. That in Brutes the Back or upper Parts are more hairy, the Belly or under Parts either mooth or les hairy: In a Man is oberved the contrary. But in our Pygmie we oberved it different; for here all behind from the Head downwards, 'twas very hairy, and the Hair o thick, that it covered the Skin almot from being een.
But in all the Parts before, the Hair was much thinner, and the Skin every where appeared, and in ome places 'twas almot bare. Nature therefore has cloathed it with Hair, as a Brute, to defend it from the Injuries of the Weather; and when it goes on all four, as a Quadruped, it eems all hairy: When it goes erect, as a Biped, it appears before les hairy, and more like a Man. After our Pygmie was taken, and a little ued to wear Cloaths, it was fond enough of them; and what it could not put on himelf, it would bring in his Hands to ome of the Company to help him to put on. It would lie in a Bed, place his Head on the Pillow, and pull the Cloaths over him, as a Man would do; but was o careles, and o very a Brute, as to do all Nature's Occasions there. It was very full of Lice when it came under my Hands, which it may be it got on Ship-board, for they were exactly like thoe on Humane Bodies. Franc. Redi Experimenta circa generat. Inector.
Seignior Redi oberves in mot Animals a particular ort of Loue, and gives the Figures of a great many.

The Hair of our Pygmie or Wild Man was of a Coal-black colour, and trait; and much more reembling the Hair of Men than the Furr of Brutes: For in the Furr of Brutes, beides the longer Hair, there is uually a finer and horter Pile intermixt: Here 'twas all of a kind; only about the Pubis the hair was greyih, eemed longer, and omewhat different; o on the upper Lip and Chin, there were greyih hairs like a Beard: And I was told by the Owners, that once it held the Baon it's elf, to be trimmed. The Face, Hands, and Soles of the Feet were bare and without Hair, and o was mot part of the Forehead: But down the ides of the Face 'twas very hairy; the hairs there being about an Inch and half long, and longer than in mot Parts of the Body beides. The tendency of the Hair of all the Body was downwards; but only from the Writs to the Elbow 'twas upwards; o that at the Elbow the Hair of the Shoulder and the Arm ran contrary to one another. Now in Quadrupeds the Hair in the fore-limbs have uually the ame Inclination downwards, and it being here different, it uggeted an Argument to me, as if Nature did deign it as a Biped. But we will lay no more tres upon it than it will bear: The Hair on the back-ide of the Hands did run tranvere, inclining to the outide of the Hands; and thoe of the hinder ides of the Thighs were tranvere likewie.

Man, tho' not o hairy as Brutes, and (as Aritotle oberves) more hairy before, than behind; yet if expoed to the hardhips of the Weather, like them; no doubt, but he would become hairy on the Body likewie; which might poibly be the Cae of Nebuchadnezzar. Daniel, Cap. 4. 33. And very Remarkable is that Story of Peter Serrano a Spaniard, who was cataway, and ecaped to a Deart Iland, which from him afterwards received it's Name, as 'tis related by the Inca Garcilao de la Vega. Royal Commen <> of Pe •• . lib. 1. cap.3. For having with the greatet difficulty utained a mierable Life for three
Years, The Hairs of his Body grew in that manner, that he was covered all over with Britles; the hair of his Head and Beard reaching to his Wate, that he appeared like ome Wild or Savage Creature.
(e) Arit. Their Face hath Many Reemblances to a Man's, for they have Notrils and Ears alike; and Teeth like a Man's, both the Fore-teeth and the Grinders.

p.U: eems to have repect to this Text of Aritotle, and what follows, where he tells us, Nam imiarum genera perfectam Hominis imitationem continent, facie, Naribus, Auribus, Palpebris, quas olae Quadrupedum in inferiore habent Genâ. Jam Mammas in Pectore, Brachia & Crura in contrarium imilitèr flexa. In manibus, ungues, digitos, longioremque medium. Pedibus paulùm differunt, unt enim, ut manus, praelongi, ed vetigium Palmae imile faciunt. Pollex quoque his & Articuli, ut homini; ac praeter Genitale, & hoc in maribus tantùm. Vicera etiam interiora omnia ad exemplar. We will compare both their Accounts, with our Pygmie; and oberve wherein they agree or differ from us.

div.p:
As for the Iace of our Pygmie, it was liker a Man's, than Ape's and Monkeys Faces are: For it's Forehead was larger, and more globous, and the upper and lower Jaw not o long or prominent, and more pread; and it's Head more than as big again as either of theirs: But why the Philoopher, after his general Aertion of the likenes of the Face of an Ape to that of a Man's, hould firt of all intance in the Noe, which is o much different, may eem trange: Since in a Man the Noe is protuberant and riing, jutting out much beyond the whole urface, and herein 'tis altogether unlike to that of Brutes, and the Ape-kind too. 'Tis not therefore on this account that the Comparion is made, But I rather think, his meaning mut be, that an Ape's Noe is like Man's, in that it is not extended to the length of the Rotrum, or upper Jaw, as in Dogs and other Brutes, but reaches only to the upper Lip. à imis Naribus, or this flatnes of the Noe, mot do derive the word Simia; tho' others, as Voius, would have it, quai mimia à
< in non-Latin alphabet > , imitari, from mimicking. But Scaliger will not allow it. Dicitur autem Simia (aith he) non ab Imitatione, ut Grammatici imperiti, ed à imitate.

The Noe of our Pygmie was flat like an Ape's, not protuberant as a Man's; and on the outide of each Notril there was a little lit turning upwards, as in Apes. 'Tis oberved of the Indian Blacks, that their Noe is much flatter than the Europeans; which may be thought rather Natural to that Nation, than occaioned (as ome would make us believe) by the Mother's tying the Infant to her Back, and o when at Work bruiing and flatting it againt her Shoulders; becaue 'tis o univeral in them all.

As to the Ears, none could more reemble thoe of a Man, than our Pygmie's; both as to the largenes, colour, hape, and tructure. Here I oberved the Helix, Ant-Helix, Concha, Alvearium, Tragus, Anti-tragus, and Lobus; only the Cartilage was very fine and thin, and the Ears did not lye o flat to the Head, as they do in a Man. But that may be from the Cutom of binding; our Heads, when Infants.
The Teeth of our Pygmie reembled a Man's, more than do thoe of Apes and Monkeys; as I hall hew in the Otcology.
(f) Arit. And whereas other Quadrupeds have not Hair on both Eye-lids, thee have; But 'tis very fine, epecially that on the lower Eye-lid, and very mall. But other Quadrupeds have none there.

In our Pygmie the Cilia or Hair of both Eye-lids appeared very fair and plain, but not o large as in Men. The Supercilia or Hair of the Eye-brows, eem'd to be rubb'd off; which might be occaioned by the jutting out of the Cranium in that place, more than in Men: Which is a Provident Proviion of Nature, for the better afeguard of the Eyes, and their defence from the Injuries they might otherwie receive in the Woods. But the Philoopher's Aertion, that no Quadruped hath Hair on the under Eye-lid beides Man but the Ape-kind, I cannot jutifie; or I do not take his meaning aright: Tho' he has much the ame Opinion a little before. Hit. Animal. lib. 2. p.m. 161. Where he tells us, < in non-Latin alphabet > . Which Scaliger thus renders: Ac Palpebras homo utrâque in Genâ habet tum & in Alis, & in Pube Pilos. Caeterae, Animantes neque in his locis, neque in Genâ inferiore: Sed ub Genam & paucos & paucae. Our Pygmie had Hair in the Arm-pits, and that in the Pubis eemed omewhat different from what grew on the ret of the Body; being not o trait, but omewhat curled; and greyih, not black. But I mut here Remark, that Pliny ues the words Palpebrae and Gena, in his Tranlating this Text of Aritotle, different from what commonly they ignifie now. For by Palpebrae he means, what Aritotle and Hippocrates call < in non-Latin alphabet > , i. e. the Hair on the Rim of the Eye-lids, à palpitatione; and Fetus calls Cilia, quia oculos celent & tueantur: And by Gena, he undertands the Eye-lid; as appears from that Paage of Pliny I have jut now quoted, Palpebris quas folae Quadrupedum in inferiore habent Genâ. And o Scaliger ues thee words in this Tranlation of Aritotle: And he makes Cilium to ignifie, Summum Genae ambitum, and not the Hair there.
(g) Arit. They have two Teats or Nipples of mall Breats on the Sternum.

The Philoopher here oberves, That the Ape-kind, common with Humane, have the Mammae on the Sternum or Breat, which is different from Brutes. And tho' the Elephant herein eems omewhat alike, yet he makes this ditinction, Arit. ibid. p. 151.
< in non-Latin alphabet > . Juxta Pectus potius, quàm in Pectore, as Scaliger renders it; or as Theodorus Gaza, non in Pectore, ed paulò citra. And a little after, Arit. ibid. p. 176. he more particularly exprees himelf, < in non-Latin alphabet > . Sub Armis, as Gaza renders it; ad Axillas, as Scaliger, where he further tells us, That the Male as well as Female Elephant have thee Teats; but they are very mall, in repect of the Bulk of it's Body, and o placed that ide-ways, you can't ee them. The Bear (he adds) hath four Teats; Sheep have but two, and thoe between the hinder Legs; Cows have four Teats there. Other Animals (he aith) have thee Teats in the middle of the Belly, and uually more numerous; as the Dog and Swine-kind: But the Panther hath but four in the Belly: The Camel hath two Mammae there, and four Teats, as a Cow; and a Liones but two there.

But Apes and Monkeys have their Teats upon the Breat, as Women have; and Albert. de Animal. lib. 22. p. 224. Albertus Magnus gives this Reaon for it, Mammillas autem habet in Pectore icut Mulier, eò quòd manus dedit ei Natura, quibus ad Pectus potet elevare partum, icut Mulier. Our Pygmie was a Male, yet here the two Papillae or Teats appeared very plain, and were exactly ituated as they are in Men. The Mammae or Breats were mall and thin, and not protuberant. The Female Orang-Outang of ) Jac. Bontij Hit. Nat. & Med. lib. 5. cap. 32. p. 84. Bontius is pictured with pendulous large Breats, and they are o decribed by Nic. Tulpij Oberv. Med. l. 3. cap. 56. Tulpius. And Gaend. de vita Peireskij. lib. 5. p.m. 170. Gaendus, in the Life of Peiresky, peaking of the Barris, aith, Huic Mammae ad pedis longitudinem.
(h) Arit. They have Arms like a Man, but hairy; and they bend them and the Legs as a Man does; the flection of the one being contrary to the other.

The Shoulder and Arm of our Pygmie were very hairy outwards, not o hairy inwards. The Contratendency of the Hair here, as that of the Shoulder pointing downwards, and that of the Arm pointing upwards, like Lucan's Pila minantia Pilis, I have already noted. This difference I hall here remark of this fore-limb in our Pygmie, as well as in Apes and Monkeys; that 'tis longer in them proportionably, than in Man. I hall examine this Part more particularly in the Myology and Oteology.

But the Curvature or Flection of the Arms and Legs in our Pygmie, as alo in Apes and Monkeys, is jut the ame as in Man; the Arms bending forwards, and the Legs backwards; whereas in other Brutes, the flection
of the fore and hinder Legs is both the áme way. Homini Genua & Cubita contraria (aith Plinij Nat. Hit. l. 11. cap. 45. p.m. 594. Pliny) item ris & imiarum generi, ob id minime pernicibus. I hall examine this Place of Pliny in the Oteology.
(i) Arit. Beides they have Hands, Fingers, and Nails like a Man's, but all thee omewhat ruder.

The Hand of our Pygmie was different from a Man's, in that the Palm was much longer; o the Thumb too, was les than the other Fingers; whereas in a Man, the Thumb is uually thicker than the ret of the Fingers: In both thee repects, it more reembled the Ape-kind. But the Fingers of our Pygmie being o much bigger than thoe of Apes and Monkeys; and its Nails being broader, and flatter, on both thee Accounts it was liker a Man. ngues Clauulae Nervorum ummae exitimantur (aith Plinij Nat. Hist. lib. 11. cap. 45. P. 594. Pliny) omnibus hi, quibus & digiti: ed Simiae imbricati, Hominibus lati.
In the Palms of the Hands of our Pygmie were remarkable thoe Lines which are uually taken notice of in Palmetry, and at the ends of the Fingers were thoe Spiral Lines, which are uually in a Man's.

(k) Arit. The Feet are particular; for they are like great Hands, and the Toes like Fingers; the middlemot being the longet; And the Sole of the Foot like the Palm of the Hand, but more extended, or longer.

Pliny (as I have remark'd) renders this Paage thus: Pedibus paulum differunt, unt enim, ut manus, praelongi; ed vetigium Palmae imile faciunt. Now the Palms of the Hands, and the Soles of the Feet of our Pygmie, were equally long, and longer, proportionably, than in Man; and herein it reembled more the Ape-kind: As it did likewie in the length of the Toes, which were as long as the Fingers, as alo in having the middlemot Toe longer than the ret. For in the Hand of a Man, the middle Finger is the longet, but in the Foot, the middle Toe is not. The Philoopher does very well liken it to a Hand, ince beides the length of the Toes, like Fingers, it had the great Toe, like the Thumb et off at a ditance from the range of the other Toes, as we hall hew hereafter.
(l) Arit. The ole of the Foot in the hinder part was more callous, ill, and odly imitating a Heel: For they ue their Feet in both Capacities, both as a Hand and Foot, and bend them like Hands.

In the Ape-kind there is a true Os Calcis, beides this Calloity. And in our Pygmie this Heel-bone was liker that in a Man, than theirs is. The Philoopher in the former Paragraph hewed what reemblance this Part had to a Humane Hand, in this, by reaon of the Os Calcis, how 'tis like
a Foot; and then makes an Inference from the different tructure of this Organ, that it performs the Ues and Offices of both.

All which is very agreeable to our Pygmie. But this Part, in the Formation and it's Function too, being liker a Hand, than a Foot; for the ditinguihing this ort of Animals from others, I have thought, whether it might not be reckoned and call'd rather Quadru-manus than Quadrupes, i. e. a four-handed, than a four-footed Animal.

And as it ues it's hinder Feet upon any occaion, as Hands; o likewie I oberved in our Pygmie, that it would make ue of it's Hands, to upply the place of Feet. But when it went as a Quadruped on all four, 'twas awkwardly; not placing the Palm of the Hand flat to the Ground, but it walk'd upon it's Knuckles, as I oberved it to do, when weak, and had not trength enough to upport it's Body. So that this Species of Animals hath the Advantage of making ue of their Feet as Hands, and their Hands as Feet, as there is occaion.
(m) Arit. The Os Humeri, and the Os Femoris are hort, in repect of the Ulna and Tibia.

In a Humane Skeleton, the Os Humeri, and the Os Femoris are much longer than the lna and Tibia. For in a Skeleton of a Woman I have by me, the Os Humeri was Twelve Inches and a half, and the Os Femoris Seventeen Inches long; whereas the lna was but Nine Inches and three quarters, and the Tibia Fourteen Inches long. In our Pygmie, the Os Humeri was Five Inches and a half, and the Os Femoris Five Inches long. The lna was Five Inches and a half, and the Tibia was Four Inches long. Thee Bones in the Skeleton of a Monkey, were much of the ame length with our Pygmie's, o that herein both differ from a Man, and our Pygmie more reembles the Ape-kind.
(n) Arit. They have no prominent Navel, but omething hard in this place of the Navel.
In our Pygmie the mbilicus or Navel appeared very fair, and in the exact Place, as 'tis in a Man; not prominent nor harder, but in all repect Natural and alike.

(o) Arit. They have the upper Parts much larger than the lower, as being Quadrupeds, almot as five to three; and as upon this account, o be becaue they have Feet like Hands, as if they were compounded of a Hand and Foot: Of a Foot, in repect of the Heel behind; and of a Hand, as to the other Parts; for they have Fingers, and what we call the Palm.

In Quadrupeds uually the pper or fore-parts are much larger than the Lower or hinder; and 'tis o in the Ape and Monkey-kind, as the Philoopher Remarks. But in our Pygmie I think this Obervation will not hold. For tho' it was much emaciated, by reaon of it's long; illnes, o that it eemed very thin and lank in the Belly; yet behind it look'd quare enough, and proportionable as a Man. But the Orang-Outang of Tulpius
had a large quob Belly. We hall preently give the Dimenions of all the Parts, as oon as we have done with this Text of Aritotle.

We hall hereafter farther conider the tructure of the Foot in the Oteology, where we hall decribe the Os Calcis, and hew how well it performs its Office, when this Animal tands erect. But ince Nature deign'd it not always to live on the Ground, but to get it's Prey in the Trees likewie, it hath very wiely formed this Part like a Hand, by which means it can more eaily climb them; and when there, hift much better by this Contrivance; as I have hewn in my Dicoure Philooph. Tranact. Numb. 239. upon the Carigueya, eu Marupiale Americanum, or the Anatomy of an Opoum; which Animal had its hinder Feet formed like Hands
(p) Arit. They live mot of their time as Quadrupeds more than as Bipeds, or erect.

Our Merchants tell me, when firt they take Apes or Monkeys, to learn them to go erect, they uually tye their Hands behind them. And I am of the Philoopher's Mind, that Naturally they go more on all Four, than erect. But whether 'tis o in our Pygmie, I do upect; ince walking on it's Knuckles, as our Pygmie did, eems no Natural Poture; and 'tis ufficiently provided in all repects to walk erect.
(q) Arit. As Quadrupeds they have no Buttocks; as Bipeds, no Tails; or but very little, like a hew of one.

Our Pygmie had Buttocks or Nates, as we hall ee in the Myology, but not o much as in Man. The Os Ichij or Coxendix was very different, as appears in the Skeleton, and as I hall decribe in the Oteology. Our Pygmie had no Tail, but an Os Coxygis, as is in Man, which outwardly made a little appearance, as in my Second Figure, and may be what Aritotle Remarks. Scaliger has this Note upon it: Caudae notam ive vetigium animadvertit, quam vix Oculis deprehendas. Tactu tamen ubee intelligas, quam i attractare tentes, promptâ mirâque celeritate ee ubtrahit, ridiculâ indignatione laeum prae e sert.
(r) Arit. The Female hath the Privy-parts, like a Woman; but the Male, more like a Dog's, than a Man's.

Our Subject was a Male, and this Part here was nothing like a Dog's. For in the Penis of a Dog there is a large Bone, which is not in the Ape and Monkey-kind. Scaliger's Note here does not make out the Aertion: Caninum Genitale dixit Simij, non temerè; nodos enim quodam deprehendimus: differt autem figurâ Glandis. I did not oberve thee Nodes here; but of this, more in the Anatomy of this Part.
(s) Arit. The Cebi (as was aid before) have Tails: As to the Vicera they have them all like a Man's.

So Pliny, Vicera etiam interiora omnia ad Exemplar. But I find this a great Mitake. For, as we hall hew, our Pygmie, who comes much nearer to a Man in the Structure of the inward Parts, than either Apes or Monkeys, yet in a great many things is very different; but where it is o, there it reembles an Ape. But on the other hand, Albertus Magnus is much more mitaken, who will not allow any likenes at all. For peaking of an Ape, he tells us, Albertus De Animal. lib. 22. p. 224. Et icut in ante habitis diximus, homini in exterioribus imile exitens, in nullo imilitudinem habet cum interioribus hominis, & minùs fere omnibus aliis Betiis. Galen Galen. de Anat. Admini • l. lib. 1. cap. 2. p.m. 26. is much more in the right, who acknowledges a very great imilitude between an Ape and a Man, both in the outward and inward Parts, where he tells US, < in non-Latin alphabet > . i. e. An Ape is the mot like a Man of any Quadruped: In the Vicera and the Mucles, and in the Arteries, and Veins and Nerves, becaue 'tis o in the tructure of the Bones. For 'tis from their make, that it walks on two Legs, and ues its fore-limbs as Hands. It hath the larget Breat of any Quadruped, and Clavicles or Collarbones like a Man, and a round Face, and a mall or hort Neck.

All which is very agreeable to our Pygmie, whom we hall ind more exactly to anwer this Character, than an Ape. And now having compared our Pygmie with this general Decription that Aritotle gives of the Ape-kind; we hall compare him with himelf, by taking the different Dimenions of the everal Parts, as well as of the whole Body; and hall oberve what Proportions they had to one another.

As from the top of the Head, to the heel of the Foot in a trait Line, it meaured Twenty ix Inches. The Girth of the Body in the bigget part about the Cartilago Eniformis, was Sixteen Inches; over the Loins 'twas Ten Inches about. The Compas of the Head over the Eyes and Ears, Thirteen Inches and a half. The aperture of the Eye-lids, three quarters of an Inch. From one corner of the Mouth, to the other, Two Inches and a quarter. From the middle of the upper Lip to the Eye-brow, 'twas two Inches three quarters. From the Eye-brow to the Occiput Seven Inches and a half. The Perpendicular Diameter of the Ear from the Top to the Lobe, was Two Inches and a half. The Horizontal Diameter of the Ear was an Inch and half. The Verge or Compas of the Ear about, was near Five Inches and a half. Where the Ear was fatened to the Head, it meaured above an Inch and half. From the Clavicula or Collar-Bone, to the Penis, Ten Inches. From the Cartilago Eniformis to the Navel, Three Inches and a half. From the Navel to the Penis, Three Inches. The ditance between the two Teats, Three Inches
and a quarter. The length of the Arm, from the Shoulder to the end of the Fingers, Seventeen Inches. The Girth of the Shoulder about the middle, Four Inches and a quarter; of the Arm near the Elbow, Five Inches. The Hand from the Writ to the end of the Middle Finger, meaured Five Inches and an half. The Thumb was an Inch and a quarter long; the Fore-Finger Two Inches, the Middle-Finger Two Inches and an half; the Ring-Finger Two Inches and a quarter, and the Little Finger One Inch and an half long. The Girth of the Thumb and the Little Finger, was One Inch; the Girth of the other Fingers was an Inch and a quarter. The Palm of the Hand was Three Inches long, and an Inch and three quarters broad.

From the head of the Thigh-Bone to the Heel, it meaured Twelve Inches: From the Heel to the end of the Middle-Toe (which was the longet) Five Inches three quarters. The Girth of the Thigh was Six Inches; of the Leg at the Calf, Four Inches and a quarter; of the Foot at the etting on of the Great Toe, near Five Inches. The Great Toe was an Inch and half long, the Fore-Toe One Inch, the Middle-Toe an Inch and half, the Third Toe an Inch and a quarter, the Little Toe One Inch long. The Sole of the Foot, about the etting on of the Great Toe (where 'twas broadet) was Two Inches over; but nearer the Heel, 'twas an Inch and half broad. The Girth of the Great Toe, where bigget, an Inch and half, the other Toes were an Inch about. Thee Meaures were taken before the Skin was trip't off, in the Skeleton, or the Skin tuff'd, they may prove otherwie.

And having now given thee Dimenions of the whole, and of mot of the External Parts; you will the better conceive the exact hape of this wonderful Animal by the Figures I have caued to be made of it. As the Firt Figure repreents our Pygmie erect, where you have a view of all the Fore-Parts. Being weak, the better to upport him, I have given him a Stick in his Right-Hand. But our Figure being made after he was dead, the Head eems too much fallen in between the Shoulders, as if it had a very hore or little or no Neck, which takes off from the Beauty of the Figure; but this is rectified and mended in the Figure of the Skeleton, where you will ee the Neck proportionate. The Head here is large and globous; the Ears tanding off, not lying cloe. The face looks like an Old wither'd Man's, which without doubt was render'd much more o, by an lcer it had in one of it's Cheeks, occaioned by a Fall it had on Ship-board upon a Cannon, which forced out one of it's Teeth; and the Jaw-bone afterwards proving carious, it might haten it's Death. The riing of the Cranium jut under the Eye-lids, as I have ramark'd, is different from what is in a Man, and renders the Face harder; as does likewie it's flat Noe, and the pper Jaw being more prominent, and leer pread, than in a Man; and it's Chin or nder Jaw being horter. The Eyes were a little unk, the Mouth large, the Teeth perfectly Humane. The Face was without Hair, and the Colour a little tawny; the Skin on the ret of the Body was white.

The Shoulders are pread and large, the Thorax or Breat extended altogether like a Man's, the Mammae and Teats the ame; the Belly was lank and pinch'd in, not prominent, by reaon of it's illnes; but here it held a more proportionable breadth to a Man's, than a Quadruped's. The Arms were longer than in a Man, and o were the Palms of the Hands; but the Thumb was much les, the Nails exactly like a Man's, and the Navel the ame. The Penis was different, as we hall hereafter hew. Here was no Scrotum, but the Tetes were contained in the Region of the Pubis under the Skin, which made it here more protuberant. The Thighs and Legs were omewhat divaricated or tradling, for want of trength, either from it's illnes, or being but young. We oberved Calves in it's Legs; the Feet long, as likewie the Toes, which were liker Fingers; and the Great Toe exactly like a Thumb, more than that on the Hand.

The Second Figure repreents the hinder Parts of this Creature, in an Erect Poture likewie. Where may be oberved, the Globous Figure and largenes of the Head, with the Ears tanding off; the curious nape and traitnes of the Back, and how it preads. At the Os Coxygis there is a little Protuberance, but nothing like a Tail.

In this Figure I have repreented him with the Fingers of one Hand bended, as if kneeling upon his Knuckles, to hew the Action, when he goes on all four: For the Palms of his Hands never touch the Ground, but when he malks as a Quadruped, 'tis only upon his Knuckles. The other Hand is holding a Rope, to hew his Climbing; for he will nimbly run up the Tackle of a Ship, or climb a Tree: And having this hold, he is the better upported, to hew the Sole of the left Foot, and the Heel there; on account of which Heel it may be thought a Foot: But the Great Toe being et off o far from the range of the others, and they all being o large and long, it more reembles a Hand, as has been oberved.

If we compare our Figures with thoe given by Tulpius, Bonlius, and Gener, we hall find a great difference. That of Tulpius eems the mot Natural; but being made itting, it does not o well repreent the Proportions of the everal Parts. The Chaps or Rotrum is longer, and 'tis les hairy in the fore-parts than ours. The Mammae are larger and pendulous, and the Belly more protuberant, Dapper, Dapper Decript. de l' A • iqu. p. m. 365. in his Decription of Africa, has borrowed this Figure from Tulpius, without naming him, as likewie his Decription, which is the ame. For avoiding the often quoting it, I will here Trancribe Tulpius's Account: But why I think it not a Satyr, as he and Dapper make it, I will give my Reaons in the following Eay. Tulpius his words are thee: Obervat. Med. lib. 3. cap. 56.

Quamvis extra forum Medicum, attexam tamen huic telae, Satyrum Indicum; votrâ memoriâ, ex Angolâ delctum: & Frederico Henrico, Arauionenium Principi, dono datum. Erat autem hic Satyrus quadrupes: ed ab humanâ pecie, quam prae e fert, vocatur Indis Orang-Outang: ive homo Sylvetris, uti Africanis Quoias morrou. Exprimens longitudine puerum trimum; ut craitie exennem.

Corpore erat nec obeo, nec gracili, ed quadrato: habiliimo tamen, ac perniciimo. Artubus verò tam trictis, & muculis adeò vatis: ut quidvis & anderet, & poet. Anteriùs undique glaber: at ponè hirutus, ac nigris crinibus obitus. Facies mentiebatur hominem: ed nares imae, & aduncae, rugoam, & edentulam anum.

Aures verò nihil dierepare, ab humanâ formâ. ti neque pectus; ornatum utrinque mammâ praetumidâ (erat enim fexûs foeminini); venter habebat umbilicum profundiorem; & artus, cum uperiores, tum inferiores, tam exactam cum homine imilitudinem: ut vix ovum ovo videris imilius.

Nec cubito defuit requiita commiura: nec manibus digitorum ordo: nedum pollici figura humana: vel cruribus furae: vel pedi calcis fulcrum. Quae concinna, ac decens membrorum forma, in causâ fuit, quod multoties incederet erectus: neque attolleret minùs gravatè, quàm transferret facilè, qualecunque, graviimi oneris, pondus.

Bibiturus prehendebat canthari anam, manu alterâ; alteram verò vais fundo upponens, abtergebat deinde madorem labiis relictum, non minùs adpoit, ac i delicatiimum vidies aulicum. Quam eandem dexteritatem obervabat utique cubitum iturus. Inclinans quippe caput in pulvinar, & corpus tragulis convenientèr operiens, velabat e haud alitèr, ac i vel molliimus illic decubuiet homo.

Quin imò narravit aliquandò affini notro, Samueli Blomartio, Rex Sambacenis, Satyros hoce, praeertim mares, in Inulâ Bornaeo, tantam habere animi conidentiam, & tam validam muculorum compagem: ut non emel impetum fecerint, in viros armatos: nedùm in imbellem, foeminarum, puellarumve, exum.

Quarum interdùm tàm ardenti flagrant deiderio: ut raptas non emel contuprarint. Summè quippe in venerem unt proclives (quod ipis, cum libidinois veterum Satyris commune) imò interdùm adeò protervi, ac alaces: ut mulieres Indicae, proptereà vitent, cane pejus & angue, altus, ac lntra, in quibus delitecunt impudica haec animalia.

Dapper, who hath trancribed this Account of Tulpius, (as I aid) but without taking any notice of him, makes this Preface to it. The Quoias Morrou (of which I have poken in the Kingdom of Quoia) are bred likewie in the Kingdom of Angola. This Animal, as it hath a great deal of a Man, o a great many have thought it to be the Iue of a Man and an Ape: But the Blacks themelves reject this Opinion. Now in the Place that Dapper refers to, he eems to give it as the Opinion of the Blacks, that they are the Iue of Men; but that by their always
living in the Woods, they are become half-Beats. I hall trancribe his Words, and o have done with him: Dapper ibid. p.m. 257. On trouve dans les bois une Epece de Satyre que les Negroes appellent Quoias-Morrou, & les Portugais, Salvage. Ils ont la ête groe, le Corps gros et peant, les bras nerveux, ils n'ont point de queve, et Marchent tantót tout droit, et tantót à quatre pieds. Les Animaux e nourrient de fruits et de Miel Sauvage, & e battent à tout moment ies uns contre les autres. Ils ont iu des Hommes, à ce dient les Negroes, mais ils ont devenus aini demi-bêtes en e tenant toûjours dans les Forêts. On dit qu'ils forcent les femmes & les filles, & qu'ils ont le courage d' attaquer des Hommes armez.

We will now examine Jacobus Bontius's Figure, and compare it with ours: And tho' he tells us, that he had een ome of both Sexes that went erect, epecially that Female one, whoe Effigies he here gives us; yet I can't but think, he indulged more his Fancy herein, than copied the true Life; or at leat it was much different from ours. For ours had no uch long Hair on the Head, and all round the Face; the Face of our Pygmie was not o flat and round, nor the Noe and nder-Lip o riing: The large Breats in his, anwers the Decription which is given of it by others; ours being a Male, had but mall ones. But the Armes in our Pygmie (as'tis in the Ape-kind) were much longer than they are repreented in his Figure, and the Feet are altogether different; for he makes them exactly like Humane Feet, and nothing like Hands, which is o Remarkable a thing in all thee Animals, that this Mitake of it elf, is enough to dicountenance the Truth of his Picture, and render it upected. I hall not take notice, how ill the Hair is drawn, nor make any further Remarks upon the tructure of the Limbs, ince I confes I do mitrut the whole Repreentation. But becaue he hath expres'd, that this Creature had o much Modety, I have added to his Figure what becomes that Character.

That Figure in Conradus Gener, Hit. de Quadruped. p.m. 859. which he tells us he had out of a German Book, wrote about the Holy Land, in ome Particulars I think more exact and jut: For here he makes the Feet like Hands, the Legs more divaricated, the Face longer, and the Rotrum more extended. But the Arms are too hort, and I do not know for what reaon there is a Tail clap't on, which its untowardly enough, which mut be urely an Addition of the Painter; or if there is any uch Creature in Nature, it mut be of another Family, different from ours.

However, I have caued all thee Figures to be copyed, that they may be the eaier compared: But ince they are o diagreeing, as are likewie
the Decriptions they give of them, it ufficiently jutifies my Complaint of the uncertainty we have of the true Animal, that they are dicouring about; ince the ame Name probably may be given to different Species of the Ape-kind. Now Orang-Outang, or Homo Sylvetris, or the Wild Man, being a General Name, I have given it alo to our Subject: Tho' I confes I am not fully atisfied whether it be exactly the ame with that of Tulpius or Bontius; or even whether that of Bontius be the ame with that of Tulpius. For Bontius his Account is o very imperfect, that from thence one cannot make a afe Concluion; and I rather upect the contrary: For Bontius decribes it with oft, tender Paions; Tulpius and Dapper make it Warlike and Fighting. Bontious's words are thee: Jac. Bontji, Hit, Nat. & Med. lib. 5. cap. 32. At quod majorem meretur admirationem, vidi ego aliquot utriuque exûs erectè incedentes, imprimis eam (cujus Effigiem hic exhibeo) Satyram femellam, tanta verecundia ab ignotis ibi hominibus occulentem, tum quoque faciem manibus (liceat ità dicere) tegentem ubertimque lachrymantem, gemitus cientem, & caetcros humanos actus exprimentem, ut nihil ei humani deee diceres, praeter loquelam. Loqui verò eos eaque poe, Javani aiunt, ed non velle, nè ad labores cogerentur: ridicule mehercules. Nomen ei indunt Ourang Outang, quod Hominem Sylvae ignificat, coque naci affirmant è Libidine Mulierum Indarum, quae e Simiis & Cercopithecis detetandâ libidine micent: Nec pueri credunt, nii qui nondum aere lavantur.

And then adds, that in Borneo there are thee Wild Men, and with Tails, but much horter than that pictured in Gener. Porrò in Inulâ Borneo (aith Bontius) in Regno Succodana dicto, à notris Mercatoribus propter Oryzam & Adamantes frequentato, Homines montani Caudati in interioribus Regni inveniuntur, quos multi è notris in Aulâ Regis Succodanae viderent. Cauda autem illis est prominentia quaedam ois Coccygos, ad quatuor, aut paulò ampliùs, digitos excrecens, eodem modo, quo truncata cauda (quos nos Spligiones vocamus) ed depilis.

'Tis for this Reaon therefore, that I might more particularly ditinguih our Animal, that I have call'd it a Pygmie; a Name that was formerly given to a ort of Ape, as I hall prove. But the Poets and Hitorians too of former Ages have invented o many improbable Stories about them, that they have rendred the whole Hitory concerning them ridiculous, and not to be believed. We hall therefore endeavour to ditinguih the Truth from the Fables in the following Eay.

TheBarisorBarrislikewie eems to be an Ourang Outang,or a Wild Man; but whether exactly the ame with ours, I will not determine, but leave to farther Enquiry. For all the Accounts concerning it that I
have at preent met with, relate rather it's Docility and Actions, and the Servile Offices 'tis capable of performing in a Family, than any thing particular as to the Decription of the Body; only in general that 'tis an Ape like a Man. Thus Peter Gaendus Lib. 5. p.m. 71. in the Life of Peiresky tells us, that in Java Major were oberved by the Sieur de Saint-Amant, Animalia quae forent Naturae homines inter & imias mediae; which being doubted of ,Peireskyproduced a Letter from Natalis or Noël, a Phyician who lived in Africa, which gave him this Account. Ee in Guineâ Simias, barbâ procerâ, canâque, & pexâ propemodùm venerabileis, incedere ipos lentè, ac videri ibi prae caeteris apere: qui maximi unt, & Barris dicuntur, pollere maximè judicio; emel duntaxat quidpiam docendos; vete indutos illicò bipedes incedere; citè ludere fitulâ, Citharâ, aliique id genus (nam quod everrant domum, convertant veru, pinant in mortario, aliaque ratione famulatum praetant, haud reputari admodum) foeminas denique in iis pati mentrua, & mares mulierum ee appetentiimos. He likewie produced other Letters from Arcoius or d' Arcos, which related what happened to one of Ferraria when he was at Angola, the Country from whence our Animal, as likewie that of Tulpius came. I will give it in Gaendus's words: Incidit nempè quâdam die in Nigritam Canibus venantem Homines ut vium, Sylvetreis. Capto, caeoque i • orum uno, inhumanitatem Nigritae increpuit, qui in uum genus ità aeviret. Ille verò, falleris, inquit, nam hic non et homo, ed bellua homini perimilis, Quippe olâ pacitur herbâ, intetinaque Ovina habet, quod ut credas meliùs, rem ecce; imulque abdomen aperuit. Sequenti die rurus venatum, captique mas & foemina: huic Mammae ad pedis longitudinem: caeterà mulieri imillima fuit; nii quod Intetina quoque herbis oppleta, & cujumodi Ovis, habuit. Totum utique piloum Corpus, ed pilo brevi, ac atis leni.

Our Animal was not o bearded, as that of Natalis; and what Arcoius relates of his Wild Man, or Barris; as it's feeding upon Gras, and having it's Intetines like a Sheep's, all this is far different from ours; tho' as to it's docility and capacity of performing thoe Actions mentioned, I can't but think our Subject might eaily have been taught to do them; and, it may be, others too of the Ape-kind, tho' different: As there are wonderful Intances of this kind given of them by Nierembergius Hit. Nat. lib. 9. cap. 44. and others. Dapper's Dapper Decript. de • A •• ue. p. 249. Decription is much the ame. There is a ort of Ape (aith he) call'd Baris, which they take when young, and breed them up, and make them o tame, that they will do almost all the Work of a Slave: For they go ordinarily upright as Men do; they will beat Rice in a Mortar, carry Water in a Pitcher, and hew uch pretty Actions of Addres, that they extreamly divert their Maters. And in Nierembergius Hit. Nat. l. 9. cap. 45. there is much the ame Account. In Guineâ cribit P. Jarricus exitere Simias, quae intar famuli in Pilâ tundant quaecunque in
eam imponuntur, quae aquam à fluviis in Hydriis capite domùm deferant, ità tamen ut ubi primùm domûs fores attigerint, illicò Hydriis exonerandae int, alioqui eas excidere, cauque ito frangi, atque tùm clamoribus ac fletu compleri univera. Neque ita modo, ed plurima item alia obire de dometicis miniteriis dicuntur hi Simij Baris. Toroi unt & robuti.

But all this does not ufficiently inform us of the particular hape, tructure, and make of the Body and the everal Parts of this Animal, o as to be fully certain whether it be the ame, or a different-Creature from the Ourang-Outang. And tho' I have mentioned it, as a Conjecture that probably the Baris might be, what we call a Drill, yet I own it as an uncertainty, ince I have not met with what can jutifie, or fully atisfie me herein.

The Pongo likewie which is decribed by Purchas, as a ort of Wild Man, is different from our Subject; as it may be alo from the ret hitherto mentioned. The Reaon, therefore, why I inert the Decription of this, as likewie of the others, I own to be, that hereby I might excite ome Inquiitive Obervers to give us a truer Account of this large and noble Species of Animals. 'Tis an Enquiry that would recompence their Curioity with abundance of Satisfaction, by the many and ueful Dicoveries that they would make, and extreamly enrich the Natural Hitory of Animals, whoe enlargement, I think, in this Inquiitive Age, hath not advanced o much as that of Botanie. For how great Diligence hath been ued of late, to ranack both the Indies, to pry into all the Corners of the World, both inhabited, and uninhabited, to find out a new Plant, not before decribed? And with what great Expence, and how magnificently are their Figures Printed? And how little hath been done in the Improvement of the Hitory of Animals? Not that I any ways dilike the former, but the latter being a Nobler Subject, I can't but recommend it, as deerving the Labours of the Curious likewie; and if any, this kind, I think, which comes o near to a Man, may be peak the preference.

But I beg the Reader's Pardon for this Digreion. Purchas's Purchas Pilgrims, Part. 2. l. 7, cap. 3. §. 7. words are thee: This Pongo is in all Proportions like a Man, but that he is more like a Giant-Creature, then a Man: For he is very tall, and hath a Man's Face, hollow-eyed, with long Hair upon his brows. His Face and Ears are without Hair and his Hands alo. His Body is full of Hair, but not very thick, and it is of a dunnih colour. He differeth not from a Man, but in his Legs, for he hath no Calf. He goeth always on his Legs, and carries his Hands claped on the Nape of his Neck, when he goeth upon the Ground.
They leep in the Trees, and build helters for the Rain. They feed upon Fruits that they find in the Woods, and upon Nuts; for they eat no kind of Fleh. They cannot peak, and have no ndertanding, no more than a Beat. The People of the Country, when they Travel in the Woods, make Fires, where they leep in the Night: And in the Morning when they are gone, the Pongoes will come and it about the Fire, till it goeth out; for they have no ndertanding to lay the Wood together. They go many together, and kill many Negroes that Travel in the Woods. Many times they fall upon Elephants, which come to feed where they be, and o beat them with their clubbed Fits, and pieces of Wood, that they will run away roaring from them. Thee Pongoes are never taken alive, becaue they are o trong, that Ten Men cannot hold one of them: But yet they take many of their Young Ones with poioned Arrows. The Young Pongo hangeth on his Mother;s Belly, with his Hands fat claped about her; o that when any of the Country People kill any of the Females, they take the Young one which hangeth fat upon his Mother. When they die among themelves, they cover the Dead with great heaps of Boughs and Wood, which is commonly found in the Forrets.

Our Pygmie had Calves in his Legs, tho' not large, being emaciated; and it being young, I am uncertain to what height in time it might have grown; tho' I cannot think to the jut Stature (if there be any uch) of a Man. For different Nations extreamly vary herein, and even thoe of the ame. Nor did our Pygmie eem o dull a Creature as thee Pongoes, but on the contrary, very apprehenive, tho' nothing o robut and trong as they are repreented to be.

I hall only further add what le Compte, a Modern Writer, tells us of the Savage Man, and o I think I hall have done: For this Argument is o Fruitful, that one does not know when to conclude. Pag. m. 510. Lewis le Compte therefore in his Memoirs and Obervations upon China, tells us, That what is to be een in the Ile of Borneo, is yet more Remarkable, and urpaeth all that ever the Hitory of Animals hath hitherio related to be the most admirable, the People of the Country aure us, as a thing notoriouly known to be true: That they find in the Woods a ort of Beast, called the Savage Man; whoe Shape, Stature, Countenance, Arms, Legs, and other Members of the Body, are o like ours, that excepting the Voice only, ons hould have much ado not to reckon them equally Men with certain Barbarians in Africa, who do not much differ from Beats.

This Wild or Savage Man, of whom I peak, is endued with extraordinary trength, and notwithtanding he walks but upon two Legs; yet is he o wift of Foot, that they have much ado to out-run him. People of Quality
Coure him, as we do Stags here, and this ort of Hunting is the King's uual Divertiement. His Skin is all hairy, his Eyes unk in his Head, a tern Countenance, tanned Face; but all his Lineaments are pretty proportionable, although harh, and thickned by the Sun. I learn'd all thee Particulars from one of our French Merchants, who hath remained ome time upon the Iland. Nevertheles, I do not believe a Man ought to give much Credit to uch ort of Relations, neither must we altogether reject them as fabulous; but wait till the unanimous Tetimonies of everal Travellers may more particularly acquaint us with the Truth of it.

Paing upon a time from China to the Coat of Coramandel, I did my elf ee in the Straits of Molucca a kind of Ape, that might make pretty credible that which I just now related concerning the Savage Man.

It marches naturally upon it's two hind Feet, which it bends a little, like a Dog's, that hath been taught to Dance, it makes ue of it's two Arms as we do; it's Viage is in a manner as well favoured, as theirs of the Cape of Good Hope; but the Body is all covered with a white, black, or grey Wool: As to the ret, it cries exactly like a Child; the whole outward Action is o Humane, and the Paions o lively and ignificant, that dumb Men can carce expres better their Conceptions and Appetites. They do especially appear to be of a very kind Nature; and to hew their Affections to Perons they know and love, they embrace them, and kis them with transports that urprie a Man. They have alo a certain motion, that we meet not with in any Beat, very proper to Children, that is, to make a noie with their Feet, for joy or pight, when one gives, or refues them what they pa • ionately long for.

Although they be very big, (for that I aw was at least four Foot high) their nimblenes and light is incredible; it is Pleaure beyond expreion to ee them run up the Tackling of a Ship, where they ometimes play, as if they had a particular knack of Vaulting to themelves, or as if they had been paid, like our Rope-Dancers, to divert the Company.

Sometimes upended by one Arm, they poie themelves for ome time negligently to try themelves, and then turn, all on the udden, round about a Rope, with as much quicknes as a Wheel, or a Sling that is once put in motion; ometimes holding the Rope ucceively with their long Fingers, and living their whole Body fall into the Air, they run full peed from one to the other, and come back again with the ame wiftnes. There is no Poture but they imitate, nor Motion but they perform; bending themelves like a Row, rowling like a Bowl, hanging by the Hands, Feet, and Teeth, according to the different Fancies which their whimical Imagination upplies them with, which they Act in the most diverting manner imaginable; but their Agility to ting themelvs from one Rope to another, at Thirty and Fifty Foot ditance, is yet more urpriing.

In this Character there are everal things I could take notice of, and I may hereafter have occaion to refer to ome of the Particulars; But what is mention'd of it's Cry, like a Child's; and it's expreing the Paions of Joy and Grief, by making a Noie with it's Feet, is agreeable enough to the Relation I had of our Pygmie: For I heard it Cry my elf like a Child; and he hath been often een to kick with his Feet, as Children do, when either he was pleaed or angered.

We hall now proceed to the Anatomy, which in a Hitory of Animals, is certainly the mot Neceary, mot Significant, and Intructive Part. Nor can I ee, how an Hitory of Animals can be well wrote without giving the Diection of the Inward Parts: 'Tis as if one hould undertake to decribe a Watch, and at the ame time, take notice only of the Cae or Cover, and tell what fine Garniture there is about it; but inform us nothing of the admirable Contrivances of the Wheels and Springs within, which gives it Life and Motion. Galen De Anat. Adminitr. lib. 1. cap. 2. p. m. 27.z thought the Diection of Apes very ueful for the undertanding the Structure of the Parts in Humane Bodies; and recommends it to his Scholars to Practice themelves herein. Not that he only diected Apes, (as Vealius oftentimes charges him with) or preferred it before the Diection of Humane Body: But where that could not be had, he advies them to get Apes, and diect them; epecially thoe that come nearet to a Man. Had he known our Pygmie, no doubt but he would have preferred it, for this purpoe, as much beyond the Ape, as he does the Ape beyond the Cynoceph •••• , and all other Animals. For, as we hall oberve, there is no <> , I have • i • herto met with, or heard of, that o exactly ree •••••
Man, in the Structure of the Inward Parts, as our Pygmie: But w ••••• t differs, (as I have remark'd) there it reembles an Ape; being different both from a Man and an Ape: And in many things agreeing with both of them.

The Skin of the whole Body of our Pygmie was whitih; but that on the Head was tawny, and of a darker colour. 'Twas thin, but trong, and adhered pretty firmly, and more than uually to the Fleh; it's greatet adhaeion was at the Linea alba, and in the Palms of the Hands, and the Soles of the Feet, and in the Fingers and Toes; as it is in Men. In the Skin of the Arm-pits, I oberved thoe Glandulae Cutaneae Axillares, which ecrete that Orange-coloured Liquor, which in ome Men tains the Shift here, with that colour. I call them Cutaneae, to ditinguih them from thoe larger Glands, that lie bedded under in the Fat, and are call'd Glandulae Axillares. For thee I have oberved to be Lymphatic Glands; and have traced the Lymphaducts thence to the head of the Ductus Thoracicus, where they empty themelves.

Together with the Skin, we took off the Mammae or Breats, which tuck cloe to it: And in our Subject, being a Male, they were but mall and thin; yet I could plainly perceive they were made up of abundance of mall Glands. I have already mentioned, how large the Breats are in the Female Orang-Outang, and the Baris, o that no Woman's are larger. As to their Situation, and their being placed upon the Pectoral Mucles, this I find is common to the Ape-kind: And they are o decribed by the Pariians Memoirs for a Natural Hitory of Animals, p. 162, &c. Englih Tranlation. in the Monkeys they diected; as alo in the Apes diected by Drelincourt: Apud Ger. Bla •• , An •• . Animal. cap. 33. pag. 109, &c. And becaue I hall have frequent occaion of referring to thee Authors, unles I ignifie otherwie, I hall always mean the Places here quoted, without mentioning them any more.

In Brutes, next under the Skin, lies a Muculous Membrane, which therefore is call'd Panniculus Carnous, which gives a motion to it, whereby they can hove off what offends them. In Man 'tis otherwie; for next to the Skin, lies the Membrana Adipoa; or the Fat, and under that, the Membrana Carnoa: And the ame I oberved in our Pygmie; for the Fat here lay next to the Skin. Drelincourt, in the Apes he diected, oberved the Panniculus Carnous next to the Skin, as 'tis in Brutes. For in the Male Ape, he tells us, Adeps nullus inter Panniculum Carnoum & Cutim; and in the Female, Panniculus Carnous cuti cohaerens, nullo adipe interjecto, Adipous nullus. So that in this Particular, our Pygmie is like to a Man, and different from the Ape-kind.

Having eparated the Skin and Membrana Adipoa, which in our Subject was not very thick, it being emaciated by it's illnes, we come now to the Mucles. But I hall reerve my elf to treat of them in the Myology. Next under the Mucles was the Peritonaeum, a Common Membrane, that lines all the inide of the Abdomen, and ends a common outward Membrane to all the Vicera contained therein, and o ecures their Situation. In this Membrane in Quadrupeds there is in the Groin of each ide, a Perforation, or rather a Proceus, by which the Seminal Veels pas down to the Tetes in the Scrotum, as is very plain in Dogs and other Animals. But in Man, whoe Poture is erect, 'tis otherwie. For here thee Veels pas between the two Coats, that make up this Membrane, the Peritonaeum; o that the inward Coat, that repects the Cavity of the Abdomen, is altogether entire, and continued, and 'tis only the outward Coat that is protruded into this Proces; and this for a very good Reaon. For otherwie, a Man, whoe Poture is erect, would be contantly liable to an Hernia, or a Rupture; which happens when this inward Coat is protruded down likewie; and if there be a decent of the Intetines, 'tis then call'd Entero-cele: If of the Omentum, Epiploocele. In our Pygmie I oberved the Peritonaeum, in this repect, to be
formed exactly as 'tis in Man; and to be entire, and not protruded; as if Nature did deign it to go erect. In Apes and Monkeys 'tis otherwie. So Blaius Ger. Blaij Micellan. Anat. Hominis Brutorumque variorum, &c. in Octa •• . p. m 253. oberved in the Ape he diected, Proceus Peritonaei (aith he) eodem modo hic e habet, ac in Cane. Datur & hic facilis via tylo ex ventre in Proceum dictum inerendo. And the Pariians have remarked the ame in the Monkeys they diected, which is a notable difference of our Pygmie's from the Ape-kind, and an agreement with the Humane. Hereafter, whenever I mention Blaius, unles I pecifie otherwie, be pleaed to take notice, that I refer to this Quotation.

The Omentum or Caul in our Pygmie was very thin and large, falling over and covering mot parts of the Guts. 'Twas fatened a Little to the Peritonaeum in the Left Side.
