It had but little Fat, and was tinged in many places with a deep Yellow Colour, by the Bladder of the Gall, as was likewie part of the Duodenum. It had numerous Blood-Veels, and it's adhaeion to the Stomach, Colon, and other Parts, as in Man. The Remarks the Pariians make upon the Epiploon or Omentum of the Monkeys they diected, were different from our Subject. For they tell us, That the Epiploon was different from that of a Man, in everal things. Firt, It was not fatened to the Colon in o many places, having no connexion with the left part of this Intetine. Ours I found was fatened jut as 'tis in Man. Secondly, It had another Ligature, which is not found in Man, viz. to the Mucles of the Abdomen, by means of the Peritonaeum, which formed a Ligament; which we have oberved in the Hind of Canada. Ours adhered to the Left ide: Drelincourt oberved it in an Ape, to be fatened to the Right Side. Both I believe to be accidental, as I have frequently een it in Humane Bodies. And in one Patient I found it fixt to the Peritonaeum in the Groin, which gave him a great deal of Pain and Trouble, epecially when his Bowels were any thing extended with Wind. Thirdly, The Pariians ay, The Veels of the Epiploon, which in Man proceed only from the Vena Porta, did nevertheles In one of our Subjects come from the Cava, having there one of the Branches of the Hypogatrica, which was united to the Branches of the Porta. In our Animal thee Veels came all from the Porta, or rather emptied themelves into it. But they oberving it only in one Subject, and it being different in all other Animals, it mut be accidental. Fourthly, In fine, the whole Epiploon was without Comparion greater than it generally is in Man; becaue, that it did not only cover all the Intetines, which is rarely een in Man, (whatever Galen ays) but it even enveloped them underneath, as it does in everal other Brutes; where it is frequently een, that the Epiploon is larger than in Man, epecially in Animals that do run, and leap with a great deal of Agility: As if it were o redoubled under the Inley • ward • to defend them, with the rest of the Bowels, against the rude jolts which thee Parts do
receive in running. It is true, that the Membranes of the Epiploon were entire and continued, as in Man, and not perforated like a Net, as they are in the generality of Brutes. The Epiploon or Caul in our Pygmie was very large, yet I have een the ame frequently in Humane Bodies; but when they are dieaed, 'tis often les and wated; o that Galen's Obervation may be true. But methinks the Reaon they give, why it hould be o large in Brutes, may be doubted of; for it being o tender a Part, it would be in danger, upon thoe violent motions, of being broken, had not Nature made it looe below, and free from any adhaeion; and it being o, it cannot perform the Office they aign it. Drelincourt's Account of the Epiploon, as he oberved it in the Female Ape, I like better. Epiploon macrum (aith he) vais turgidis involvens Intetina omnia, uque ad pubem, adhaerens Extremo Hypochondrio dextro, quâ parte Colon ubtratum jecoris limbis. Idem adhaeret ventriculi fundo & Colo, ut in homine. And in the Male Ape he diected 'twas tinged yellow, as ours was.

We hall proceed now to the Ductus Alimentalis, at leat thoe parts of it that are contain'd in the Abdomen, viz. the Stomach and Intetines; which I make to be the true Characterisk of an Animal, and a Proprium quarto modo. For all Animals have thee Parts; and all that have them, are Animals. The Senes, or ome of them, are wanting in a great many Animals, and in ome we perceive none but that niveral one, Tactus, yet here we find a Ventricle and Intetines. By thee Parts 'tis, that the Animal Kingdom is principally ditinguih'd both from the Vegetable and Angelick. Vegetables, 'tis true, receive contantly Nourihment, and without it, they perih and decay; but 'tis in a far different manner; 'tis not received into uch an Organick Body, where the Food is prepared and digeted, and o the Nutritive parts thereof dipened afterwards into all the Body, and the ret ejected, as Excrementitious; this is only to be met with in Animals, and in all of them. But yet I find there are intermediate Species of Beings between Vegetables and Animals, as the Zoophyta: the Hitory of which I could extreamly deire might be given us; and can't but think that regularly in compiling a Hitory of Animals, one hould commence from them; and amongt thee, no doubt, but that there are everal degrees of Perfection, till we come to what might be properly called an Animal. I have had no Opportunity of oberving any of them, but only one; wherein I could perceive a enible Motion and Contraction of ome of the Parts, but could not ditinguih any thing like the Structure of any of the Parts in an Animal, or the Organs that belong to them. An Accident diappointed me of perfecting my Obervations, otherwie I hould have communicated what I had dicovered. But am enible that there are great Curioities here to be met with, if diligently enquired into; and that they might be, was the occaion of this Digreion.

This Canalis Alimentalis therefore, or Inductory Veel (as I call it, for the Reaons I have often mentioned in my Anatomical Lectures at Chirurgeon's Hall) is commonly ditingihed into three Parts; The Gula, the Ventricle, and Intetines: The two latter do lie in the Cavity of the Abdomen, the former, in the Thorax and Neck; but being but one continued Canalis, I hall treat of the whole here.

The Gula or Gullet, by M. T. Cicero de Nat. Deorum, lib. 2. §. 54. p. m. 42. Tully (in that excellent Anatomical Lecture he gives us, where he is proving a Providence) is call'd Stomachus. As 'tis alo by Celus Cornel. Celus, de re Med. lib. 4. cap. 1. o likewie in A. Gellius, A. Gellij. Noct. Attic. lib. 17. cap. 11. and frequently by Hippocrates. Fid. Anut. Foeii Occonom. Hi • p. in verb • . And Aritotle Arit. Hit. An • m. lib. 1. cap. 10. §. 108. p. m. 89. &
• aim • lit. and Galen Galen de licis aectis. lib. 5. cap. 5. p.m. 490. exprely tell us, that that Part between the Fauces and the Ventricle, which the Antients called Oeophagus, after Aritotle's time, was wont to be call'd Stomachus, tho' now this word is more appropriated to the Ventricle it elf, which Tully in the ame place calls Alvus. So true is that of Horace,
Horace de Arts Poetic. ver. 60. t Sylvae foliis pronos mutantur in annos
Prima cadunt: it a verborum vetus interit aet • s.
However I hall follow Horace's Rule, ince Cutom now hath appropriated the word Stomach, to the Ventricle, epecially our Englih Tongue, I hall do o too.
Multa renacentur, quae jam cecidere: cadentque
Quae nunc unt in honore vocabula: i volet uus:
Quem penes arbitrium est, & vis & norma loquendi. Horace. Ibid.
• . •• .

This Gula or Gullet is a Hollow Mucle, and fitly enough compared to a Funnel; where the Mouth, which may be thought a Part belonging to it, being more capacious, firt receives the Food, and prepares it, by chewing, and then forces it down into this Stem or Pipe, to convey it to the Ventricle. I did not oberve, upon the Diection, any difference of this Part in our Pygmie, from that of a Man. For as in a Man, (and o conformable too in other Circumtances) it paed under the lower Mucle of the Diaphragm, which by that lant running of it's flehy Fibres over it, may perform to it the Office of a Valve, and prevent the Regurgitation of the Food that way. Which may be the more neceary in our Subject, becaue being ued to climb Trees, and in coming down, to be prono Capite, it might be the more liable to this Accident. But for the better preventing this, I find here, that the Paage of the Gula, a little above where it empties it elf into the Ventricle, was traiter, and
the inward Membrane here more rugous than in a Man; o that it eemed omewhat Analogous to a Valve. Drelincourt decribes it, in the Female Ape he diffected, thus. Orificium ejus uperius, nullâ Valvulâ clauum; ed interceptum duplici portione Diaphragmatis carnosâ, ab ejus tendinibus oriundâ.

The Ventricle or Stomach, as we hall call this Part, in our Pygmie, as to it's Situation and Figure, exactly repreented a Humane Stomach. When inflated, from the entrance of the Gula along the upper part to the Pylorus, it meaured Two Inches and three quarters. Meauring with a Thread from the Pylorus along under the Fundus, up again to the entrance of the Gula, I found it to be Fifteen Inches; in all, near Eighteen Inches. The length of the Stomach in a trait Line, was Six Inches and an half; and it's breadth in a trait Line, where broadet, near Four Inches. The Girth of the Stomach in the middle, was near Twelve Inches. So that I thought the Stomach large, in Proportion to the bulk of the Body. It had numerous Blood-Veels, preading themelves all over, as in a Man's; and I could plainly perceive the Inoculations of large Trunks of the Coronary Branches, with thoe that decended from the upper Parts.

The Pariians oberved in their Monkeys, That the Ventricle did likewie differ from a Man's, it's inferiour Orifice being very large and low; for it was not elevated o high as the uperiour, as it is in a Man. I did not oberve this in our Pygmie. So Drelincourt tells us in the Female Ape, Ventriculus rugis interiùs nullis gaudet; and ome other Particulars he takes notice of. But there was nothing in ours, that I oberved, different from a Man's.

As to their Food, I find it very different in the Ape-kind; as in part appears by what I have already mentioned of the Ourang Outang, the Baris, the Pongo, &c. So that I can't but think, (like a Man) that they are omnivorous. What chiefly our Pygmie affected, when Wild, I was not informed of; after it was taken, and made tame, it would readily eat any thing that was brought to the Table; and very orderly bring it's Plate thither, to receive what they would give him. Once it was made Drunk with Punch, (and they are fond enough of trong Liquors) But it was oberved, that after that time, it would never drink above one Cup, and refued the offer of more than what he found agreed with him. Thus we ee Intinct of Nature teaches Brutes Temperance; and Intemperance is a Crime not only againt the Laws of Morality, but of Nature too.

Jacobus Bontius Jac. B • ntii. Ht. N. • . & Md. lib. 4. in Animada. in Garciae ab Orto, Cap. 45. p.m. 48. tells us, that the Bezoar-tone is bred in the Stomachs of Apes, as well as Goats, and he prefers it as the bet. Porrò vidi (aith he) & Lapides Pa-zahar natos in ventriculis Simiorum, qui teretes unt & longitudinem digiti aliquandò excedunt, qui praetantiimi omnium cenentur. Pa-zahar, he tells us a little before, ignifies in the Perian, contra veneuum, whence may come the word Bezoar. Joh. Georg. Volchamerus Mi • cell. Curi •• a German. De <…> an.1583. •• erv. 189. p.420. takes notice of one he had from Grimmius out of the Baboon-kind, as big as a Wallnut. And in the Scholium on that Obervation, Joh. Bapt. Tavernier's Jo. Bapt. Tavern. lib. 2. • tin. Indic. c.p.24. Travels are quoted, where he prefers two Grains of this, before ix of the Goat-Bezoar. Tho' Philip. Baldaeus, in his Decription of Malabar and Cormandel, does eteem it much cheaper, Caper Bauhinus hath wrote a ditinct Treatie of the Bezoar-tone, to whom I refer my Reader; and hall only farther oberve of it, that I think this Medicine ought not to be depied, becaue in Health a Man may take a large Quantity of it, without any Injury; for I have evidently een in the greatet Weaknees, mot Remarkable Effects from it, and have had Succes beyond expectation; it upporting the Spirits, and relieving them, where a more active Medicine might over-power them, and yet not have done that Service.

But this Stone in Goats and Monkeys is a Dieae, and not Natural; as well as the Stone in the Bladder or Kidneys of a Man. Bontius Bontius <> in c.p. 46. p.m. • 8. therefore oberving the good Effects of the Bezoar-tones bred in thee Animals, argues with himelf, why thoe in Men, which he finds laminated in the ame manner, might not be of as great an Efficacy; and upon Tryal, he aures us, that they are o. Hoc ceriè compertum habeo, Lapidem in veicâ hominis repertum, urinam & udores probe ciere, quod tempore ingentis illius petis quae Anno 1624 & 1625. Leydam, Patriam means & reliquas Hollandiae Civitates, mierandum in modum vatabat, in penuriâ Lapidis Baaartici, nos exhibuie memini, & Sudorificum (auim dicere) melius & excellentius invenie, cum admixtâ Theriacâ aut Mithridatio, cum Olco Succini aut Juniperi guttis aliquot.

We come now to the Third Stage of the Ductus Alimentalis, the Intetines; which erve for the eparating the Chyle from the Facaes, and o tranmitting it into the Vaa Chylifera, or Venae Lacteae;, as they are call'd, which conveys it into the Blood, for the recruiting the contant wate that is made there, and repairing it's loffes; as alo for the Nourihment and Augmentation of the Parts: And for the doing this, 'tis requiite that the Inte • ines hould be long; and they being o, that they hould be coyled and winding; that this Separation might be the better performed, and o we find the Guls in our Pygmie. For from the Pylorus
to the Anus, they meaured Thirteen Feet and three Inches, viz. from the Pylorus to the Caecum or beginning of the Colon, was Nine Foot Ten Inches; and the Colon and Rectum were Three Feet and Five Inches long. The Caecum here, or Appendicula vermiformis, was Four Inches and three quarters long. So that the length of the Guts here, in proportion to tne length of the Body, is much the ame as 'tis in a Man. But in two of the Sapajous diffected by the Pariians, the whole Intetines were but Five Foot two Inches; and in the other two Monkeys, Eight Foot long. So that herein our Pygmie more reembles a Man, than their Monkeys did.

And as in the length, o likewie in other Circumtances, the Intetines of our Pygmie were liker to thoe of a Man, than thoe of the Monkey and Ape-kind are. For the Pariians tell us, that in their Monkeys, the Intetines were almost all of the ame bignes, and that the Ileon was in proportion a great deal bigger, than in a Man. In our Subject we found a enible difference. For the mall Guts, which were much of a bignes, being a little extended, meaured in Compas about Two Inches and three quarters. The Colon was Three Inches and three quarters about; and the Appendicula Vermiformis (which was in our Pygmie as 'ris in a Man, and is not to be met with in Apes and Monkeys) was about the bignes of a Gooe-quill. It's length I have mentioned before.

Into the Duodenum of our Pygmie, a little below the Pylorus, were inerted the Ductus Communis of the Gall, and the Ductus Pancreaticus; they both emptying themelves into the Gut at the ame Orifice as is uual in Man. And the ame is oberved likewie by Drelincourt in the Male Ape he diffected, where he tells us, à Pyloro qui videtur uggrunda • e circularis & carnoa principio Ecphyeos praepoita, ad foramen uque intra candem Ecphyin Commune Ductui Bilario & Wirzungiano, praecie pollex et Mathematicus; ab illo autem foramine intra duplicem Ecphyeos tunicam tilus gracillimus intruus est in praedictam Veiculae felleae recurvitatem, ruruque ab eodem Intetinali foramine idem tilus compulus est in Ductum Wirzungianum. But the Pariians oberved in the Monkeys, that the Inertion of the Ductus Pancreaticus into the Intetine, (which in Man is always near the Porus Bilarius) was Two Inches ditant there-from. So that in this Particular the Monkey does not o much reemble a Man, as Apes and our Pygmie do.

The Convolutions and Windings of the mall Guts in our Pygmie, and their Situation, were much the ame, as in a Man: And they were all plentifully irrigated with Blood-Veels. In the inward Coat of the Intetines I could oberve the Miliary Glands, decribed by Dr. Willis; as alo thoe larger cluters of Glands, mentioned by Joh. Conrad. Peyerus. The Colon I thought proportionably longer, than 'tis in a Man. It had the ame Ligaments and Cells, and leaves of Fat hanging to it, as a Man's
hath; and the ituation, was the ame: but it being o long, it had more windings than uually. The Pariians oberved in their Monkeys, that the Colon was not redoubled like an S. as in Man, being quite trait. Drelincourt's Ape was more like ours, for peaking of the Colon, he aith, retorquetur variè antequàm producat Rectum; cellulas habet ut in Homine. For the length of the Colon in the Monkeys diffected by the Pariians, was but thirteen Inches; and an Inch in Diameter; whereas, the Colon of our Pygmie with the Rectum, was three Foot five Inches, as I have mentioned; and therefore liker to a Man's, and requiring thee convolutions the more.

In a Man the Intetines are commonly ditinguihed into Intetina Tenuia and Craa: The Tenuia are ubdivided into the Duodenum, Jejunum, and Ileon; The Craa, into the Caecum, Colon and Rectum: and the Caecum commonly is reputed that Appendicula Vermiformis, which is placed at the beginning of the Colon, where the Ileon empties it elf into it. Now this Part in a Man, being o mall; and being oberved never to contain any Excrement; I can't think, that it deerves the Name of an Intetine, much les to be reputed one of the Craa. 'Tis true, in Brutes, this part is often ound to be very large and capacious; and to be filled with faces; and in uch, it may be jutly eteemed an Intetine. As in a Rabit, 'tis very long and hath a Cochlear Valve; o in an Otridge, there are two Caecums; each a yard long, with a like Valve, But in Man, 'tis far different. Many therefore do not think this Proceus Vermiformis, to be the Caecum; but rather take for is, that bunching out of the beginning of the Colon; which is projected beyond the entrance of the Ileon; which in the Common Ape and Monkey is more, than in a Man. However, I think it not enough, as to make it a ditinct: Intetine; and the number of the Intetines in a Man, ought to be made fewer.

Our Pygmie therefore having this Proceus Vermiformis in all Circumtances, o like to that in a Man; and Monkeys and Apes having nothing like it: it is a remarkable difference of our Subject from them, and an agreement to the Structure of a Humane Body. So the Pariians tell us in their Monkeys, the Caecum had no Vermiform Appendix. So in the Ape diected by Blaius, he • aith, Proceus Vermiformis in totum hic deideratur. And o Drelincourt, Caecum caret Epiphyi Vermiformi, qualem homines habent. We will ee therefore, what kind of Caecum 'tis, that they decribe in the Monkeys and Apes.

The Pariians tell us, in the Diffection of their Monkeys; That the Caecum was very large, containing two Inches and half in length; and an Inch Diameter at the beginning: it went pointing, and was fortified by three Ligaments, like as the Colon is in Man; there to form little Cells; this Conformation is wholly different from that of a Man's Caecum. 'Tis true, 'tis more projected, than in a Man; So Blaius in his Ape, makes it jutting
out beyond the Inertion of the Ileon, Manûs tranverae, eu trium digitorum patium. And Drelincourt tells us, duarum unciarum est. But ince it hath thoe Ligaments of the Colon, 'tis plain, that 'tis only a part of it, and not a ditinct Intetine; or as Blaius more truly calls it, Principium Coli. He hath given a figure of it, but not very exact; and in another figure he repreents the Valve of the Ileon at the Colon, or rather Valves; for he makes more than one. His Decription, as 'tis faultily printed; o I am afraid, it is not very accurately drawn up, and therefore do omit it.

But what is different from a Man, as alo from the Ape and Monkey too, or any other Animal I yet know of; is a ort of Valve I oberved at the other Extream of the Colon in our Pygmie, where it paes into the Rectum. For the turn of the Colon here, is very hort; and in the inide I oberved a Membranous Extenion like a Valve, an Inch in length, which divided the Cavity half way. The Rectum did not much differ from the Colon in the magnitude of it's fistula, but was much the ame; and in other repects, as 'tis in a Man.

This great length of the Intetines in our Pygmie was orderly colligated and fatened to the Meenterie, which kept them in a due ituation; and o, as to make in them, everal windings or convolutions; that hereby they might the better make a ditribution of the Chyle; and the whole was, as 'tis in a Man. But I oberved here, the Membranes of the Meenterie, to be more looly joyned together, than uually. For by moving them by my fingers, I found the blood veels which were fatened to the upper Membrane, would eaily hove over thoe, that were fixt in the under Membrane of the Meenterie; and run on either ide of one another, as I would draw them. I have ometimes een the ame in Humane Bodies.

The Mearaic Veels here, were very numerous; as they approach the Intetines, they form everal Arches, whereby they communicate with one another; and from thee Arches, they end out numerous Branches to the Intetines of each ide, which run claping them; afterwards they ubdivide, and inoculate with one another in infinite Ramuli: o that by injecting thee Veels with Mercury, they appeared o numerous; as almot wholly to cover the Trunk of the Intetines. And the ame is in Man.

I have likewie een, by injecting the Meenterick Veels; that the Mercury has paed into the Lymphaeducts; and o into the Venae or Vaa Lactea. Which is a great contrivance of Nature. For the Motion of all fluids being Pulion, without this advantage, part of the Chyle, mut necearily tagnate in ome of the Veels; till a freh ditribution of Chyle comes; to protrude it on; and o it would be apt to coagulate and
caue Obtructions. But by the Lympha thus paing into them; the Chyle is till forced forwards, and the veels wahed clean of it; and being thus often moitened, they are preerved from becoming over dry, or cloed or obtructed. So Provident therefore is Nature, that in the whole Via lactea, not only in the Meenterie; but into the Receptaculum Chyli, and Ductus Thoracicus likewie; abundance of Lymphaeducts are emptied. Which gives us one good Reaon; that Nature does not act in vain, in making uch a eparation of à Liquor from the Mas of Blood; which is o oon to be return'd to it again; ince hereby he performs o great an Office.

In the Meenterie of our Pygmie I oberved everal mall Glands cattered up and down, as in a Man; but not o regularly amaed together in the middle; as the Pancreas Aellij is in Brutes. And Drelincourt oberved much the ame in the Male Ape. Glandulae ad radicem Meenterij, & paim in ambitu, numeroae & planae, magnitudinem Lentulae, ed Ovales. Anatomoes frequentiimae Venarum cum Venis & Arteriarum cum Arteriis in univero Meenterij circulo. And as that part of the Meenterie which fatens the Colon is call'd Meocolon; o for the ame reaon, that lip of it repreented in our figure, that runs down to the Proceus vermiformis, may be call'd the Meo-caecum.

We hall next proceed to the Liver, in which part our Pygmie very remarkably imitated a Man, more than our common Monkeys or Apes do. For the Liver here was not divided into Lebes as it is in Brutes; but intire as it is in a Man. It had the ame hape; it's ituation in the body was the ame; and it's Colour, and Ligaments, the ame, It meaured in it's greatet length about five Inches and an half; where broadet, 'twas about three Inches; and about an Inch and three quarters in thicknes. Towards the Diaphragm 'twas convex: it's under part was Con • ave, where it receives and emits the Veels, having a little Lole here, as 'tis in a Man.

The Pariians remark in the Monkeys they diffected, that the Livermas very different from the Liver of a Man, having five Lobes as in a Dog; viz. two on the right ide; and two on the left; and a fifth laid upon the right part of the body of the Vertebrae. This last was divided, making as it were two leaves. So Drelincourt in the Male Ape oberves , Je •• ris I <> duo juxta umbilicalem venam, quorum ecundo incuneata crat ve •• ula f • llis, duo alij ventriculum amplectebantur, cum lobulo quinto e inercute in patium ventriculi intra orificium utrumque. So likewie in the Female Ape he tells us , Jecur opplet regionem Epigatricam quint uplici lobo, uno exto minimo opplens cavitatem lunarem ventriculi. But Blaius in the Ape he diected aith , Epar cum humano minimò, optimè cum Canino convenit, manif • tiimè in lobos VII divium, tantae magnitudinis ut etiam utrumque Hypoclondrium
occupet. Vealius Vealij de fabricâ corporis humani, lib. 5. cap. 7. p.m .619. therefore is in the right, where he aith, Quae enim Diectionum Profeores de Jecoris formâ, ac penulis eu fibris (quos < in non-Latin alphabet > Graeci vocant) commentantur; è Canum potiùs, & imiarum ectionibus, quàm hominum didicerunt. Humanum enim Jecur in fibras, Porcini, ac multò adhuc minùs Canini Jecoris modo, non dicinditur. And that he hints here at Galen, is plain, from what he exprees in his Epitle ad Joachim Roelants,
Andr Vealij Epistola, &c. p.m. 81. where he farther enlarges upon it. And Galen
Galen. de Anat. Adminitrat. lib. 6.cap. 8. himelf tells us, that Herophilus was of this Opinion. So Theophilus Protopatarius
Theophilus de Corporis humani fabrica, lib. 2. cap. 2. aith, that the Liver is divided into four Lobes; and gives us there a ditinct Name for each . Aritotle,
Arit. Hit. Animal, lib. 1. cap. 17. p. m. 595. 'tis certain, was much more in the right, where he aith , < in non-Latin alphabet > . Rotundum Jecur hominis et, ac imile bubulo. For the Liver of a Bullock, like a Man's is entire; and not divided into Lobes. However Francicus Puteus
Franc. Putei Apologia pro Galeno in Anatomicis contra Andr. Vealium, lib. 5. p. m. 153. in his Apology, having named everal Phyicians and Chirurgians, that were with him at the opening of Charles the Ninth, Duke of Savoy, aith , hi omnes per Jovem mihi pount ee Tetes, quod obervatum est Epar habuie quatuor pinnulas. Jacobus Sylvius
Vaeani cujudam Calumniarum in Hipp. Galenique rem Anat. depulio. per Jac. Syivium. vid. Depul. 26. p. m. 150. likewie jutifies Galen, againt Vealius; and tells us , Quin & Hippocrates Lobos Epatis humani quinque connumerat libro uo de oibus, Rufus autem quatuor vel quinque. But Renatus Henerus
Renat. Henerus adverus Jacobi Sylvij Depulionum Anat. Calumnias. pro Andrea Vealio Apologia, p.m. 55. hath anwered Sylvius as to this matter; and there needs no farther dipute about it, if one will but believe his own Eyes, he may fully atisfie himelf, that, in an Humane Liver there are none of thoe Lobes, but that 'tis one entire Body; as it was alo in our Pygmie. But in Apes and Monkeys the Liver is divided into Lobes.

The great ue of the Liver is for to make a eparation of the Gall from the Mas of Blood. We will therefore here examine the Biliary Veels; nor do I find them any thing different from thoe in a Man; only the Bladder of Gall here in our Pygmie eemed longer, being four Inches in length. It's adhaeion to the Liver was not o much as it is in a Man; for at the fundus or end, it juts beyond the Liver about half an Inch. For about three quarters of an Inch, it is more cloely joyned to the Liver; afterwards it is fatened to it only by a Membrane, as is alo the Ductus Cyticus. So that the Veica fellea when inflated with wind, eemed more to repreent an Intetine by it's anfractus and length, than the uual hape of the Bladder of Gall; which commonly is more bellying out.

The Pariians oberved in their Monkeys, that the Bladder was fatened to the firt of the two Lobes which were on the right ide. That it was an Inch long, and
half an inch broad; it had a great Ductus, which was immediately inerted underneath the Pylorus. This Ductus received three others, which intead of that, which in Man is ingle, and which is called Hepaticus; thee three Ductus's had their Branches dipered like Roots into all the Lobes of the Liver, o that the first had four roots, viz. one in each of the three right Lobes, and one in the first of the left; the econd and third Ductus had both their roots in the econd of the left Lobes, thee branches did not run under the Tunicle of the Liver, o that they were apparent, and not hid in the Parenchyma, as they generally are. But in our Subject the ditribution of the Ductus Hepaticus was altogether the ame as it is in Man. In the Male Ape, Drelincourt decribing the Bladder of Gall, aith, Veicula fellea longa 22/3 pollicibus à fundo ad cervicem, ubi recurvitatem habet maximam, dimidiatè haeret mera ubtantiae Jecoris.

The Ductus Hepaticus in our Pygmie iued out of the Liver with two branches; one ariing from the right, the other from the left part of the Liver; and after a hort pace, joined into one Trunk; and that, after a little way, joyning with the Ductus Cyticus, do form the Ductus Communis, which empties it elf into the Duodenum a little below the Pylorus, at the ame Orifice with the Ductus Pancreaticus, exactly as 'tis in Man, as I have mentioned.

At the Simous part of the Liver I oberved the Vena Porta to enter, as likewie the Epatic Arteries and Nerves, And here in the Membrane about thee Veels, I oberved a pretty large whitih Gland. The Vena mbilicalis entered the Liver at the fiure. It eemed large, but I found it's fitula or pipe was cloed. The Vena Cava iued out of the Liver at the Convex part, where 'twas joyned to the Diaphragm.

In the Spleen of our Pygmie I did not oberve any thing extraordinary, or different from a Humane Spleen. It was of a lead Colour, and of the hape repreented in our figure; 'twas fatened by Membranes to the Peritonaeum; and by the Omentum and Vaa brevia to the Stomach, o that upon inflating the Stomach, the Spleen would be brought to lye cloe on the Stomach, as if it was fatened immediately there. The Spleen here was two Inches and an half long; and one Inch and a quarter broad; and eated as uually in the left Hypochondre under the Batard Ribs. The Ramus Splenicus was very remarkable, ending it's Trunk along the Pancreas, as in Man, and having numerous branches near the Spleen.

The Pariians tell us, that in their Monkeys the Spleen was eated along the Ventricle as in Man; but it's figure was different, in one of our Subjects being made as the Heart is repreented in Blazonry; it's Bais containing an Inch. They give a figure of it, but nothing like that of ours, which more repreented the figure of an Humane Spleen; tho' in Man it's figure is often oberved very different. Blaius in the Ape he diected, oberves
that the Spleen triangularis figurae est, exiguus admodùm repectu corporis; coloris nigricantis, laeve equidem molleque valdè corpus, at exteriùs inaequale quai ex globulis variis confectum, adeò ut etiam conglomeratis Glandulis Subtantiam Lienis annumerare velle, tali in ubjecto fundamentum aliquod agnocat. Ex Ramo Splenico numeroos eoque inignes Ventriculo uppeditat ramos, magnitudinem & figuram externam Fig. 3a. Tab. XI. exhibet. But his figure of the Spleen was nothing like to that of ours. For I did not oberve thoe inequalities in the uperfice which he repreents in his, to exhibit the conglomerate Glands. 'Tis true, having injected the Spleen of our Pygmie the Mercury filling the cellulated body of the Spleen, did make an appearance on the urface omewhat like thoe inequalities in his figure. But Frederic. de Ruch Epit • la Anatomica Pr • bl • matica qua • ta. is very poitive, that neither thoe Glands, nor Cells mentioned by Malpighius, are to be met with in a Humane Spleen: tho' he grants, that they are in the Spleen of Brutes. Drelincourt in the Female Ape aith, Lien Scalenum figura refert, cohaeret Reni initro & liber est • Diaphragmate. And in the Male Ape he oberves, Lien triangularis & craior quàm in foeminâ, Pancreas excipiens.

We hall therefore now proceed to the Pancreas, which in our Pygmie was ituated, jut as it is in a Humane Body; lying under the Stomach, tranvere to ihe Spine, from the Spleen towards the Liver. It was about two Inches long, about half an Inch broad, of a white yellowih Colour; it's urface uneven, being made up of abundance of Glands; it's Secretory Duct emptied it elf into the Duodenum, jut where the Ductus Communis of the Gall doth, as I have mentioned before.

The Pariians in their Monkeys oberved, that the Pancreas had only it's ecure, which made it to reemble that of Man; it's connection, and inertion being wholly particular. For it was trongly fatened to the Spleen; and the inertion of it's Ductus into ihe Intetine (which in Man is always near the Porus Bilarius) was two Inches ditant therefrom. Blaius in his Ape decribes it thus; Pancreas ventriculo ubtratum, olidoe admodùm ubtantiae est, nec adcò molle, quàm in Canibus aliique Animalibus notatur. Longum itidim inigniter, ast latitudinis cjus, q • aenè minimi digiti latitudini repondeat. He takes no notice here, how the Ductus Pancreaticus was inerted; which Drelincourt tells us in the Female Ape was eight lines above the Porus Bilarius. Pancreas connalum I • enali Caudae, & extremo Reni initro. Fjus ductus ineritur o • to lineis upra Porum Bilarium, contrà ac Canibus, ubternitur immediate Ventricilo, & uperternitur brevi Intetino. Tho' in the Male Ape he tells us. 'tis inerted into the Duodenum at the ame Oriice with the Duct of the Gall, as I have already mentioned and quoted before.

The Glandulae Renales in our Pygmie were very large, and placed a little above the Kidnies as they are in Man. That on the right ide, was of a triangular; that on the left of an oblong figure. They were about three quarters of an Inch long: and almot half an Inch broad. They had the ame Veels, as there are in a Man.

The Pariians in their Monkeys, oberve that the Gland called Capula Atrabilaria, was very viible, by reaon that the Kidney was without fat. This Gland was white, and the Kidney of a bright red; it's figure was triangular. Blaius in his Ape tells us, Glandula Renalis triangularis erè figuraeest, notabilis valdè pro ratione Corporis, and gives us a figure of it, which was nothing like ours. What Drelincourt remarks in the Male Ape, is, Capulae Atrabilariae triplicem Scrobiculum habent, quarum liquor expreus linguam non it à contringit, uti in Capulis foemineis. And in the Female Ape he tells us, Ren Succenturiatus initer ab Emulgente venam habet; idem major Dextro. This I oberved in our Pygmie; but he aith nothing farther here of their Liquor, nor did I tate it in ours.

We hall now proceed to the Kidneys. In our Pygmie I did oberve very little or no fat in the common or outward Membrane, uually called Adipoa: Drelincourt oberved the ame, nullus hic Adeps in Tunicâ communi vel propriâ, as he tells us of his Ape. The Kidneys of our Pygmie were two Inches and a quarter long, an Inch and an half broad; and about an Inch in depth. They had not altogether o large a Sinus at the Entrance of the Emulgent Veels, as there is in a Man's; and the whole appeared omewhat rounder; but their ituation was the ame, as were likewie the Emulgents. Having divided the right Kidney length-ways, I oberved the Cortical or Glandulous Part to appear like a ditinct Subtance, being a of tawny or yellowih colour; and different from the Inward or Tubulary Part; which was more entire and compacted together, than in a Man's; and was of a red colour, by means of the blood veels which run between the Tubuli rinarij or Secretory Ducts, which make up this part of the Kidneys. Which Veels when inflamed and overextended, by making a Compreion on thee Tubuli rinarij, may caue a Suppreion of Urine; in which cae Phlebotomy or Bleeding is very neceary. And without doubt was the Caue of the Succes Riverius Riverij Oberv. Med. Cent.I. Obj. 1. met with in a Patient, who had a Suppreion of Urine for three days; for upon bleeding freely, he was preently relieved, and in a hort time rendered a large quantity of Urine. In this Tubulary Part of a Humane Kidney I always oberve thee Blood Veels: but here uually the Cortical or Glandulous Part makes a deeper decent between the heads of this Tubulary, and divides it into everal Bodies; and as many of them as appear, o many leer Kidneys may be reckoned to make up the Body of each Kidney. In Infants the Kidney externally appears more divided
than in Adult Perons; but mot remarkably they are o, in a Bear, the Porpois and an Otrich; where there are abundance of ditinct mall Kidneys amaed together to make up each.

The Pariians in the Kidneys of their Monkeys oberve, that they were round and flat; their ituation was more unequal, than in a Man; the right being much lower than the left, viz. half it's bignes. Drelincourt in the Female Ape remarks, Renes globot, dexter intra Hypochondrium incumbit Cotae 11. & 12. Siniter locum habet intra Cotam ultimam. Altitudo Renis dimidiae unciae. Renalium venarum dextra longè elatior initrâ. Rene aperto Carnis dicrimen ut in homine, exterior quidem nigricans lineis quatuor craa, interior albicans lineis duabus.

The Pelvis of the Kidney in our Pygmie was as 'tis uually in a Man; and the reters had nothing remarkably different in their Structure, from the common make. They were about the bignes of a Wheat traw; and were inerted into the neck of the Bladder, as repreented in our figure; rather omewhat nearer the neck, than in an Humane Bladder.

The Pariians and Blaius have no remarks upon the reters. Drelincourt in the Male Ape aith, reteres uprà Poas Muculo & Iliaco, atque ubtùs vais Spermaticis, quibus decua • im ubtrati unt etiam quibus vacula admittunt, ee reflectunt in Hypogatricam, decuantes ramos Iliacos & Ejaculatorios. And in the Female, reteris expaniones arcuatìm reflexae ut in homine. Vaa habent upernè à Renalibus, infernè à Muculis.

The Bladder of rine in our Pygmie was of an Oblong figure, not o globous as commonly in Man, for being moderately blown up it meaured four Inches in length; and two Inches and half in breadth. In other Circumtances 'twas agreeable enough with an Humane Bladder.

The Pariians tell us, that in the Female Monkey, the Neck of the Bladder had it's hole otherwie than in Women, being very far in the Neck of the Matrix, viz. towards the middle, at the place where it's roughnes began, which were een only towards the Extremity of the Ductus, near the internal Orifice. Blaius aith nothing of it in his Ape; and all that Drelincourt tells us is, Veica Peritonaeo upena ut in aliis Brutis.

Before we proceed to the Parts of Generation (which remain beides to be here decribed) we hall a little take notice of thoe large Canales of the Blood, the Arteria Aorta and the Vena Cava, and the Rivulets they emit or do receive; all which I find in our Pygmie to be jut the ame, as they are in a Man. For from the Aorta aries here, the Arteria Caeliaca; the Arteria Meenterica uperior; then the Emulgent Arteries; below them, the Spermatick Arteries; then the Arteria Meenterica inferior; then the
Trunk divides into the Iliac Branches. So the Vena Cava too in our Pygmie exactly imitated that in a Man.

How the Structure of thee Veels are in Monkeys, the Pariians do not tell us, and their figure is very imperfect; as is likewie that in Blaius, which eems altogether fictitious. What he writes, is this; Arteria magna circa Renem dextrum uccumbit Venae Cavae, & ubi Iliacos Ramos contituit eandem upergreditur; contrà ac in Homine, Cane, aliique animalibus fieri reperimus, ubi initra occupat, hinc à initra ad dextram progreditur upra Arteriam. So Drelincourt tells us in the Male Ape, Aorta decendens mox atque bifurcatur equitat, & adcendenti Cavae incumbit.

We come now to the Parts of Generation; and hall begin with the Vaa Praeparantia; The Arteries and Veins. The Spermatic Arteries in our Pygmie do both arie out of the Trunk of the Aorta, a little below the Emulgent Arteries, as in our figure; and after having ran a little way, they meet with the Spermatic Vein; and are both included in a common Capula, and o do decend to the Tetes. Thee Arteries do carry the blood to the Tetes, from whence the Semen is afterwards eparated; the reidue of the Blood is return'd from the Tetes by the Spermatic Veins; whereof that on the right ide enters into the Trunk of the Vena Cava, a little below the right Emulgent Vein; and that of the left, is emptied into the left Emulgent Vein, jut all one as it is in a Humane Body. Having injected the Spermatic Vein with Mercury, it dicovered abundance of Veels, running waving; which otherwie did not appear: and a great many of them were extreamly fine and mall.

The Pariians give no decription of the Spermatic Veels in their Monkeys; and in their figure the left Spermatic Vein is omitted, or left out. Thomas Bartholine Thom. Bartholin. Acta Medica & Philo. Hanien. an. 1691. & 1672. Ob. 36. in his Anatomy of a Mamomet (which he decribes, as not having a Tail; and therefore it mut be of the Ape-kind, and not a Cercopithecus, or a Monkey, as he calls it) in his figure of thee parts, repreents the left Spermatic Vein, emptying it elf into the left Emulgent, as it is in our Creature. Blaius therefore in the account of the Ape he diected, mut be mitaken; both in his figure and decription too; for in the former, he repreents the left Spermatic Vein running into the Trunk of the Cava; and jutifies it in the latter; in telling us, Vaa Spermatica utroque latere ex Trunco Cavae & Aortae oriuntur, & quidem altiori loco ea quae unt lateris dextri, inferiore quae initri. But Drelincourt certainly is more in the right, who informs us, that in the Male Ape he diected, Vena Spermatica dextra craa, & ab interiori trunco Cavae adcendentis pollice infra Emulgentem initram enacitur, urculoque emittit initros in Membranas vicinas. Arteria Spermatica dextra à trunco anteriori
Aortae paulò infra Emulgentem initram enacens ub Venâ Emulgente intercruciat Cavam acendentem, quae uperinequitat, & conjungitur Venae Conociali eò praecisè loci ubi Vena ineritur uum in truncum. Sinitra Vena Spermatica ineriturin Emulgentem juxta truncum Cavae, & conocialem Arteriam admittit eò praecisè loci, in quo enacitur dextra. So in the Female Ape he aith, Spermatica Vena initra ab Emulgente initrâ, dextra è Trunci parte anteriore, pollice infra Emulgentem initram.

We come now to decribe the Tetes, which in our Pygmie were not contained in a pendulous Scrotum, as they are in Man, but more contracted and pured up by the outward Skin, nearer to the Os Pubis, and were eated by the ides of the Penis, without the Os Pubis; and I oberved them bunching out there, before the Diection; o that it eemed to want a Scrotum; or at leat the Skin which incloed them, was not o dilated, as to hang down like a Cod; but contracted them up nearer to the Body of the Penis which to me eems a wie Contrivance of Nature. For hereby thee Parts are les expoed to the injuries, they might otherwie receive in climbing Trees, or other accidents in the Woods. However, the outward Skin here that incloes them, performs altogether the office of a Scrotum. And if I mitake not, I oberved that Sepimentum, as in a Humane Scrotum; which is made by a decent of a Membrane there, which divides each Teticle from one another.

But whether the Tetes being thus cloely pured up to the Body, might contribute to that great alaciounes this Species of Animals are noted for, I will not determine: Tho' 'tis aid, that thee Animals, that have their Teticles contained within the Body, are more inclined to it, than others. That the whole Ape-kind is extreamly given to Venery, appears by ininite Stories related of them. And not only o, but different from other Brutes, they covet not only their own Species, but to an Exces are inclined and ollicitous to thoe of a different, and are mot amorous of fair Women. Beides what I have already mentioned, Gabriel Clauderus Micell. Curioa German. Decur. 2. Ann. 5. Ob. 187. tells us of an Ape, which grew o amorous of one of the Maids of Honour, who was a celebrated Beauty, that no Chains, nor Coninement, nor Beating, could keep him within Bounds; o that the Lady was forced to petition to have him banihed the Court. But that Story of Catanenda in his Annals of Portugal (if true) is very remarkable; of a Woman who had two Children by an Ape. I hall give it in Latin, as 'tis related by Licetus; and 'tis quoted too by Anton. Deuingius Ant. Deuingij Faicul. Diertat. elect. de Ratione & Loquela Brutorum, p.m. 196. and others.

In hanc Sententiam faciunt (aith Fort. Licetus Fortun. Licetus de Montrorum Cauis, lib. 2. cap. 68. p.m. 217.) quae Catanenda retulit in Annalibus. Luitaniae de filiis ex muliere, ac imio natis, mulierem
nempe ob quoddam crimen in inulam deertam navi deportatam, quum ibi expoita fuiet, eam imiorum, quibus fertilis locus er at, agmen circumtetie fremebundum; upervenie unum grandiorem, cui reliqui loco ceerint: hunc mulierem blandè manu captam in antrum ingens abduxie, eique cum ipum tum ceteros copiam pomorum, nucum, radicumque variarum appouie; & nutu ut veceretur invitâe; tandem à fer â coactam ad tuprum; facinus hoc multis diebus continuatum adeò, ut duos ex ferâ liberos pepererit: ita mieram (quantò mors optabilior !) vict itâe per annos aliquot; donec Deus miertus navim eò Luitanam detuliet; quumque milites in terram aquatum ex proximo ad antrum fonte excendient: abeetque fortè fortuna imius; feminam ad invios diu mortales accurrie, & occidentem ad pedes upplicâe, uti e facinore, & calamitoiima ervitute irent ereptum, adentientibuque, & caum mierantibus illis, eam cum ipis navim adcendie. Sed ecce tibi imium upervenientem inconditis getibus, & fremitibus conjugem non conjugem revocantem: ut vidit vela ventis data, concito curu de liberis unum matri otentat, minatur, ni redeat, in mare praecipitaturum; nec egniter fecit, quod minatus: tum recurrit ad antrum, & eâdem velocitate ad littus rediens otentat alterum, minatur, & demergit: ubequitur, donec undae natantem vicere. Rem totam Luitania tete notiimam, & à Rege mulierem Ulytipone addictam ignibus, quorundam precibus vita impetrata, lethum cum clautro perpetuo commutâe.

But to return to our Buines. Our Pygmie in this Particular of the Scrotum, more reembles the Ape-kind, than a Man. For the Pariians tell us, that the Parts of Generation in three of our Subjects, which were Males, were different from thoe of Man, there being no Scrotum in two of thee Subjects, and the Teticles not appearing, by reaon that they were hid in the fold of the Groyne. It is true that the third, which was one of the Sapajous, had a Scrotum, but it was o hrunk, that it did not appear. Or, as they afterwards expres it, The Teticles were hut up in a Scrotum, which joyned them cloe up to the Penis. So in the Ape Blaius decribes, Tetes inignes atis, acculo uo inclui, non dependent extra abdomen, ad modum eum quo in Homine, Canibus, imilibuque Animalibus aliis, ed vicini adeò unt tendinibus muculorum Abdominis, quos vaa Spermatica traneunt, ac i iis uniti eent, ic ut potiùs in Inguine utroque collocatos eos dicerem, quàm ultra oa Pubis a Corpore pendulos, And o Drelincourt to the ame purpoe; Scrotum pendulum nullum est, est Teticuli utrinque juxta Ois Pubis umma latera, vel Spinam ummam ejus decumbunt extra prorus Abdominis cavum, & proindè extra Muculorum Epigatrij Aponeuroes.

In the other Parts I am here to decribe, I find our Pygmie more conformable to the Structure of the ame in a Man. For the Tetes were included in a Tunica Vaginalis, and had a Cremater Mucle: which being eparated, I oberved the Epididymis large, and the Body of the Tetis to be about the bignes of a Filbird; and it's compounding Parts nothing at all different from thoe of a Man. Jacobus Sylvins
Jac, Sylvij Variorum Corporum diect. Operum, p. m. 130. in the Ape he diffected, oberved, the Tetes humanis majores.

The Pariians tell us, that in ome of their Subjects the Teticles were long and trait, and but one line in breadth, and eight in length. In one of their Sapajous they were found of a figure quite contrary, and almost as remote from the figure of thoe of Man, being perfectly round. Drelincourt's account in his Ape is, Tunica Elytroides fibris carneis à Cremater conpera, ut in homine. Arteria Spermatica miro luu, piratim revolvitur uper Teticuli dorum. Teticulus autem Ventri Epididymidum adhaeret, nii fibrillis paucis & laxis, capite uo, quo Spermatica Deferentia admittit, eparatur illaeus, cauda autem ua, qua ejaculatoria vaa emittit, tot punctula candicantia exhibet, divulus ab Epididymide, quot à Teticulo canaliculi protenduntur.

From the Epididymis in our Pygmie (as it is in a Man) was continued the Vas Deferens; a lender Ductus, which conveys the Semen from the Teticle to the Veiculae Seminales. Thee Veiculae were two cellulated Bladders placed under the neck of the Bladder of rine; which on the outide, did eem (as it were) nothing ele but the Vas Deferens dilated, and placed in a waving figure there. And as the Body of the Tetes was made up of a curious convoluted Contexture of Seminal Veels, which running into fewer, form at lat the Body of the Epididymis; and thee Veels afterwards paing all into one Duct, do make up the Vas Deferens: o this Vas Deferens here, being dilated and enlarged, does form the Veiculae Seminales. And the ame is in a Man.

The Pariians here do take notice of that Paage in Aritotle I have already quoted, where he likens the Parts of Generation in the Male Ape to thoe of a Dog, more than a Man. But the Philoopher herein, is under a Mitake; for, as they intance, in the Penis of a Dog, there is a Bone, which is not in the Monkey's; o likewie in Monkeys, there are Veiculae Seminales, which are not to be met with in a Dog. They decribe them in their Monkeys thus: The Glandulous Protatoe were mall; the Paratatae Cyroides were in requital very large; they contained an Inch in length; their breadth was unequal, being four lines towards the neck of the Bladder, and a line and an half at the other end, differing herein from thoe of Man, who has them lenderest near the neck of the Bladder. They were compoed of everal little Baggs, which opened into one another. The Caruncle of the Urethra was mall, but very like to that of a Man. Blaius hath given us a figure of thee Parts, which I do not like as neither that of the Pariians. He decribes them thus: Veiculae Seminales hic valdè amplae, quae immio flatu per ductum Seminalem Ejaculatorium inignitèr intumecunt, Quod i premantur, manifetiimeè obervamus Materiam
iis contentam moveri in Meatum rinarium, Veicae continuum, & quidem per foramen ingulare, quod in unoquoque latere unicum est, quae res occaionem videtur dedie Jacobo Sylvio duos ductûs Seminales in imiâ contituendi. All that Drelincourt aith of them is, Vaa ejaculatoria retrò Veicam tendunt in Corpucula proedura mirè anfractuoa, ut & ipum initium Epididymidis. Which is very conformable to what I oberved in our Pygmie.

Between the root of the Penis, and neck of the Bladder, is eated the Corpus Glanduloum, or the Prostatae, which in our Pygmie appeared the ame as in Man. The Pariians tell us in their Monkeys that they were mall. Blaius in his figure, beides the Protates, which he aith are Glandula veicis adtans, albidior olidiorque repreents another, at the Letters (H. H.) viz. Glandula alia, major, rubicunda & plexu Nervorum, aliorumque vaorum praedita; which is no Gland, but the Bulb of the Penis. Drelincourt in his Ape tells us, Corpora Glanduloa duos velut Nates circa veicae cervicem uprà Sphincterem exhibent.

We come now to the Penis, which in our Pygmie was two Inches long; the girth of it at the root was an Inch and a quarter; but it grew taperer towards the end. It had no fraenum, o that the Praepuce could be retracted wholly down; and herein our Pygmie is different from a Man. The Slit of the Penis here was perpendicular as in a Man. In the figure the Pariians give us, it eems to be horizontal, as it is plainly repreented by Bartholine in his third and fourth figure of his Mamomet, altho by his econd figure one would think otherwie. Whether there was any Balanus or Glans in the Penis of our Pygmie, or what it was, I am uncertain: I do not remember I oberved any. In my third figure the Penis is repreented decurtated at the end, and without the Praeputium, which was left entire to the Skin. Dreclincourt's account of it in the Ape is this; Genitale prorsùs expers est fraenuli ac proinde Praeputium devolvitur ad radicem uque Penis, & denudatur Glans ipa, atque Penis integer. Balanus conimilis virili, excepto fraenulo, atque praeterea hiatum maximum exhibet, quâ parte Ligamenta Cavernoa deinant, & Glans utrinque prominet. At the root of the Penis of our Pygmie, we oberved the Muculi Erectores to be hort, and thicker proportionably than in a Man and the Ligamentum Supenorium larger: The Muculus accelerator rinae was large, covering the Bulb of the Cavernous body of the rethra. The Corpora Nervoa, or the two Cavernous bodies of the Penis were divided length-ways by a Sepimentum in the middle, as in Man. In the rethra likewie there was a Cavernous body. The Veels of the Penis anwered exactly to thoe of a Man.

Blaius in his Ape faith, Penis Nervoum Corpus unicum tantum habere videtur, epimento notabili detitutum. But I am apt to think he might be mitaken; for in our Subject 'twas very plainly divided, but more remarkably
towards the root than forwards. What he adds afterwards, Circa radicem Penis Tuberculum exile occurrit, exteriùs carnoae naturae, interiùs reticulari vaorum plexu refertum, intertitia ipius materiâ rubicundâ occupante, by this I uppoe he means the Bulb of the Penis. Drelincourt exprees it better, where he aith, Totus Penis duobus Ligamentis Cavernois à tuberibus Ichij gaudet. In our Subject thee two bodies were very large and cavernous within. But what Drelincourt adds, rethra, planè carnoa; This was different in our Pygmie; for as I have mention'd, the ides of the rethra, here were Cavernous too, tho' not much.

How the Organs of Generation are in the Female of this Species of Animals, I have had no opportunity of informing my elf. But by Analogy I can't but think, they mut be very like to thoe of a Woman, ince they are o even in Monkeys and Apes in everal repect; tho' in ome, they imitate the Structure of thee Parts in Brutes. Thus the Pariians oberve, The generative Parts of the Female had alo a great many things which rendered them different from thoe of Bitches, herein reembling thoe of Women; there were ome of them likewie which were as in Bitches, and after another manner than in Woman; for the exteriour Orifice was round and trait, as in Bitches, and the generality of other Brutes, and had neither Nymphae nor Carunculae. The Neck of the Bladder had it's hole otherwie than in Woman, being very far in the Neck of the Matrix, viz. towards the middle, at the place where it's roughnes began, which were een only towards the extremity of the Ductus near the Internal Orifice. The Trunks of the Matrix were alo different from thoe of Women, and reembling thoe of Brutes in that they were proportionably longer, and more redoubled by various turnings. The Clitoris had omething more conformable to that which is een in other Brutes that have it, than in that of Women, being proportionably greater, and more viible than it is in Women. It was compoed of two Nervous and Spongious Ligaments, which proceeding from the lower part of the Os Pubis, and obliquely advancing to the ides of thee Bones, did unite to form a third Body, which was ten lines in length. It was formed by uniting of the two first, which a very trong Membrane joyned together, going from one of the Ligaments to the other, beides a hard and nervous Membrane which inveloped them. They terminated at a Gland like to that of the Penis of the Male. The little Mucles, which were fatned to thee Ligaments, proceeded as uual from the tuberoities of the Ichium. Thee Ligaments were of Subtance o thin and pongious, that the wind penetrated, and made them eaily to well, when blown into the Network, of the Veins and Arteries which is in this place. This Network was viible in this Subject, being compoed of larger Veels than they proportionably are in Women. It was ituated as uually under the econd pair of Mucles of the Clitoris. It's figure was Pyramidal, ending from a very large Bais in a point, which run along the third Ligament to it's extremity towards the Gland.

The rest of the Parts of Generation were like to thoe of Women. The Neck of the Bladder had it's Mucles as in Women: For there were a great number of flehy Fibres, which proceeding from the Sphincter of the Anus, were fatened to the ides of the Neck of the Uterus, and other uch like Fibres which did come from the Sphincter of the Bladder to inert them elves at the ame place. The Body of the Uterus, it's Membranes, internal Orifice, it's Ligaments as well the round as broad, and all it's Veels had a conformation intirely like to that, which thee ame Parts have in Women. The Teticles, which were ten lines long, and two broad, were as in Women, compoed of a great number of mall Bladders, and fatned near the Membranes which are at the extremity of the Tubae, and which is called their Fringe.

Drelincourt hath very little on this Subject, all he aith is, rethra rubicunda olida & brevis. Vagina admodum rugoa, monticulum habens in medio, Papillis extuberans ut in Palato, Pollicem longa, tranverim cia, Pollicem lata. Orificium interiùs valdè olidum. Cervix interior admodùm dura, & paulò intrà oculum internum duritie cartilaginoâ.

We hall proceed now to the Parts of the Middle Venter, the Thorax; and here, as the Parts are fewer, o my Remarks will be alo: and the rather, becaue in our Pygmie we oberved o very little difference from the Structure of the ame Parts in a Man. I mut confes I can't be o particular in all Circumtances, as I would, becaue for the preerving the Sceleton more entire, I did not take off the Sternum. However, I oberved enough to atisfie my elf with what I thought mot material.

This Cavity was divided from the Abdomen by the Diaphragm, whoe Aponeurois or Tendon eemed rather larger than in a Man: and the econd Mucle which encompaed the Gula, as it paes through it, was very fair.

I made no Remarks upon the Pleura, and Mediatinum: The Thymus in our Pygmie was about an Inch long, and placed as 'tis in Man; downwards 'twas divided, but upwards 'twas joyned together. So in a Man I have often oberved it divided. Generally this part is larger in Infants and Embrios than in grown Perons, for the Reaons I have frequently mentioned in my Anatomical Lectures. The Pariians oberved in their Monkeys that the Thymus was large. Blaius and Drelincour •
have no Remarks about it.

The Lungs in our Pygmie had three Lobes on one ide, and but two on the other; five in all. Their Colour, Subtance, Situation, and all Circumtances exactly reemble a Man's. The Pariians tell us, that in their Monkeys the Lungs had even Lobes, three on the right ide, and as
many on the left, the eventh was in the Cavity of the Mediatine, as in the generality of Brutes. This again makes a notable difference between the internal parts of the Ape, and thoe of Man, whoe Lungs have generally at the most but five Lobes, oftener but four, and ometimes but two. Vealius affirms that he never aw in Man this fifth Lobe, which he reports to be in Apes, uppoing that they have but five. The Paage that the Pariians hint at in Vealius is this, Lobum autem qui in Canbus, imiique Venae Cavae Caudicem uffulcit, nunquam in homine obervavi, & hunc illo detitui certo certius cio, quamvis interim Galeni locus in eptimo de adminitrandis Diectionibus mihi memoria non exciderit, quo inquit, quintum hunc Pulmonis Lobum eos non latêre, qui recte ectionem adminitrant; innuens Herophilo & Marino ejumodi Lobum fuie incognitum, uti anè fuit, cùm illi Hominum Cadavera, non autem cum ipo, imiarum ac Canum duntaxat aggrederentur, in quibus praeenti Lobo nihil est manifetius.Andr. Vealij de Corporis humani fabrica, lib. 6. cap. 7. p. 724. Tho Galen be herein mitaken, Vealius certainly is too evere in his Cenure, in charging him, that he never diected any thing but Apes and Dogs; for the contrary evidently appears in abundance of Intances, that might be produced. And one would think he had not diected Apes and Monkeys in making but five Lobes in their Lungs, whereas in either there are more. In what he argues, that this fifth Lobe in a Man could not lie upon the Vena Cava; becaue in a Man the Pericardium is fatened to the Diaphragm, and the Vana Cava enters there, and o immediately paes to the Heart; this is true, and the ame I oberved in our Paymie. So that in the formation of this Part, our Pygmie exactly reembles a Man; and is different from both the Mankey and Ape-kind. The former we have een; as to the latter, Drelincourt tells us in the Male Ape; Pulmo dexter quadrifidus, Lobus inimus omnium craiimus, uperior minùs craus, intermedius reapsè medius ilu & magnitudine. Quarius demùm crenam inculptam habet, quâ parte Cavae fulcrum praebet. Pulmo initer biidus, & Lobus ejus uperior bifurcatus. So in the Female Ape, Lobi Pulmonis dextri totalitèr divii IV, quorum uperior, biidus totus, adeo ut int quinque in eâ parte: iuiter Pulmo biidus totus, & Lobus uperior ultrà dimidium ui divius.

The Trachaea or wind-pipe in our Pygmie was altogether the ame as in a Man; coniting of a regular order of Cartilaginous Annuali, which were not perfectly continued round; but towards the Spine, were joyned by a trong Membrane. Drelincourt aith of it, Trachaeae annuli e habent uti Intetinourm pirae, nervois Membranis colliguntur. The Comparion, I think, is not o well made.

For the preent we will leave following the Duct of the Trachaea up to the Larynx, (the Part according to the Method of Nature, we hould have began with) and make ome farther Obervations, on thoe under our preent view. In the Cavity of the Thorax therefore, (as I have remark'd) the Pericardium or that Bag that incloes the Heart in our Pygmie, was fatened to the Diaphragm, jut 'tis in Man. I mut confes, when I firt oberved it, I was urpried, becaue I had not een it o in Brutes before. And Vealius and others make it as a peculiarity to a Man. I will quote Vealius's words, and make an Inference from our obervation, and o proceed.

Vealius Andr. Vealij de Corporis Humani f • brica, lib. 6. cap. 8. p.m. 728. therefore tells us, Caeterum Involucri mucro, & dextri ipius lateris egregia portio Septi tranveri nerveo circulo validiimè, amploque admodùm patio connacitur, quod Hominibus est peculiare. Simiis quoque & Canibus & Porcis involucrum à epto mullùm ditat. Tantùm abest ut ipi magnâ ui portione connecteretur, adeò anè ut & hinc luce clarius contet, Galenum hominis vicera aut ocitantèr, aut neutiquàm pectâe, Simiaque & Canes nobis decribentem, immerito veteres arguie. He can't forbear at all turns to have a fling at Galen: But he is here in the right, and Galen mitaken. So Blancardus Stephn Blanca • ai Anatom. reformat.cap. 2. p. 8. tells us, Homo prae caeteris Animalibus hoc peculiare habet, quod ejus Pericardium Septi tranveri medio emper accrecat, cum idem in Quadrupedum genere liberum, & aliquanto patio ab ipo remotum it.

Now our Pygmie having the Pericardium thus fatened to the Diaphragm, it eems to me, as if Nature deigned it to be a Biped and to go erect. For therefore in a Man is the Pericardium thus fatened, that in Expiration it might ait the Diatole of the Diaphragm: for otherwie the Liver and Stomach being o weighty, they would draw it down too much towards the Abdomen; o that upon the relaxation of it's Fibres in it's Diatole, it would not acend ufficiently into the Thorax, o as to caue a Subidence of the Lungs by leening the Cavity there. In Quadrupeds there is no need of this adhaeion of the Pericardium to the Diaphragm: For in them, in Expiration, when the Fibres of the Diaphragm are relaxed, the weight of the Vicera of the Abdomen will eaily pres the Diaphragm up, into the Cavity of the Thorax, and o perform that Service. Beides, was the Pericardium fatened to the Diaphragm in Quadrupeds, it would hinder it's Sytole in Inpiration; or it's decent downwards upon the contraction of it's Mucular Fibres; and the more, becaue the Diaphragm being thus tied up, it could not then o freely force down the weight of the Vicera, which are always preing upon it, and conequently not ufficiently dilate the Cavity of the Thorax, and therefore mut hinder their Inpiration. Thus we ee how neceary it is,
that in a Man the Pericardium hould be fatened to the Diaphragm, and in Quadrupeds how inconvenient it would be; that from hence I think we may afely conclude, that Nature deign'd our Pygmie to go erect, ince in this particular 'tis o like a Man; which the common Apes and Monkeys are not; and tho' they are taught to go erect, yet 'tis no more than what Dogs may be taught to do.

We proceed now to the Heart; where we oberved that in our Pygmie, its Auricles, Ventricles, Valves and Veels were much the ame as they are in a Man's. It's Cone was not o pointed, as in ome Animals, but rather more obtue and blunt, even more than a Man's. What Avicenna Avicennae lib. 3. Fen. 2. Tract. 1.p.m. 670 remarks of the Heart of an Ape, having a double Cone, mut be accidental and extraordinary: for he tells us, Et jam repertum et Cor cujudam Simij habens duo Capita. And a little after, he denies the Heart to be a Mucle; Jam autem erravit (aith he) qai exitimavit, quòd it Lacertus, quamvis it imilium rerum in co, verùm motus ejus non est voluntarius. The peron he hints at, I uppoe, is Hippocrates, who o long ago aerted this; < in non-Latin alphabet > (aith Hipp. de Cora • , p.m. 270 Hippocrates) < in non-Latin alphabet > . Cor muculus est validus admodùm non Nervo, verùm Carnis piamento. And Steno and Dr. Lower ince have hewed us the way of diecting it, and have made it mot evident that 'tis Mucular; and it's motion is uch; but as Avicenne oberves,'tis not a voluntary motion, but involuntary. 'Tis pity we had not a better Tranlation of his Works; for unles it be ome particular Pieces, the ret is mot barbarouly done, as appears from that little I have quoted of him. But to return to our Pygmie; the magnitude and figure of the Heart here, was exactly the ame as repreented in our Scheme, where part of the Pericardium is left lying on it. Both in the right and left Auricle and Ventricle, I oberved two Polypous Concretions, which plainly repreented the Valves both in the Arteria Pulmonalis, and Aorta. I mut confes by what I have hitherto oberved of them, (and I have very frequently met with uch Concretions in Humane Bodies) I cannot think thee Polypus's to be any thing ele, than the Size of the Blood, or the Serum coagulated after Death. The Obervation I formerly gave Vide Tho. Barthelini Acta Med. & Philo. Hafnien. Vol. 5. Ob. 30. p. 94. of a Polypus in the Trachaea and Bronchiae of a Patient troubled with an Haemoptoe, in it's kind I think remarkable.

The Pariians Oberve that the Heart of their Monkey was a great deal more pointed, than it uually is in Man; which is likewie a Character of Brutes. Yet in the interiour Superficies of it's Ventricles, it had that great number of Fibres and flehy Columns, which are een in Men. Drelincourt in his Ape oberves, Cor olidum in ventriculo initro, laxum in dextro; praedurus Conus ejus: Serum in Pericardio alum. Vaa Coronaria tumida, Praeertim circà Ventriculum. Adeps circà ca nullus.

There was nothing farther, I think, that I oberved peculiar in the Thorax of our Pygmie. I hall now therefore follow the Duct of the Trachaea up to the Throat. And here as in Man, I oberved placed the Glandula Thyroidea, upon the Cartilago Scutiformis of the Larynx; 'twas red and pungy, full of Blood veels, not much unlike the inward Part of the Spleen, but omewhat firmer. In a Man I have always oberved this part to be red. Drelincourt's Account of it in the Ape is, Glandulae Thyroideae & Cricoideae craae unt, & ubnigricantes; & illas permeant urculi Corotidis Arteriae & Jugular is venae externae; cum urculis Nervi Recurrentis. There is no enible account yet given of the ue of this part, as I have met with: And I think that from a Comparative Survey of it in other Animals, and a trict Obervation of it's Structure, and the Veels that compound it, it were not difficult to aign other ues of it more atisfactory.

As to the Larynx in our Pygmie, unles I enumerate all the Cartilages that go to form it, and the Mucles that erve to give them their Motion, and the Veels that run to and from it, and the Membranes and Glands, there is nothing that I can further add, but only ay, that I found the whole Structure of this Part exactly as 'tis in Man. And the ame too I mut ay of the Os Hyoides. The Reflection that the Pariians make upon the obervation of this, and it's neighbouring Parts in the Diection of their Monkey's, I think is very jut and valuable. And if there was any further advantage for the forming of Speech, I can't but think our Pygmie had it. But upon the bet Enquiry, I was never informed, that it attempted any thing that way. Tho' Birds have been taught to imitate Humane Voice, and to pronounce Words and Sentences, yet Quadrupeds never; neither has this Quadru-manous Species of Animals, that o nearly app • oaches the Structure of Mankind, abating the Romances of Antiquity concerning them.

The Pariians therefore tell us, That the Mucles of the Os Hyoides. Tongue, Larynx, and Pharynx, which do mot erve to articulate a word, were wholly like to thoe of Man; and a great deal more than thoe of the Hand; which nevertheles the Ape, which peaks not, ues almot with as much perfection as a Man. Which demontrates, that Speech is an Action. more peculiar to Man, and which more ditinguihes him from Brutes than the Hand; which Anaxagoras, Aritotle, and Galen have thought to be the Organ which Nature has given to Man, as to the wiest of all Animals; for want perhaps of this Reflection: For the Ape is found provided by Nature of all thoe marvellous Organs of Speech with o much exactnes, that the very three mall Mucles, which do take their rie from the Apophyes Styloides, are not wanting, altho' this Apophyis be extreamly mall. This particularity does likewie hew, that there is no reaon to think, that Agents do perform uch and uch actions, becaue they are found with Organs proper thereunto;
for, according to thee Philoophers, Apes hould peak, eeing that they have the Intruments neceary for Speech.

I hall not engage in this Argument here, becaue it would be too great a digreion; hereafter, it may be, I may take an occaion to do it; for this is not the only Intance in our Subject, that will jutifie uch an Inference: tho' I think it o trong an one, as the Atheits can never anwer.

We hall take notice next of the vula, a Part of ome ue too in forming the Voice; for where 'tis miing or vitiated, it much alters the ound; and even this I found in our Pygmie to be altogether alike as in Man. It had thoe two Mucles which are in a Man, the Muculus Sphaeno-Palatinus, and the Pterigo-Palatinus eu Sphaeno-Pterigo-Palatinus; the Tendon of which lat, paed over the Pterigoidal Proces, which was to it like a Trochlea or Pully, and was afterwards inerted as in a Man.

The Pariians tell us that the Uvula, which is in no other Brutes, was found in our Apes (it hould be Monkeys) wholly reembling that of Man. And o Blaius, vula in Animalibus aliis praeter hominem & imiam numquam à me obervata. All that Drelincourt aith of it is, vnla firma est & carnoa.

The Tongue of our Pygmie in all repectts, as I know of, reembled a Humane Tongue; only becaue 'twas omewhat narrower, it eemed longer: And under the Tongue in our Pygmie we oberved the Glandulae Sublinguales as in Man.
Drelincourt oberves in the Ape, Linguae bais non tantùm incumbit Hyoidi uperno, ed amplectitur ejus tuber inferius poticè: Papillas habet Bovinis imiles, & tunicam propriam permeantes.

At the Root of the Tongue of each ide were placed the Tonillae in our Pygmie, as they are in a Man. They were protuberant and hard, and not o foraminulous, as uually in Man; very probably being vitiated by the lcer in the Cheek. For Drelincourt tells us in the Ape, Amygdalae cavae, pertuae & Scrobiculos habentes.

The Parotides under each Ear in our Pygmie were large, and of the ame Figure as in Man. Parotis glandula contegit Muculum Sterno-Matoideum, articulationem Maxillae & Muculi Pectroalis portionem, aith Drelincourt.

The Maxillary Gland of the left ide (where the Ulcer in our Pygmie was) had two of it's Lobes, globous and protuberant, above the Surface of the other Part, being inected and tumefied by the Ulcerous Matter. Thee Glands were about an Inch long, and about half an Inch broad;
and there were two other mall Glands a little ditant from the head of the Maxillary. Glandulae alivales ad angulum Maxillae Inferioris oblongae, laxae, molles, albicantes, aith Drelincourt.

But before I leave thee Parts, there are ome others I mut here take notice of, in this Comparative Survey; which tho' they are not to be met with, either in our Pygmie or in Man; yet are very remarkable, both in the Monkey and Ape-kind, viz. thoe Pouches the Monkeys and Apes have in their Chaps, which erve them as Repoitories for to hoard up, upon occaion, food in; when they are not dipoed for the preent to devour it; but when there Stomachs erve them, they then take it out thence and o eat it. That the Ape-kind has thee Pouches, Drelincourt does inform us; where he tells us, Muculus latiimus Mentum univerum & buccas obtegit, quâ parts imiae accum formant, intra quem Eculenta recondunt. Pliny is very expres, That both Satyrs and Sphinges (which I make to be of the Monkey kind) have them likewie, Plinij Hit. Nat. lib. x. cap. 72 p.m. 466. Condit in Theauros Maxillarum Cibum Sphingiorum & Satyrorurn Genus. Mox inde enim ad mandendum manibus expromit; & quod formicis in annum olenne est, his in dies vel horas. The account the Pariians give us of this Pouch in the Mouth of the Monkeys they diected, is this; That it was compoed of Membranes and Glands, and of a great many Muculous and Car nous Fibres. It's ituation was on the outide of each Jaw, reaching obliquely from the middle of the Jaw to the under part of it's Angle, paing under a part of the Mucle called Longiimus. It was an Inch and an half long, and almost as broad towards it's bottom. It opened into the Mouth between the Jaw and the bottom of the Gum. 'Tis into this Pouch that Apes ue to put what they would keep; and it is probable that the Muculous Fibres which it has, do erve to hut and open it, to receive and put out what thee Animals do there lay up in reerve. Now our Pygmie having none of thee Pouches in it's Chaps, nor nothing like them; 'tis a notable difference both from the Monkey and Ape-kind, and an Agreement with the Humane.

We hould now come to dicoure of the five Senes: But there is little I have at preent to remark of them. For in the Organs of thoe of Tactus, and Gutus, there was no difference I could oberve between our Pygmie and a Man. As to thoe of Hearing and Smelling, I hall make my Obervations upon them, in the Otcology. Here therefore I hall only remark ome things of the Eyes, the Organs of Seeing; and o proceed to the Brain.

The Bony Orbit of the Eye in our Pygmie was large, conical, and deep. Here we oberved the Glandula Lachrymalls, and Innominate. The Bulb of the Eye in proportion to the Bulk of the Body, was rather larger than in a Man. The Iris was of a light hazel Colour: The Pupil
round and large: The Crytalline Humour Sphaerical or Lentiformis, and almot as large as in a Man. The Optic Nerve was inerted exactly as in a Man. The Tunica Choroides rather blacker than in a Man. And whereas in Brutes, that are prono Capite, there is uually a Muculus Septimus, which from it's ue is call'd Supenorius; in our Pygmie there was none of this Mucle. All the other Mucles of the Eye, were exactly the ame as in Man. This eventh Mucle is alo wanting in the Ape, as appears by the figures Caerius Jul. Caeri • Pla • ni • ni Pentaethe • e • on, h. e. de quinque enib • s, Vide de Organ • vi • us. Tab. 3. fig. 12, 13. has given us of the Eye of an Ape. Neither the Pariians nor Blaius, nor Drelincourt do give us any Remarks upon this Part.

We proceed now to the upper Venter, the Head, where at preent we hall examine the Brain; that Part, which if we had proceeded according to the Method of Nature in forming the Parts, we mut have began with. For I can't but think, as 'tis the firt Part we oberve formed, o that the whole of the Body, i. e. all the Containing Parts, have their rie from it. But I hall not enlarge upon this Argument here; it would be too great a digreion, to give my Reaons for uch an Hypotheis. From what is generally received, viz. That the Brain is reputed the more immediate Seat of the Soul it elf; one would be apt to think, that ince there is o great a diparity between the Soul of a Man, and a Brute, the Organ likewie in which 'tis placed hould be very different too. Yet by comparing the Brain of our Pygmie with that of a Man; and, with the greatet exactnes, oberving each Part in both; it was very urpriing to me to find o great a reemblance of the one to the other, that nothing could be more. So that when I am decribing the Brain of our Pygmie, you may jutly upect I am decribing that of a Man, or may think that I might very well omit it wholly, by referring you to the accounts already given of the Anatomy of an Humane Brain, for that will indifferently erve for our Pygmie, by allowing only for the magnitude of the Parts in Man. Tho' at the ame time I mut oberve, that proportionably to the Bulk of the Body, the Brain in our Pygmie, was extreamly large; for it weighed (the greatet part of the Dura Mater being taken off) twelve Ounces, wanting only a Dram. The Pariians remark, that in their Monkeys the Brain was large in proportion to the Body, it weighing •• o Ounces and a half: which nevertheles was inconiderable to ours; ince our Pygmie exceeded not the Stature and Bulk of the Common Monkey or Ape; o that herein, as in a great many other Circumtances, our Pygmie is different from the Common Monkey and Ape, and more reembles a Man.

I can't agree with Vealius, that the Structure of the Brain of all Quadrupeds, my all Birds, and of ome Fihes too, is the ame as in Man.
There is a vat difference to be oberved in the formation of the Parts, that erve to compoe the Brain in thee various Animals. And tho' the Brain of a Man, in repect of his Body, be much larger than what is to be met with in any other Animal (for Vealius makes the Brain of a Man to be as big as thoe of three Oxen) yet I think we can't afely conclude with him, that Animals, as they excell in the largenes of the Brain, o they do likewie in the Principal Faculties of the Soul: For if this be true, then our Pygmie mut equal a Man, or come very near him, ince his Brain in proportion to his Body, was as large as a Man's. Vealius And. Vealij de C • rp • ris H • man • s fa •• ca, lib.
• . cap.
• . p. 773. 774. his words are thee; Cerebri nimirùm contructione Simia, Canis, Equus, Felis, & Quadrupeda quae hactenùs vidi omnia, & Aves etiam univerae, plurimaque Picium genera, omni propemodùm ex parte Homini correpondeant: neque ullum ecanti occurr at dicrimen, quod ecùs de Hominis, quàm illorum Animalium functionibus tatuendum ee prae cribat. Nii fortè quis meritò dicat Cerebri molem Homini, Perfectiimo anè quod novimus Animali, obtigie maximam, ejuque Cerebrum etiam tribus Boum Cerelris grandius reperiri: & dein ecundum Corporis proportionem mox Simiae dein Cani magnum quoque non ecus obtingere Cerebrum, quam i Animalia Cerebri tantum praetarent mole, quanto Principis Animae viribus apertius viciniúve donata videntur.
