Since therefore in all repects the Brain of our Pygmie does o exactly reemble a Man's, I might here make the ame Reflection the Pariians did upon the Organs of Speech, That there is no reaon to think, that Agents do perform uch and uch Actions, becaue they are found with Organs proper thereunto: for then our Pygmie might be really a Man. The Organs in Animal Bodies are only a regular Compages of Pipes and Veels, for the Fluids to pas through, and are paive. What actuates them, are the Humours and Fluids: and Animal Life conits in their due and regular motion in this Organical Body. But thoe Nobler Faculties in the Mind of Man, mut certainly have a higher Principle; and Matter organized could never produce them; for why ele, where the Organ is the ame, hould not the Actions be the ame too? and if all depended on the Organ, not only our Pygmie, but other Brutes likewie, would be too near akin to us. This Difference I cannot but remark, that the Ancients were fond of making Brutes to be Men: on the contrary now, mot unphiloophically, the Humour is, to make Men but meer Brutes and Matter. Whereas in truth Man is part a Brute, part an Angel; and is that Link in the Creation, that joyns them both together.

This Digreim may be the more pardonable, becaue I have o little to ay here, beides jut naming the Parts; and to tell you (what I have already) that they were all like to thoe in a Man: For the Dura Mater, as a Common Membrane, firmiy ecured the ituation of the whole Brain trictly
adhering to the Sutures of the Cranium above; before to the Crita Galli; and at the bais o trongly, that it was not eaily to be eparated. By it's anterior Proces of the Falx, it divided the two Hemipheres of the Cerebrum; by it's tranvere Proces, which decended deep, jut as in a Man, it eparated the Cerebrum and Cerebellum: it enjoyed the ame Sinus's, and in all Particulars 'twas conformable to what is in a Man.

The Pia Mater in our Pygmie was a fine thin Membrane which more immediately covered the Subtance of the Brain, and may be reckoned it's proper Membrane; ininuating it's elf all along between the Anfractus of the Cerebrum and the Circilli of the Cerebellum; being copiouly furnihed with numerous Branches of Blood Veels, but they appear'd more on the Convex Part, then at the Bais.

The figure of the whole Brain in our Pygmie was globous; but by means of a greater jutting in of the Bones of the Orbit of the Eye, there was occaioned a deeper depreion on the Anterior Lobes of the Brain in this place, than in a Man. As to other Circumtances here, I oberved all Parts the ame. The Anfractus of the Cerebrum were alike; as alo the Subtantia Corticalis and Medullaris. On the bais of the Brain, we may view all the Ten pair of Nerves exactly ituated and placed as in a Humane Brain; nor did I find their Originations different, or any Particularity that was o. I hall therefore refer to the figures I have caued to be made of the Brain, and their Decriptions; where we may oberve the Arteriae Carotides, Vertebrales, and Communicans, and the whole of the Blood Veels in our Pygmie to be the ame as in a Man. Here was the Infundibulum, the Glandulae duae albae ponè Infundibulum, the Medulla Oblongata with it's Annular Protuberance, and the beginning of the Medulla, Spinalis, jut as in Man. I am here only a Nomenclator, for want of Matter to make particular Remarks upon. And the Authorrs that have hitherto furnihed me with Notes, how the ame Parts are in Apes and Monkeys, do fail me now; it may be, finding here nothing new or different, they are therefore ilent. All the Pariians do tell us of the Brain in their Monkeys is this:

The Brain was large in proportion to the Body: It weighed two Ounces and an half. The Dura Mater entered very far to form the Falx. The Anractuoities of the External part of the Brain were very like thoe of Man in the Anteriour part; but in the inward parts before the Cerebellum, there was hardly any: they in requital were much deeper in proportion. The Apophyes, which are called Mamillares, which are great Nerves that do erve to the melling, were not oft, as in Man, but hard and membranous. The Optick Nerves were alo of a Subtance harder and firmer than ordinary. The Glandula Pinealis was of a Conical figure, and it's point was turned towards the binder part of the Head. There was no Rete Mirabile: for the Carotides being entered into the Brain, went by one ingle Trunk on each ide
of the edge of the eat of the Sphenoides to pierce the Dura Mater, and to be ditributed into the bais of the Brain. In our Subject I thought the Anfractus of the Brain much the ame, both in the anteriour and hinder part. Nor did I oberve any difference in the Mamillary Procees or Optick Nerves, or Rete Mirabile, but all, as in a Man.

The Cerebellum in our Pygmie was divided by Circilli, as in Man. It had likewie the Proceus Vermiformes, Dr. Willis Willis Cerebri Anat. cap. 3. p. 22. makes this Remark upon this Part: Cerebellum autem ipum, in quibuvis ferè Animalibus, ejudem figurae & proportionis, nec non ex ejumodi lamellis conflatum reperitur. Quae Cerebrum diverimodè ab homine configuratum habent, uti Volucres & Pices, item inter Quadrupedes Cuniculi & Mures, quorum Cerebra gyris eu convolutionibus carent; his Cerebelli pecies eadem, imilis plicarum dipoitio & Partium caeterarum compoiturae exitunt. 'Tis from hence he forms his noted Hypotheis, How that the Animal Spirits that are bred in the Cerebrum, do erve for Voluntary Motions; and thoe in the Cerebellum for involuntary.

If we urvey the inward Parts of the Brain in our Pygmie, we hall here likewie find all exactly as in a Humane Body; viz. The Medullary Subtance running up between the Cortical; The Concameration, the Corpus Calloum, the Fornix and it's Crura the ame. The Ventricles large and patious. The Corpora Striata, the Thalami Nervorum Opticorum all alike. The Plexus Choroides the ame; as were alo the three Foramina as in Man; The Glandula Pinealis proportionably large. The Protuberantiae Orbiculares; i.e. The Nates and Tetes in our Pygmie were the ame as in Man; whereas in Brutes (as Dr. Willis well oberves) the Nates are always proportionably larger than in Man; but it was not o in our Pygmie. The Valvula major here was very plain. The Cerebellum being divided, the Medullary Parts repreented the Branches of Trees, as a Man's does. The Medulla Oblongata and Medulla Spinalis the ame as the Humane; and all Parts being o conformable here to a Humane Brain, I thought it ufficient jut to name them, ince I have caued to be made two figures of the Brain in our Pygmie from the Life, and in its Natural Bignes, where all the Parts are plainly repreented to the Eye.

div.head: THE OSTEOLOGY, OR DESCRIPTION OF THE BONES.
div.p:
WE come now to the Oteology, to give a Decription of the Sceleton of our Pygmie, by comparing which, with that of a Man, an Ape and a Monkey we may oberve (as we have already of the other Parts) that here too, our Pygmie more reembles a Man than Apes and Monkey's do; but where it differs, there 'tis like the Ape-kind. Galen (as I have already quoted him, vid. p. 15.) tells us that an Ape of all Creatures is the most like to a Man in the Vicera, Mucles, Arteries, Veins and Nerves, becaue 'tis o in the Structure of the Bones. But it may be quetioned, Whether even the Structure of the Bones themelves, does not depend upon that of the Mucles: ince in their firt Formation, they are oft and vacular; then Cartilaginous, and in time at lat are hardened into Bones. In Ricketty Children too, we find, that even the Bones are rendered crooked, by the Contraction of the Mucles, how much more, when they are tender and oft, might they be bended any way by them. But by undertanding exactly the Structure of the Bones, we hall the better apprehend the Rie and Inertions of the Mucles. And for the better attaining this, Galen in the ame Chaper Galen. de Anat. adminitr. lib. 1. cap. 3. p. m. 29, 30 recommends to his Students, when they cannot have an opportunity of Conulting an Humane Sceleton, then to
make ue of thoe of Apes; not that he thinks them both alike, but the mot like: and tells them, that it was worth their while on this account to go to Alexandria, where the Phyicians taught their Scholars the Doctrine of the Bones from the Inpection of Humane Sceletons themelves, which he much prefers before Books. But ince in his time Humane Sceletons were not to be had but at Alexandria, for the upplying this Defect, they might oberve the Bones of Apes; and after that, they might read his Book De Oium Naturâ, and to do as he did, viit the Sepulchres and Graves, and to oberve there the Humane Bones themelves: And he tells us of two Sceletons he made ue of; One that the River had wahed out of a Tomb, where the Fleh was corrupted and wahed away, yet the Bones held together. The other was of a Thief that was Executed, who was o much hated, that none would bury him; but the Birds pick'd off his Fleh, and left his Bones as a Sceleton. But aith he, < in non-Latin alphabet > , &c. i.e. If yon can't happen to ee any of thee, diect an Ape, carefully view each Bone, &c. Then he advies what ort of Apes to make choice of, as mot reembling a Man: And concludes, < in non-Latin alphabet > , i. e. One ought to know the Structure of all the Bones either in a Humane Body, or in an Ape's; 'tis bet in both; and then to go to the Anatomy of the Mucles.

What Galen advied, no doubt he practied himelf, and oberved both. But Andreas Vealius will not allow him this: For in his great and excellent Book De Corporis Humani Fabricâ, he all along tell's us, that Galen gives us rather the Anatomy of Apes than of a Man: And in his Epitola ad Joachimum Roelants de Radice Chynae, his chief Deign is to prove, that Galen never diected a Humane Body: and that he is often mitaken in the Hitory of the Parts, as alo in their Ues; and that his Reaonings are frequently unconcluive.

Upon the coming out of Vealius his firt Book, he was warmly oppoed by Jacobus Sylvius a Phyician at Paris, who had formerly been Vealius his Mater in Anatomy; in a Treatie tiled Depulio Veani cujudane Calumniarum in Hippocratis & Galeni Rem Anatomicam. This was anwered not long after by Renatus Henerus, who publihed another Treatie, viz. Adverus Jacobi Sylvij Depulionum Anatomicarum Calumnias pro Andreâ Vealio Apologia. Sylvius afterwards procures a Diciple of his to write againt Vealius, who puts out, but unuccesfully, Apologia pro Galeno contra Andream Vealium Bruxellenem, Francico Puteo Medico Vercelleni Authore. A Scholar of Vealius, Gabriel Cunaeus, makes a Reply to Puteus in his Apologiae Francici Putei pro Galeno in Anatome examen. Upon Vealius his leaving Rome, a Diciple of his, Realdus Columbus, grew very famous for Anatomy, but ungrateful to his Mater, as Vealius
complains in his Book De Radice Chynae, and his Examen Obervationum Falloppij. But Gabriel Falloppius was always kinder to him, and mentions him with the greatet Honour, and calls him Divine; tho' in everal things he dients from him, which occaioned Vealius his putting out his Obervationum Falloppij Examen.

The Deign of Bartholomaeus Eutachius in writing that Dicoure of his, Oium Examen, is to jutifie Galen, that he did not only diect Apes, but Humane Bodies likewie; and that his Decriptions are conformable to the Parts in Man, and not to Apes and Monkeys. He therefore draws a Comparion between the Sceleton of an Ape and a Man; and hews wherein they differ; and how far Galen's Decriptions of thoe Parts are different from thoe in an Ape. Volcherus Coiter has likewie made the ame Comparative Survey, in his Analogia Oium Humanorum, Simiae & verae & caudatae, quae Cynocephali imilis est, atque Vulpis. In mot things I find Coiter to follow Eutachius, but Eutachius I think is to be preferred, becaue in his Annotationes de Oibus, he quotes the Texts of Galen at large. Johannes Riolanus the Son hath wrote upon the ame Argument likewie; viz. Simiae Oteologia five Oium Simiae & Hominis Comparatio; and he being later than either of the former, and having made ue of all before him, he may be thought to be the mot exact.

In giving therefore an Account of the Oteology of our Pygmie, and the better to compare it's Sceleton with that of a Man, and an Ape, and a Monkey, I thought I could not do better, than to inert this Dicoure of Riolanus; and by Commenting upon it, to hew wherein our Pygmie agrees
or differs. This I thought the mot compendious way, and what other Obervations I have, that conveniently I can't inert in my Comment, I hall add at the cloe of this Dicoure. And tho' I may be cenured by ome for dicouring o largely upon an Ape, yet this Apology I have to make, That 'tis an Argument that has exercied the Pens of the greatet Anatomits we have had; and ours being one of a higher degree than the Common ort, and in o many Particulars nearer approaching the Structure of Man, than any of the Apekind, and it being o rare and uncommon, it may the more excue me, if I endeavour to be as particular as I can. But in ome meaure to avoid this Fault, I hall omit Riolan's firt Chapter, which is but Praefatory, and begin with the econd.

div.head: CAP. II.
De Capitis & Faciei Oibus.
div.p: SImiae Caput (a) rotundum est, humano imile, cynocephali verò caput oblongius. triuque (b) Suturae adeo unt obcurae, ut earum nullum appareat vetigium. Propterea potiùs harmoniae dici merentur, quam uturae, quia rerum conutarum figuram non aemulantur. Attamen Volcherus Coiter uturas attribuit imiis, parum ab humanis dicrepantes. In cercopitheco quammiformes deiderantur. (c) Frontis Os in calvariae bais ede, ad conjunctionem Ois phenoidis, tranver â potius lineâ quàm utura ditinguitur: ampla oblongaque ciura homines divium obtinent, in quam aliud Os intar cribri perforatum conjicitur, arctiimeque contringitur. At (d) Simiae Os Frontale ea in parte omnino continuum exitit, & quâ naus principium umit, non longè ab ea ede, quae frontem contituit, alto & rotundo foramine parumper à lateribus compreo, illo foramine quod nervum viorium emittit, nonnihil ampliori, excavatum est. In ejus humiliori profundiorique ede, quatuor aut quinque alia foramina recta & lata cernuntur. In imia caudat a (e) Os Ethmoides admodum profundè in nares decendit, paulò infra eam regionem ex qua naus exoritur. Harmoniâ per medium dividitur, & utrimque ab Oe frontis, quod etiam profundèr decendit effingi videtur. (f) Superficies fellae Sphenoidis ad narium principium in Oe frontis non est plana & aequalis ut in homine, ed est eminentiima. In poteriori ellae eminentia glandulam excipiente, reperitur for a men exculptum. In ellae (g) hujus ubtantia nulla latet cavitas ut homine. (h) Cavitates illae quae in apophyibus pterygoideis exculptae unt, maximae & profundae apparent, (i) Oa, Bregmatis, & Temporum, nec intus, nec foris, ullam demontrant diviionem, quai ex unico continuatoque Oe contarent. (k) In Oe temporum apophyis Matoidis deet, Styloidis exigua et. (l) Cavitas auris videtur unica, orbiculatim in plures gyros triata, nec tria Oicula Malleolus, Incus, & Stapes reperiuntur, quibus aliorum animantium aures intructae unt, i credimus Caerio, ed ego emper obervavi.
Os Zygma (m), quâ parte ab Oe orbitario procedit, craum & robutum est, atque ejus in medium lineâ potiùs quàm uturâ ditinguitur. In homine veròtenue exitit, & uturâ dirimitur.

Simiae Facies (n) rotunda est, cynocephali oblonga & antrorum protuberans. Oa verò Maxillae uperioris repondent humanis. (o) Suturae unt harmoniis, ive rimis imiles, potiimum ea quae medium palatum interecat. Sed pecutliaris utura notatur, ab inferiore orbita incipiens, ecundum longitudinem maxillae ad caninum dentem cujuque lateris prorepit, ipumque palatum dirimit.

Maxilla inferior (p) integra est, nullâ lineâ in mento diecta, breviima est corporis proportione, ita ut ex omni animantium genere nullum breviorem habeat, excepto homine. Extremitas quae cavitati temporum articulatur, et condyldis, ut in homine. Quare non est gynglymoides haec articulatio, ut cripit Volcherus Coiter.

(q) Simia in dentibus caninis & molaribus differt ab homine. Caninos quidem habet dentes humanis imiles, in unaquaque maxilla binos, qui utrimque aident & accumbunt incioribus. Singulas radices ut inciores habent, ed altiùs infixas robutioreque, minùs etiam ex anteriore parte, quàm poteriore preas & angutas. Ac imia cynocephalos dentes caninos longiores prominentioreque, qiàm vera imia obtinet. Molarium dentium numerus in homine incertus et, authore Galeno: aepius enim in utraque maxilla unt exdecim, interdum viginti, nonnunquam viginti quatuor. At imiae emper certus ac definitus molarium numerus. Differunt quoque Maxillares imiae ab humanis, in figura externa, & radicum numero, quamvis enim priores duo molares imiae, ab humanis, aut nihil, aut certè parum dicrepent, quia in imia primus inferior unum tantùm apicem obtinet: Attamen in poteriorum dentium menis, ecundum longitudinem maxillarum, profunda admodum linea exculpta et. Quant lineam altera etiam tranvera, quae in quinto dente imiae non caudatae gemina et, intrinecus & extrinecus ad gingivam uque protractata interecat. Quo fit, ut inguli ejumodi dentes eminentias, ut plurimum quatuor in angulis (nam quinto ix unt) tres verò foveas in medio habentes, duarum errarum mutuò ibi occurrentium modo committantur: quod profectò accuratiius Author Galenus explicare minimè praetermiiet, i molares imiarum decripiet.

Os Hyoides (r) humano firmè imillimum exitit, praeterquam quod medium ipius oiculum amplius est, quàm in homine, & poteriore ede inigniorem otendit cavitatem, gibbis ipius laryngis partibus invehitur, fitque propugnaculum cartilaginis cutiformis. In illa enim lata oblongaque apophyi, interiores partes Ois hyoidis efformat, quae deorum adeo producitur, ut intar clypei cartilagini thyroidi obtendatur.

(a) The Cranium of our Pygmie was round and globous, and it eemed to be three times as big as the Head of a Common Monkey; for, that I might the better compare them, I procured the Sceleton of a Monkey, which I found was exactly the length or that of our Pygmie: though at the ame time we hall ee, that in everal of the Parts, 'twas vatly different. For meauring the Head of our Pygmie by a Line drawn round from the Noe, over the Orbit of the Eyes, to the Occiput or hinder part of the Head, and o to the Noe again, I oberved 'twas Thirteen Inches. The Cranium of the Monkey meaured there only Nine Inches and a quarter. The girth of the Head of the Pygmie, from the Vertix round by the Ears to the Vertix again, was Eleven Inches and an half: in the Monkey 'twas only Seven Inches and an half. The longitudinal Diameter of the Cranium of the Pygmie was Four Inches, of the Monkey Two Inches and a quarter. The latitudinal Diameter of the Cranium of the Pygmie was Three Inches and above a quarter; of the Monkey a little above Two Inches. The profundity of the Cranium of the Pygmie, from the Vertix to the Foramen where the Medulla Spinalis paes out, was about Three Inches and a quarter; in the Monkey Two Inches. So that in the largenes of the Cranium, the Pygmie much exceeds the Monkey, as alo Apes, and more reembles a Man.

(b) The Sutures in our Pygmie perfectly reembled thoe in an Humane Cranium; The Sutura Coronalis Sagittalis, and Lambdoides being all errated or indented very curiouly, as in Man. In the Lambdoidal Suture I oberved Nine Oa triquetra Wormiana. In the Cranium of a Monkey I found the Coronary Suture for the mot part to be Harmonia, and only for a little pace to be errated towards the middle, where it meets the Sagittal Suture. The Sagittal Suture here was indented throughout. The Lambdoidal Suture, as extended from the Sagittal of each ide for about half an Inch, was errated; then the Suture diappeared, and there was formed here a riing ridge of the Cranium, which was continued to that Apophyis which makes the hinder part of the Os Zygomaticum. There was no uch bony ridge in the Cranium of the Pygmie. In the Monkey too I aw the Squammous Sutures very plain, tho' Riolan denies them; which likewie in our Pygmie was very apparent. Our Pygmie therefore in the Structure of the Sutures exactly reembled a Humane Cranium, and more than Apes and Monkeys do: For in them the Coronary and Lambdoidal Sutures were only in part errated; and they had no Oa triquetra Wormiana.

(c) In our Pygmie there was an Os Cribriforme, as in Man; 'twas about half an Inch long, and a quarter of an Inch broad; in it I numbred about Thirty Foramina; here was likewie that long ridge, (which is call'd Crita Galli) as in a Man, to which the Dura Mater was fatened.

(d) In the Cranium of the Monkey there was no Crita Galli; and where the Os Cribriforme hould have been, there was a hollow Paage which led towards the beginning of the Notrils, at the end of which there might be a mall Os Cribriforme perforated with four or five holes. But this Part appeared very different from the Structure of a Humane Skull, as likewie from our Pygmie; which was occaioned chiefly by the great bunching in of the Bones of the Orbit of the Eye, tho' our Pygmie too had thee Bones more protruded in, than they are in a Humane Cranium.
(e) This appeared more in the Cranium of a Monkey than in our Pygmie; tho' here too 'twas omewhat more than in a Man's Skull.

(f) The Sella Equina in our Pygmie was exactly like a Man's. In a Monkey I oberved it more riing and higher. In the middle of the Sella Turcica eu Equina of our Pygmie, I oberved a Foramen; and the ame I found in a Humane Cranium I have by me.

(g) In our Pygmie I did not oberve thoe two Cavities under the Sella Turcica which are to be met with in a Humane Skull. But the Bone here was very pungy and cavernous, and might anwer the ame end, tho' not formed perfectly alike.

(h) Thee Cavities in our Pygmie, were nothing o large as they are in a Monkey, but conformable to the Structure of this Part in an Humane Skull. And in our Pygmie too, I oberved the Pterigoidal Procees as they are in Man, but I did not find them in the Monkey.
(i) The Oa Bragmatis and Temporum in our Pygmie were very plainly ditinguihed by an indented Suture. In the Cranium of the Monkey thee Bones were divided by a lineal Suture call'd Harmonia.
(k) The Matoid and Styloforme Proces in our Pygmie were very little, yet more than in the Monkey; but herein our Pygmie rather imitates the Ape-kind.

(l) Becaue I would not poil the Sceleton, I did not examin the Organ of the Inward Ear: But am wholly inclined to Riolan, who tells us he always found thoe Three little Bones, the Malleolus, Incus, and Stapes there; and no doubt but they are to be met with in our Pygmie. Tho' Caerius therefore thinks Galen does not mention them, and never oberved them, becaue they are not to be found in Apes: But Riolan tells us the contrary.
(m) The Os Zygomaticum in our Pygmie was not half o big or large as in the Cranium of the Monkey; herein therefore our Pygmie more reembles a Man.

(n) Tho' the Face of our Pygmie was rounder than an Ape's, as that is than a Monkey, and a Monkey's more than the Cynocephalus, yet 'twas not altogether o much as a Man's; the upper Jaw being proportionably longer and omewhat more protuberant. The Bones of the Noe too in our Pygmie more reembled the Ape-kind, than the Humane, being flat and imous; hence imia; and not protuberant and riing as in Man.

(o) The Suture of the Palate in our Pygmie was jut the ame as in a Man. In a Monkey I oberved that peculiar Suture Riolan mentions, but did not find it in the Pygmie: Only in the Palate of the Pygmie I oberved a Suture, not from the Dens Caninus, as was in the Monkey, but from the Second of the Dentes Inciores.

(p) In our Pygmie the under Jaw was perfectly cloed at the Mentum, as 'twas in the Monkey; and 'tis o in a Man. Galen Galen de Anat. Admini •• .lib. 4. cap. 3. p. 94. tells us, < in non-Latin alphabet > . i. e. That of all Animals a Man hath the hortest Chin, or under Jaw, in proportion to his Body; then next to a Man, an Ape, then a Lynx, then Satyrs, and after thee the Cynocephali. And I may add, of all Apes, our Pygmie hath the hortet. The Articulation of the under Jaw in our Pygmie was Condyloides, as 'tis in Man; and not Gynglymoides, as Volcherus Coiter and Barthol. Eutachius oberve.

(q) Our Pygmie had in each Jaw before, four Dentes Inciorcs; then following them, of each ide a Dens Caninus; then after them of each ide, Four Dentes Molares, in all Fourteen Teeth in each Jaw, in both Twenty eight. But our Subject being young, I oberved that all the Teeth were not perfectly grown out of the Jaw-bone, and could perceive ome of the Molares, that till lay hid there, or were not much exerted. In a Monkey in each Jaw there were two Dentes Inciores before; then four Dentes Canini, two of each ide; then eight Dentes Molares, four of each ide. The Number of the Teeth in each Jaw, and in the whole the ame as in the Pygmie: only the Monkey had four Dentes Canini in each Jaw, the Pygmie had but two, as in a Man: Or at leat in the Monkey, the two firt of the Canini eemed to be Amphibious, between an Incior and Caninus; being not o broad as the two firt Inciores, nor o much exerted or extended as the two other Canini were. In the number of the Teeth our Pygmie imitated more the Ape-kind than the Humane: But in the Structure of them, more the Humane than the Ape-kind; for the Mena or Supericies of the Melares, was not o errated as the Monkey's, but liker Humane Teeth.

I have omitted the Printing the next Paragraph in Ri • lan, becaue I
would not be tedious: And for the ame reaon, do not here particularly decribe each Bone in the Head and Jaws of our Pygmie; for where I do not remark otherwie, 'tis to be undertood, that all thoe Parts are the ame in a Man, our Pygmie and the Ape-kind.
(r) There was nothing particular that I oberved in the Os Hyoides of our Pygmie that was different from that of a Man's.

div.head: CAP. III.
De Spina & Oibus & Adnexis.
div.p: SIMIAE (a) Cervix brevis est, eptem vertebris extructa, corpora vertebrarum anteriori parte non unt rotunda ut homini, ed plana. Poticae apophyes pinoae non unt longae, & bifidae, ed breves, implices, & acutae. In prima (b) vertebra, nullum pinae vetigium apparet, imò nulla entitur aperitas, in anteriore parte corporis primae vertebrae humanae obtua quaedam eminentia apparet, quae in imia magis extuberat, & in mucronem producitur. Quod i vertebras & pinas breves habet imia, (c) apophyes tranveras obtinuit longiores, atque ad anteriora magis, quàm in homine reftexas. Imprimis verò exta colli vertebra, quae hunc proceum prae caeteris inignem adepta et, eumque bifidum, magique recurvum & aduncum, quàm in aliis vertebris. Hic autem pondylus extus maximus est, propter illas tranveras apophyes grandiores, in imia caudata minor est. Septimi pondyli tranverae apophyes implices & tenues, in caudata imia bifidae, & atis longae exitunt, quae licet in homine implices appareant, exto tamen craitie non

(d) Prima imiae vertebra ad finem proceus tranveri acendentis utrimque foramen habet, ad nervum tranmittendum, quo humana caret vertebra, eptima colli vertebra in homine aepius est perforata: nde evenit, quod tranveri proceus hujus vertebrae non unt imiles apophyibus tranveris colli, ed potiùs thoracis apophyibus tranveris aimilantur. (e) Vertebrarum dori corpora parum ab humanis differunt, neque apophyes multùm diimiles unt, exceptis rectis ultimarum duarum vertebrarum, quae rectiores unt in imiis, paulùm deorum inclinat in hominibus. In (f) potremis vertebris dori reperiuntur quatuor infernae apophyes articuli gratiâ contructae. In humanis vertebris duae tantùm notantur, quas etiam in lumborum vertebris obervabis. (g) In imia decima dori vertebra, infra uprave ucipitur, at in homine est duodecima.

(h) Lumbi, inquit Galenus, in imiis unt longiores quàm in hominibus, i pro ratione reliquarum partium hoc aetimare velis, nam in homine quinque vertebrae lumbos eformant, in imiis non ecus, quàm in aliis quadrupedibus ex adunt. (i) Harum vertebrarum proceus ab humanis differunt. Siquidem tranveri in homine teretes unt & oblongi, nonnihil in exteriora converi, cotularum vicem gerentes. In imia unt ampli, intrò pectantes, & intar quammae tenues: figurâ caudam hirundinis referunt, aut cornu retortum, quod oblongo acutoque mucrone erigitur, ac urum vergit. Ac tertia lumbi vertebra primò incepit tranverum conequi proceum, qui brevis est. Reliqui ubequentes longiores exitunt. (k) Poteriores proceus pinoi non unt recti, ed upernè pectant, atque excipiuntur à upernis incumbentibus vertebris, quae hiatu ive ciura triangulari inter duos tranverales proceus exitente, dum in poteriora imia pinam inflectit, eodem tranverales excipiunt.

(l) Obervandum venit in homine circa radices infernas tranverarum apophyewn lumbarium, atque etiam duarum infirmarum thoracis, quaedam tubercula magnitudine figuraque mepilorum nucleos referentia aepius reperiri, quae cum in canibus & imiis non habeantur, upicari poet aliquis vicem illarum quas paulò antè decripi proceritatum in homine tenere.
(m) Os Sacrum pinae fundamentum in homine, ex tribus vertebris conflatur: In imiis ex duabus tantum componitur, quibus ilium Oa copulantur.

(n) Simiae longior est Coccyx, quàm homini, pluribus ideo contructus Oibus, quae juxta commiuram Ois Sacri perforata unt, medullamque continent, atque nervos antrorum & retrorum emittunt, quae omnia deunt in coccyge hominis: cur autem imia vero coccyge caruerit, rationem reddit Fallopius, in Obervat. Anatomicis.
(o) Homo, inquit Galenus, ex omnibus animalibus Cotas curviimas habet, propterea latiimum pectius obtinuit. Simiae latius caeteris pectus datum, ed humano angutius.

(p) Porro imia, tam caudata, quàm non caudata, cotas viginti ex prae e fert, cum in homine tantùm viginti quatuor reperiantur. Harum utrimque unt octo verae cotae, in homine eptem, quae per articulum terno committuntur. Quinque vero nothae cotae non deinunt in perfectam cartilaginem verus ternum invicem contrictae, ut in homine, ed oeae magis quàm cartilaginoae, à e mutuò disjunguutur. Cotae in imia, tam caudata, quàm non caudata, patiis vertebrarum intermediis ineruntur: at in hominibus magis corporibus vertebrarum attexuntur.

(q) Sternum octo contat Oibus rotundis, quorum primum aliquantiper preminet, upra cartilaginum duarum primarum conjunctionem, quae duae cartilagines videntur amplexari upericre parle primum os terni. Cartilagines
•• tarum commiuris Oium terni accrecunt, duae ultimae concurrunt imul in articulationem ultimi & penultimi ois terni. ltimum os terni xiphoidem • artilaginem referens, impensè longum est, & teres.

(r) Simia quoad capulas & claviculas homini maxime imilis est, authore Oaleno. Clavicula incipiens à primo terni oe ad medium cotae rectà procedit, inde ad acromion uque multùm curvata intumecit: huic articulationi interjectum est oiculum, quod in homine ad decimum octavum annum & ultrà, appendix exitit: at in imia, nec itud oiculum, nec illius vetigium ullum apparet, imò pars illa robutiima est.

(a) In our Pygmie there were even Vertebrae of the Neck, as there are in a Man, and an Ape too; but they were hort, making in length about two Inches; and eemed more to imitate thoe in Apes, being flatter before, and not o round as in Man. And their Spines, tho' they were longer, and more obtue, and not o acute as in Monkeys; yet they were not biide, as they are in Man.

(b) In the firt Vertebra of the Neck in the Pygmie there was no Spine, but an Aperity; in a Man there is a mall Spine. And before, 'twas like to the Humane, having an Obtue Eminence, and not running to a Mucro, as in the Ape and Monkey. The Dens of the econd Vertebra in the Pygmie was partly Cartilaginous.

(c) I did not oberve in the Pygmie the Tranvere Apophyes to be longer, nor to be reflected more forward, nor the ixth Vertebra to be larger than the others; nor the eventh Vertebra, to be any thing different from the ame in Man; but in all thee Circumtances, our Pygmie eemed to imitate the Structure of the ame Parts in Man, more than does the Ape-kind.
(d) Thoe Foramina oberved in the Vertebrae of the Neck of Apes, were wanting in our Pygmie, who herein imitated the Humane Sceleton.
(e) I did not oberve any difference between the Vertebrae of the Back of our Pygmie and thoe of a Man's; nor what Riolan remarks of the Apophyes rectae of the two lat Vertebrae.
(f) In the lower Vertebrae of the Back of the Pygmie, I oberved but two Apophyes infernae, as 'tis in a Humane Sceleton: in a Monkey there are four Apophyes there.
(g) Our Pygmie if Riolan's account be true, is different both from the Ape and Man too; for here 'twas the thirteenth Vertebra, quae infra, uprave ucipitur.

(h) The Vertebrae of the Loins in our Pygmie were about two Inches long; and their number the ame, as in Man, viz. five; and not ix, as are in Apes and Monkeys: But the Os Ilium of each ide does acend o high, as to include the two lower Vertebrae; which is not o in Man.
(i) The Tranvere Procees of the Lumbal Vertebrae in the Pygmie, were round and thick, as in Man; and not thin and lat, or broad, as in the Monkey.
(k) The Spines of the Lumbal Vertebrae in the Pygmie, were trait, as in a Man; and not bending upwards, as in the Ape and Monkey kind.

(l) I am apt to think thee Tubercula are in our Pygmie; but our Subject being young, and everal of the Parts not yet hardened into Bones but Cartilaginous; I was not fully atisfied herein, and do leave it as a Quaere.

(m) Riolan in this account is mitaken, nor is he here conitent with himelf, as to what he writes of this part in other places. Job. Philip. Ingraias Comment. in Galen. de Oibus, Cap. x. Text.
• . pag. m. 18 •
who has wrote a mot learned and incomparable Comment upon Galen's Book de Oibus, tells us; Amplum Sacrumve Os in Homine ex vel ad minus quinque ex Oibus contat. Galenus tamen, Simiarum Canumve Sceletos diecans, interdum quatuor ex Oibus componi inquit. Sub Oe inquam Sacro largiùs umpto, Coccygem quoque comprehendens: (quem Coccygem pro uno Oe, ut in praeenti textu facit, tanquam quartum adjungens aumpit, à Sacro interim ditinguens) aepius autem tribus duntaxat propriè umptum Os Sacrum à Coccyge ditinctum expreit, uti nunc etiam facit: unde tribus ex partibus contructum ee ait, tanquam ex propriis Vertebris. So Falloppius and others do make the Os Sacrum in a Man to conit of ix Bones, ometimes five. In our Pygmie the Os Sacrum was compoed of five Bones: But in the Sceleton of a Monkey I oberved but: three Bones or Vertebrae which did make up the Os Sacrum.

But as our Pygmie in the number of the Vertebrae which compoes the Os Sacrum, did imitate the Humane kind; o in other repects 'twas much liker to the Sceleton of Apes and Monkeys: For the Os Sacrum here, was nothing o dilated and pread, as 'tis in Man; but contracted and narrow as 'tis in Apes; and very remarkably different from the Humane Sceleton; as 'twas likewie in the Spines and Procees which more reembled the Ape-kind.

(n) The Os Coccygis in our Pygmie conited of four Bones, as 'tis in an Humane Sceleton, and thee not perforated. In the Ape, and epecially in the
Monkey, there are more Bones, and thoe perforated, as Riolan decribes them. Hence Julius Pollux tiles it, < in non-Latin alphabet > , Perforatus Coccyx. This Os Coccygis makes a little bunching out of the Skin in the Pygmie, as I have repreented it in my econd figure, and is remark'd before (vide pag. 14.) but in Man, 'tis not protuberant. What Riolan oberves out of the Nubian Geography, of a Nation in the Ile of Namaneg, having Tails, I think is fabulous; unles they be Monkeys, or of that kind: I am certain that Story of the Kentih Longtails he mentions, is utterly fale, tho' he modetly exprees himelf, fabuloum puto. His words are thee: In Inula Namaneg Maris Orientalis, Gens est caudata, ex Geographiâ Arabicâ Nubieni pag. 70. fabuloum puto quod de Anglis Caudatis referunt Hitorici, quibus ob injuriam D. Thomac Cantuarieni illatam, Deus Coccygem intar Caudae produxit Riolan. Encheirid. Anat. lib. 6.cap. 16. p. 451..
(o) In our Pygmie the Ribs were altogether as much curved, as in an Humane Sceleton; and it was as full cheted as a Man.

(p) In the number of the Ribs our Pygmie imitated the Ape-kind: for it had thirteen of a ide, ix and twenty in all: In a Man there is but twenty four, tho' ometimes there has been oberved thirteen of a ide. As to the other Particulars that Riolan mentions, viz. the number of the Cotae verae, and the oious Extreams of the Nothae, and the Articulation of the Ribs, herein our Pygmie more reembled a Man: for it had but even Cotae verae that were articulated to the Sternum; and the Extreams of the Nothae were Cartilaginous, not Oious, and continued to the Sternum as in an Humane Sceleton; and the Articulation of the Ribs was more on the Body of the Vertebrae, than in the Intertices. Drelincourt is mitaken in mentioning but twelve Ribs in the Ape, of a ide, or his was different.

(q) Jo. Philippus Ingraias Jo. Phil. Ingraias Comment. in Galen, d • Oibus, Cap. 12. Text. 1. pag. m. 190. makes eight Bones in the Sternum of Infauts; and tells us, that in time thee Bones do coalece, and grow ewer. Galen makes even Bones in the Sternum, according to the number of the Cotae verae that inert their Cartilages into them. But the eighth Bone Ingraias aith, is for the Cartilago Eniformis. In the Sternum of our Pygmie I numbred even Bones, the two lat being mall and partly Cartilaginous; and here the Cartilages were inerted at the Commiures and Joynings of the Bones of the Sternum. The Cartilago Eniformis was long and roundih. The whole of the Sternum of our Pygmie much more reembled the Humane Sceleton, than the Monkey's, being much broader and larger, and as far as I oberved jut alike.

(r) The Scapula of our Pygmie, tho' in mot repects it reembled a Man's, yet I thought it did not o much, as a Monkey's; for it eemed
narrower, and the Bais was proportionably longer. But this I uppoe might happen in preparing the Sceleton by paring away the Cartilages (for the Creature was young) which in a longer time would have hardened into a Bone. So likewie that Proces which receives the Clavicula call'd Acromion, was Cartilaginous, as was likewie the End of the Proceus Coracoides, and of the Cervix it elf, which lat received the head of the Shoulder Bone. So that as yet there was not a Sinus formed here for the receiving it; but that Extream was flatter than uually and plain; nor was there that Sinus under the Spine, as in an adult Humane Scapula.

I oberved no difference in the Figure and Structure of the Clavicula in our Pygmie and in a Man. Nor did I oberve that Bone Riolan mentions, but a large Cartilage which did conjoyn that Extream of the Clavicula to the Acromium, which in time might become long; this Cartilage was about a quarter of an Inch long.

div.head: CAP. IV.
De Artubus Superioribus.
div.p: (a) SIMIAE & Hominis Omoplatae omnino imiles unt.

(b) Humerus imiae non admodum ab humano differt, in caudata diimilis est juxta inferius caput, quod cubito articulatur. Hac enim regione re •• ectitur ab exterior parte introrum, atque in illa flexura canaliculum acquirit ex oppoito latere pervium.
(c) Cubiti Oa duo in utraque imia humanis repondent.

(d) Carpus imiae non valde differt ab humano, obtinuit tamen nonum os, de quo ic loquitur Eutachius: Hoc oiculum non in prima brachialis acie est locatum, ed tertio ejudem aciei oi incumbit, atque inter ea quae indicem & medium digitum utinent eipum inerit: vocatur à Galeno
< in non-Latin alphabet > , hoc oe videntur carere imiae caudatae, ed ejus loco adipieuntur os peculiare, quod carpi oi cubito ubtrato annectitur, & atis longe protuberat. Deinde intar cornicis verus manus volam incurvatur, atque cum proceu ois carpi radio articulati, magnam cavitatem muculorum tendinibus efformat.

(e) Metacarpij, Digitorumque Oa imiae, tam caudatae quàm non caudatae, parum admodum ab humanis oibus di • repant. Simia quidem magnum manus digitum Pollicem, mutilum obtinet, & curtum, & indici propinquum, non oppoitum, intar alt • rius manus, ut in homine: Reliqui digiti muliò unt minores digitis pedum.

(a) I have already mentioned that the Scapula or Omoplato in our Pygmie did not eem o like a Man's, as a Monkey's did; nor does it appear o in my figure; not but that I think 'tis o, when adult; and it's Cartilages are hardened into a Bone: but my figure only repreents what was now formed into a Bone, and without the Cartilages, which in time would have become bony.

(b) The Os Humeri in our Pygmie was a little above five Inches long, jut the ame length with the Thigh Bone, and not altogether o thick. That end which was joined to the Bones of the Cubit, was about an Inch and a half broad. I oberved here, upon the flexure of the Cubit forwards, that in the Os Humeri there was a deep inus, and the Bone o thin here, that it would admit the Rays of Light thorough; but 'twas not pervious as Ri • la •
aith it is in a Monkey; nor did I oberve it o, in the Sceleton of a Monkey.
(c) In the Pygmie the Bones of the Cubit were exactly like a Man's. The lva was five Inches long; the Radius five Inches and an half. They had large Cartilages at both Extreams.

(d) So likewie the Bones of the Carpus in the Pygmie reembled thoe of a Man. I did not oberve here that ninth Bone decribed by Eutachius. For indeed in our Subject, there were but four in each Carpus, that were oified: the others were only Cartilaginous.

(e) In the Hand, our Pygmie reembled the Ape and Monkey-kind. For tho' the Bones of the Metacarp and Fingers were like to thoe of a Man; yet the Thumb was much maller, than the other Fingers, and horter, and liker the Ape-kind. This Galen frequently takes notice of. 'Tis true, the other Fingers were much larger in our Pygmie than in the Ape-kind, and more reembling thoe of a Man, o that I was urpried to ee them o big: but the Thumb, which the Ancients and Gallen call < in non-Latin alphabet > , and Hippocrales
< in non-Latin alphabet > , in our Subject was o diproportionate and little, that as Galen remarks Galen de uu Partium, lib. 1. cap. 22. p.m. 310., any one that hould view it, would think that it was but a ridiculous imitation of Man-kind, and nothing anwering to it's Names. And in the precedent Chapter he vigorouly diputes againt the Epicure • ns and the Followers of A • lepiades; and from the admirable Structure and wie Contrivance of all the Parts, and particularly the Tendons that go to the Fingers; he confutes their Hypotheis as vain, and hath this noble Fyiphenema,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet >
i. e. Vos, per Deos immortales, cùm nihil habeatis, quod in tot Inertionibus reprehendatis, neque Tendonum molem, neque locum, neque Inertionis modum, ed in his omnibus mirabilem quandam Proportionem videatis, unâ olâ in utroque magno digito imilitèr perditâ (& hoc non ine ratione, quod eâ non egebamus) temerè dicitis & abque Arte omnia hujumodi facta fuie.

The Bones of the Metacarpus in the Pygmie were an Inch and three quarters long. The two lat Joints of the Thumb were carce an Inch long; the firt Joint of the Thumb was a little above an Inch. The Fore-finger was two Inches and almot an half: The middle Finger, two Inches and three quarters. The third or Ring-finger was two Inches and half a quarter; and the little Finger was not full two Inches long. The firt Joint of the fore and middle Finger was above a quarter of an Inch broad, and the Girth of each about was an Inch. The Pygmie therefore in the Fingers, having them o large and thick, imitated a Man; but in the Thumb, which was o lender and mall, it reembled the Ape-kind.

div.head: CAP. V.
De Artubus Inferioribus.
div.p: OSSA (a) Ilium in utraque imia, tam caudata quà;m non caudata, toto habitu, & figura ditant ab humanis: dehicunt enim eo in loco, ubi pubis Oa ee debebant, atque omnino privantur Oe pubis: propterea ad velociter currendum ineptae unt. Ichij articulus planè diimilis est ab illo hominis, ut notavit Galenus.

(b) Ea est Femoris tructura in imia, ut eam tare rectam non permitt at, nec intar hominis corpus uum erigere, aut incedere, ne quidem edere, quia femoris caput obliquim in articulo coxae, committitur. (c) In homine cervix rotundi capitis femoris oblonga est, & enim obliquè deorum ducitur. In imia verò brevis, & propemodum tranvera viitur. Sed femoris cervice, apophyes duae, trochanteres dictae, in imia imiles unt humanis, verum in illa, ut in caudata minores.

(d) Patella utriuque imiae manifetum dicrimen ab humana demontrat: est enim oblonga, non rotunda, Quamvis autem extri • eus gibba it, atque intus cava, nihilominus longè aliter e habet quàm in homine. Nam ecundum
ipius longitudinem recurvatur, excavaturque adeo, ut nihil propemodum in medio emineat, curvo aduncoque ejus inu naviculam quandam elegantiimè referre videatur. In caudata imia patella videtur ex duobus Oibus mutuò adnatis contructa.
(e) Tibiae utrumque Os in utraque imia humanis Oibus imillimum est.

(f) Simiae Pes ab humano maximè dicrepat, est enim oblongus latuque homini, angutus brevique imiae, pro ratione corporis, pedique digiti longiores unt, ed metatari Oa breviora, calcaneum verò angustius, & anteriori in parte qua cum Oe, cyboide committitur, latius evadens, magique inibi longum, quàm retrò, impedit ne imia diu erecta, & tare, & ambulare queat. Atragalus Galeno tenuis non efficitur, ed manens ublimis, O • caphoidi conjungitur, quod imiae repugnat, in qua atragalus humilem, oblongam atque tenuem cervicem habet. Planta in imia ex quatuor Oibus componitur. Pollex ex tribus, inquit Eutachius. Quamvis Volcherus in caudata imia nuliam obervarit dierentiam, quâ dicreparent ab homine. (g) Digitorum notiima est dicrepantia in homine, ut notavit Galenus, omnes una erie diponuntur, breviimoque patio dicreti, multo minores unt, quàm qui in manu habentur. Nam quantò pes umma manu major est, tanto illius digiti manus digitis unt minores.

(h) Accedit quod pollex longitudine indici aequalis est, quem dupla craitudine uperat, talique est quatuor digitorum commenuratio, ut ab indice ad minimum emper deficiat longitudo: & ecundae aciei Oa, i indicem exceperis, breviora unt iis, quae in tertia phalange reponuntur. Haec omnia in • traque imia aliter e habent, omnes enim pedis digiti inigni patio dicreti unt, multoque longiores, quàm in manu exitunt: Pollex caeteris digitis brevior tenuiorque est, atque diveram ab aliis poitionem ortitur, dehicit etiam, ut pollex in manu valde ab indice. Digiti pedis imiae, manus humanae digitorum eriem imitantur, est enim pollex in pede imiae reliquis digits brevior, inter alios quatuor digitos ut in manu, medius omnium longiimus.

(a) There was no Part I think in the whole Sceleton where the Pygmie differed more from a Man, than in the Structure and Figure of the Os Ilium: for in a Humane Sceleton thoe Bones are pread broad, forming a Sinus or Hollow on the Inide. In the Pygmie they were proportionably longer and narrower, and not o Concave on the inide, but in all repects Conformable to the Shape of the ame Bones in the Ape and Monkey-kind. But why Riolan hould deny the Os Pubis to be in Monkeys, I ee no reaon; for naturally there is not that Dehicence or Separation of the Os Pubis, as Coiter has given in his Figure of the Sceleton of a Monkey, and as he decribes it; from whence I uppoe Riolan borrows this Decriprion: for in the Sceletons of two Monkeys I oberved thee Bones were joined together, and in the Pygmie they are cloed as in a Man. When the Cartilage that joins them is divided, they will part
aunder; but otherwie they are firmly knit together. This therefore is no reaon, why they hould not run fat: and the contrary was oberved of the Pygmie that it did o.

The length of the Os Ilium, from it's Spine to it's Conjunction with the Os Ichium, was three Inches; where 'twas broadet, 'twas an Inch and half; where narrowet, but three quarters of an Inch. The Os lchium was an Inch and three quarters long; the Os Pubis was an Inch long.

(b) I did not oberve any difference in the Structure of the Thighbone in our Pygmie from that in Man; nor was it's Articulation or Inertion of it's Head into the Acetabulum, more oblique than in Man. So that from this Articulation, I aw no reaon why it hould not walk upright and it; our Pygmie did both: When I aw it, 'twas jut a little before it's death; and tho' 'twas weak and feeble, it would tand, and go upright.

The length of the Thigh-bone in the Pygmie was five Inches: The girth of it in the middle an Inch and three quarters; where 'twas joined to the Bones of the Leg, 'twas an Inch and almot an half broad.

(c) The Neck of the Head of the Thigh-bone in our Pygmie was not different in it's length, as I did oberve, from that of a Man's, but the ame proportionably; as were likewie the two Apophyes, called Trochanteres.

(d) The Patella in our Pygmie was not yet oified. As much as I could dicover of it's hape, it was the ame as in Man; round and not long; and but one Bone, and not two, as Riolan decribes it in the Monkey. In the Sceletons of the Monkeys I ued, thee Bones were lot, o that I did not oberve them.

(e) The two Bones in the Leg, the Tibia and the Fibula were jut the ame in the Pygmie as in Man; and their Articulations were alike: The Tibia was four Inches long; the Fibula was a little horter. The girth of the Tibia in the middle was about an Inch; of the Fibula, about half an Inch.

(f) What makes the foot of the Pygmie eem different from a Man's, is chiefly the length of the Toes, and the Structure of the great Toe. In other repects, it has a great reemblance with it. For the Bones of the Metatarus here, eemed proportionably as long as in Man. The Os Calcis, Calcaneum or Heel-bone was not narrow, but broad; and forewards, where 'twas joined to the Os Cuboide or Cubiforme, not broader, nor longer than behind; where it juts out o far, as ufficiently ecures it's
tanding or walking erect. The Atragalus I did not oberve different from a Man's. The Scaphoides or Naviculare here was Cartilaginous. If one reckons three Joints in the great Toe, then there can be but four Bones in the Planta Pedis, or Metatarus; which with Eutachius I am more inclined to, becaue really this Part performs upon any occaion the ue of an Hand too; and the great Toe, (like the Thumb in the Hand) tands off from the range of the other Fingers. Beides, I oberved a difference in the Colour in the Bones of the Metatarus and the Toes: for the Colour of the Toes was white and opace; the Colour of the Bones of the Metatarus was like to that of the Cartilages, and more tranparent. Now all the three Bones in the great Toe were of the ame colour, white as were the other Toes. Therefore I hall make but four Bones in the Metatarus, anwerable to thoe of the Metacarpus in the Hand, and three Bones in the great Toe.

(g) And as the Hand of our Pygmie in ome Parts reembled the Humane; in others the Ape-kind: So the ame may be aid of the Foot too. For the Heel, the Tarus and Metatarus were like to the Humane. But all the Toes were liker to the Ape and Monkey-kind: For the Toes here, if we may call them Toes, and not rather Fingers, were almot as long as the Fingers in the Hand; much longer proportionably than in Man, and not lying o cloe together: But the Bones of the Fingers in the Hand, were larger and bigger than thoe of the Toes.

(h) The great Toe in the Pygmie, was horter than the firt of the other Toes; tho' in a Man 'tis altogether as long; and herein it reembles the Ape-kind. But whereas Aritotle (as I have remarked) mentions, that in Apes the middle Toe is the longet, as is the middle Finger in the Hand; In the Sceleton of the Pygmie I did oberve, that the firt and middle Toe were both much of a length, each meauring an Inch and three quarters: The third and little Toe were about an Inch and an half long; the little Toe being rather omewhat horter than the third Toe. If in the great Toe you reckon three Articuli, as Eutachius does, then from the Tarus to it's Extream, the great Toe meaured two Inches and an half: but if with Coiter you make but two Articuli or Joints in the great Toe, and the other to be a Bone of the Metatarus; thee two were only an Inch and a quarter long: The four Bones of the Metatarus were much of a length, being about an Inch and a quarter long.

This great Toe (as has been already frequently remarked) being et off from the range of the others, more reembles a Thumb. This Difference I oberve in it's make, That the Bones that compoe it, are much bigger and larger, than any of the other Toes; and in repect of the Thumb in the Hand, vatly bigger. In the Sceletou of a Monkey I did not oberve the Bones of the great Toe, to exceed thoe of the other. But as the Thumb in the Foot is much bigger, than that in the Hand; o the Fingers in the Hand are much larger than thoe in the Foot.

div.head: CAP. VI.
De Seamoideis.
div.p: IN Homine Oa Seamoidea pauca unt, magnaque ex parte cartilaginoa, & i ea quae pollici applicantur exceperis, in contanti ede firmata. In imia verò multa, atque magna occurrunt, & oea perpetuò unt. Cuique primo quatuor digitorum internodio, & ecundo pollicis gemina ferè emper adnectuntur. Duo oicula magnitudine ciceris, upra utrumque tuberculum femoris in origine gemellorum reperiuntur.

As to the Oa Seamoidea in our Subject, I have very little to ay: For it being young, very likely they might be only Cartilaginous, and the Skin adhering o firmly here, they might be taken off with it. Since they are in Apes, I do not doubt, but that they were in our Pygmie too, tho' I did not oberve them.

Having now made my Remarks upon the Comparion, that Riolan, or rather Eutachius and Coiter, have given us, between the Sceleton of a Man, an Ape, and a Monkey; and hewn wherein the Sceleton of our Pygmie either agreed or diagreed from any of them, I hall make ome Reflections upon the whole; and more particularly upon ome Parts, which deerve here a more ditinct Conideration. But hall firt of all take the Dimenions of the Sceleton, and of ome other Parts I have not mentioned already.

As from the top of the Cranium to the Extream of the Heel in a trait Line, the Sceleton of the Pygmie meaured about two Foot; from the firt Vertebra of the Neck to the lat of the Os Coccygis, eleven Inches; from the head of the Shoulder-bone, to the end of the middle Finger, 'twas about fifteen Inches; the end of this Finger reaching in an erect Poture an Inch and half below the Patella: whereas in an Humane Sceleton, from the end of the middle Finger to the lower part of the Patella, it wanted five Inches and an half: Our Pygmie therefore herein imitated the Ape-kind. From the head of the Thigh-bone, to the bottom of the Os Calcis in the Pygmie, was about ten Inches. From the etting on of the firt Rib, to the fatening on of the lat, was four Inches. The ditance between the lat Rib, and the Spine of the Os Ilium, not full two Inches. From the Spine of the Os Ilium, to the bottom of the Os Pubis, in a trait Line, was four Inches and three quarters. The ditance between the end of the Scapula, and Spine of the Os Ilium about three Inches.
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>

Both when it was alive, and after it's death, I admired the traitnes and hape of it's Back. Now the Scapula coming down o low on the Ribs, and inclining towards the Vertebrae of the Back, and the Os Ilium riing o high, they do contribute very much towards it; and mut alo a • ford a great afeguard and trength to the Back and Spine.

The Sceleton of our Pygmie was jut the ame length of one of a Monkeys that I borrowed: But becaue I oberved mot of the Apophyes of the Bones to be Cartilaginous in the Pygmie, I mut conclude, that 'twas but young; and that probably it might grow taller; to what height I am uncertain. Yet I can by no means be induced to believe, that it would ever arrive to the Stature of a Man, as ome ort of this Species of Animals has been oberved to do; for then I could not expect to have een here, the Bones themelves o olid, or the Cranium to be o entirely oiied, or the Sutures to be o cloed and indented, and the Backbone and Ribs o fully hardened, as all the Bones of the Artus or Limbs were likewie, except at their Apophyes, and in the Carpus and Tarus. Now all thee Parts that had thee Cartilaginous Apophyes, had already acquired o great a length, in proportion to the ret of the Body, that 'tis not to be imagined, that they would have exceeded it, or at leat not much; and conidering that Animals come to their < in non-Latin alphabet > of growth ooner or later, according to their Longevity, as a Man, (till he is pat the Age that any of thee Creatures, it may be, arrive to) does not leave growing: this inclines me to think, ince we found mot parts of the Body o perfected here, that it might not in time much exceed the height it had already acquired. I could have wihed that thoe that have wrote of any of this Species of Animals, had given us their Dimenions and Ages; but they are ilent herein, or at leat too general: only Le Compte observed an Ape in the Straits of Molucca four foot high; but this may not be our ort. As to thoe of Borneo, I was informed by a Sea-Captain who ued thoe Parts, that the King there formerly had one as tall as a Man, that would frequently come down to the Town, and a great many Stories are told of him. The ame Captain had two given him, both young, and about the height of our Pygmie; but thee were not hairy, but naked as a Man; and one of them that he carried to Batavia, was looked upon as o great a Rarity, that all the time he taid there, his Ship was contantly viited by uch as came to ee it. But 'tis Master of Fact, not Reaoning, that will bet determine this doubt, and a faithful Obervation that mut inform us, to what tallnes this ort of Animal in Angola, and the Countries thereabout, does uually grow; for in different Countries they may be different in this repect, tho' the ame Species, as is een even in Mankind.

'Tis not therefore that I am fond of the word Pygmie, that I have called our Animal o, or that I would undertake to jutifie our preent
Subject to be exactly the Pygmie of the Ancients: Of this Quadru-Manu; ort of Animals there are divers Species, and ome may be taller and others horter; but all of them being but Brutes, I was unwilling to call ours a Man, tho' with an Epithet. 'Twas neceary to give it a Name, becaue not tallying exactly with the Decriptions of thoe that are given us, I did not know but that it might be different: and it's preent height correponding o well with that of the Pygmies of the Ancients, (and we may allow omething for growth too) induced me to this denomination: For as A. Gellius A. G • ll. N • st. A •••• . lib. 9. cap. 4. p. 205 tells us, the Pygmies were two Foot and a quarter high. Pygmaeos quoque (aith he) hand longè ab his naci, quorum qui longiimi unt, non longiores ee quàm pedes duos & quadrantem. And o Pliny Plin • N •• Hit. lib. 7. cap. 2. p.m. 13., Suprà hos extremâ in parte Montium Tripithami, Pygmaeique narrantur, ternas Spimathas longitudine, hoc est ternos dodrantes non excedentes; that is twenty even Inches. For as Ludovicus Vives Lud. <> Comment in D. Aug <…> ni de Civitate De • , lib. 16. cap. 8. p.m. 82 •
oberves, a Foot contains ixteen Digiti or twelve Pollices. The Dodrans or Spithama, which is the Palmus major, contains nine Pollices; the Palmus minor is but three Pollices, or four Digiti, that is, a quarter of a Foot: And o Herodotus Herod • tus in Europe, No. 149. p.m. 448. informs us, that the Palmus contains four Digiti, and the Cubit ix Palmi. The Pygmie therefore being Tripithamus or three Spithamae long, was twenty even Inches long, or as A. Gellius tells us, two Foot and a quarter. So our Animal, before Diection meaured twenty ix Inches; but in the Sceleton, only four and twenty Inches. Not but Strabo Strab • . Geograph. lib. 15. p.m. 489. out of Megathenes, does mention too, the < in non-Latin alphabet > , as well as the < in non-Latin alphabet > ; but thee latter (he tells us) were thoe, that Homer makes to fight the Cranes, However it be, if our Ape be not the Pygmie of the Ancients, yet I can't but think, the Pygmies of the Ancients were only a ort of Apes, notwithtanding all the Romances that have been made about them. And if o, and our Ape be found not much to exceed the meaures given, I hall think my Conjecture in giving this Name, not amis. But of this hereafter. And to proceed:

Since the Bones are the main Timber-work in this Fabrick of Animal Bodies, by which the whole is upported, and upon their Structure, in a good meaure, does depend their manner of local motion, we will here more particularly enquire, which may be thought the mot natural way of walking in our Pygmie, either as a Quadruped or a Biped, for it did both upon occaion; and we will ee whether by Nature 'twas equally provided for the doing both.

Now when I oberved it to go upon all four, as a Quadruped (as has been already remark'd) it did not place the Palms of the Hands flat to
the Ground, but went upon it's Knuckles, or rather upon the firt Joints of the Fingers of the Fore-hands, the econd and third Joints being bended or touching the Ground; which eem'd to me o unuual a way of walking, as I have not oberved the like before in any Animal. And I did expect it the les here: becaue the Fore-limbs being o very long, it might be thought, that it had the les need of thus raiing the Body. And the whole weight of the Body thus lying upon thee Joints of the Fingers, one would think, that they hould be oon tired in upporting it, and that Nature did not deign it for a Contancy, but only upon occaion, or a preent hift: For if it was to be it's uual way of walking, no doubt, for it's greater eae, it would place the Palms flat to the Ground, as all other Animals do the ole of the Foot, and hereby it would be rendered better able to bear this weight.

Beides, when it walks thus upon it's Fingers, the flexure at the Elbow will be inwards, towards the ides of the Body, which is different from all other Quadrupeds, and in it's Progreion will be of no ue at all, nay, will be an hinderance to it; and it will require a great tention of the Mucles to keep thee Fore-limbs trait; and if they are not kept o, they mut halt, and can't move wiftly; which makes me diffident, that this can't be it's Natural Poture in going; for Nature always contrives the eaiet and bet ways of Motion. Now in Quadrupeds the flection of the fore and hinder Limbs, is both the ame way: But in a Man and an Ape (as I have before remarked from Aritotle) 'tis contrary; or as Pliny exprees it, Homini genua & Cubita contraria, item ris & Simiarum generi, ob id minimè pernicibus. But how Pliny comes to bring in the Bear here, I do not undertand: for if with the Pariians Vide Their Anatomic Decription of a Bear in their Memoirs, p. m. 44. we hould here undertand by Genua, the Heel-bone, and by Cubita a Bone of the Carpus (which are often longer in Brutes than in Man) then this will be a Property not peculiar to Bears, but might be oberved in other Quadrupeds too. I hould rather own it as a Mitake in Pliny. Nor can I aent to the Pariians, That all Animals have thee Parts turned after the ame, manner, whatever Aritotle may report thereof. I mut confes I am of Aritotle's mind, and any Body may experience it in himelf, and oberve the flexure of the Cubit to be different from that of the Knee; and where 'tis o, there the Motion upon all four, will be very awkward and unnatural, and as Pliny oberves, it can't be wift.

I hall here further oberve, that in Quadrupeds the make of the Thorax, the etting on of the Scapula, and the Articulation of the Humerus, or Shoulder-bone, are much different from what they are in Bipeds.: for Quadrupeds are narrow Cheted, and their Thorax not o round as in a Man, becaue in them the Scapulae are to be placed more forward upon the Ribs, and not o backwards as in Men. And the Articulation or the
Shoulder with the Scapula in Quadrupeds lies nearer the Ribs; in Man 'tis extended farther from them. Now our Pygmie o exàctly imitating Humane-kind in all thee Circumtances, makes me think that Nature did not deign it a Quadruped, but a Biped. For it had a full round Chest or Thorax, and it's Scapulae placed backwards, not o forwards on the Ribs, and the Articulation of the Shoulder with the Scapula, tood off from the Ribs as it do's in Man. And from this very Conideration Galen len de uu Partium, lib. 13. cap. 11. p. m. 627. tells us, That a Man, if he would, could not walk upon all four, < in non-Latin alphabet > (aith he) < in non-Latin alphabet > . i.e. Meritò itaque Homo ne, i volet, quidem ambularc quatuor artubus queat, quòd in ipo Scapularum Articuli longè à Thorace int abducti. And Galen all along owns, that the Structure of the Scapula in the Ape, is the ame as in a Man; and tells us that an Ape is exactly neither a Quadruped, nor a Biped, but amphibious between both. For in the ame Chapter, peaking of the Ape, he aith, < in non-Latin alphabet > i. e. Quod verò ad Scapulas & Claves attinet, homini maxime est imilis, quamquàm eâ parte homini imilis ee non debebat, nam quod ad ambulationis celeritatem pertinet, imia inter genus utrumque ambigit, neque cnim Bipes penitus est, neque Quadrupes; ed quatenùs est Bipes, clauda est, non enim rectè planè tare potest; & quatenùs est Quadrupes, mutila imul est, ac tarda, quòd Humeri articulus à Thorace plurimùm it abductus, quemadmodùm i idem articulus in alio quopiam animante a Thorace divulus extra eceiet. Now altho' Galen tells us here, that an Ape can carce tand upright; yet in another place he declares quite the contrary; for, aith he Galen de uu Partium, lib. 11. cap. 2 •
, < in non-Latin alphabet > . i.e. Est autem imillima homini Simia, ut quae rotundam praecipuè habet factem, Dentes Caninos parvos, latum Pectus, Claviculas longiores, minimùm Piloa, quae recta etiam tat bellè ut & incedere ine errore, & currere velociter poit.

We have een upon what accounts our Pygmie may be thought not to be a Quadruped, or that it's natural Greion is not on all four, and how ill it is provided to go that way. We will now enquire, Whether there is not more reaon to think that Nature deigned it
to be a Biped, and to walk erect. And in the doing this, we may oberve the largenes of the He • l-bone in the Foot, which being o much extended, ufficiently ecures the Body from falling backwards, as the length of the Toes do's it's being cat too forwards; and the Arms being o long, may eaily give a poie either way, for the preerving the AEquilibrium of the Body. And it may be, this is the Reaon why the Pongos hold their hands behind their Necks, when they walk erect. If we conider the Articulation of the Os Femoris in the Acetabulum, there is no difference to be oberved from a Man, nor indeed in any other Circumtance that relates to this Matter. 'Tis true, in my firt figure I repreent him as weak and feeble and b •• ding; for when I firt aw him, he was dyings; beides, being young, and ill it had not that trength in it's Limbs, as in time and in health, it might have acquired; and I was willing to repre
•• nt what I aw my elf. But what very much ways with me, to think him a Biped, and to go erect, and that Nature did deign it o, much more than any of the Ape and Monkey-kind beides, was my oberving the Peritonaeum to be entire, and not perforated or protruded in the
• roin, as it is in Apes and Dogs, and other Quadrupeds: as likewie, becaue I found the Pericardium in our Pygmie to be fatened to the D •• hragm, as 'tis in Man, and which is not o in Apes and Monkeys. Both which are o remarkable differences, and (as I have already <> marked) o particularly contrived for the advantage of an erect <…> re of the Body, that, I think, the Inference is eaie, and we may <…> ly conclude, that Nature intended it a Biped, and hath not been wanting in any thing, in forming the Organs, and all Parts accordingly; and if not altogether o exactly as in a Man, yet much more than in any other Brute beides: For I own it, as my contant Opinion, (notwithtanding the ill urmie and uggetion made by a forward Gentleman) that tho' our Pygmie has many Advantages above the ret of it's Species, yet I till think it but a ort of Ape and a meer Brute; and as the Proverb has it, < in non-Latin alphabet >
Lucian. adverus indoctum. Oper. p. m. 865. An Ape is an Ape, tho' finely clad.

This Proverb, perhaps, might have it's rie from ome uch occaion as Lucian mentions in another place; and the Story being pleaant, and relating to what we have been jut now dicouring upon, viz. it's manner of Motion, we will inert it here, and then proceed to the Myology. Lucian Lucian. Picator ive Revivicentes. p. m. 214. therefore aith, < in non-Latin alphabet > &c. i. e. Fertur AEgyptius Rex quidam Simias ut tripudiarent intituie, Animaliaque (nam admodùm ad res humanas imitandas unt. apta) celerrim • didicie, ut Peronata ac Purpurata altarent: eraique admodùm viu res digna, donec Spectator quipiam
urbanus nuces è inu depromptas in medium abjiceret: id imiae videntes, tripudij oblitae, id quod erat, imiae pro altatoribus evaerunt, Peronas conterebant, vetitum dicerpebant, invicemque pro fructibus depugnabant, ità ut Pyrriches ordo diolveretur, à Theatroque ridebatur. And in another place Lucian. pro Mercede conductis, p.m. 363. he tells the like Story of Cleopatra's Apes. So that they can, not only go erect, but can dance in a figure too, if taught to do o. But this is not natural, but acquired by Art; and even Dogs have been taught to do the ame. So AElian AElian. Hit. Animal. lib. 5.p.m. 26. tells us, that an Ape is eaily taught to perform any Action; if 'tis taught to Dance, 'twill Dance, or Play upon the Pipe; and that once he aw one upply the Place of a Coachman; holding the Reins; pulling them in, or letting them looe, and uing the Whip, as there was occaion. And that Story in Kercher (100)Kercher. China illutrata, Part.4.cap. 7. p.m. 195., of the Embaie that the King of Bengal ent to the Great Mogul in the Year 1660 is very remarkable, where a great Ape richly adorned, did drive a Chariot magnificently gilded, and et with Jewels; and did it with the greatet State and Pageantry in the World, and as skilfully as the bet Coach-man could do.

It would be infinite to relate all the Stories that are told us of them; and I have been too tedious already. I hall therefore haten now: But mut inform the Reader, that I am obliged to my good Friend Mr. Cowper, not only for deigning all my figures; but obtained of him likewie to draw up this enuing account of the Mucles; whoe great Skill and Knowledge herein, is ufficiently made evident by his Myotomia Reformata, or, New Adminitration of all the Mucles in Humane Bodies, publihed ometime ince: To which I refer my Reader, for a fuller account of them, whenever 'tis aid, that uch and uch Mucles in the Pygmie reembled thoe in Humane Bodies. And for his greater Eae, there are References all along made, to the figures; where the firt Number ignifies the Figure, or Table; the econd Number the Mucle exhibited or repreented there.

div.head: 84 THE MYOTOMY OR DESCRIPTION OF THE MUSCLES.
Of the Mucles of the Abdomen.
div.p: THE Obliquus Decendens (Fig. 3.38.) agreed in it's ituation and progres, with that of a Humane Body, as the accurate Galen and Vealius decribe it, and did not partly pring from any of the Tranvere Procees of the Vertebrae of the Loins; or their Ligaments and Membranes, as the later Writers would have it in Humane Bodies. Neither did any part of the Obliquus Acendens (Fig. 3. 39.) arie from the Lumbal Vertebrae, as Vealius decribes it in Men: but agreed with the Decription of Galen, and did not differ from the Humane. Drelincourt oberves the like in Apes: The ame Author takes notice, that the Pyramidales are wanting in thoe Animals; which were abent alo in the Pygmie. The Rectus (Fig. 3. 40.) agreed with the Humane, and had no Connection with a Mucular Portion, pringing either from the Clavicula or firt Rib, as Vealius has figured Galen's Decription of it in Apes and Dogs. The Pariians ay, In Monkeys it acends to the top, paing under the Pectoralis and Little Serratus, it was Flehy only to the half of the Sternum, the rest being but a meer Tendon. Drelincourt oberves the Tendinous Incriptions of thee Mucles in Apes, appear'd only on their inide, and not on the out. The Tranveralis in this, as in mot Quadrupeds, did not differ from that in Man.

The Cremater Mucles were very mall by reaon of the leannes of the Subject. The Accelerator Spermatis (Fig. 7. G.) Erector Penis (Fig. ib. K.) and Tranveralis Penis (ib. L.) agreed in their Situation and Figure with thoe of Men; the lat of which only varied in it's Termination, as appears in the Figure.

The Detruor rinae agreed with the Figure of the Bladder of rinae of this Animal. The Sphincter Veicae differ'd not from that in Men; and mot, if not all Quadrupeds; it being placed in the Neck of the Bladder, beyond the Caruncula or Caput Gallinaginis, immediately above the Protates. The Sphincter Ani differ'd not from the Humane; unles it might eem omewhat les. The Levatores Ani were longer and more divided from each other, than in Humane Bodies: The like may be oberv'd in mot, if not all Quadrupeds; by reaon of the Length and differing Figure of the Bones, whence thee Mucles take their rie.
I could find no Occipital nor Frontal Mucles in this Animal.

The Orbicularis Palpebrarum (Fig. 3.2.) and Aperiens Palpebram Rectus agreed with the Humane, and thoe of mot Quadrupeds. The Obliquus Superior, Inferior, Elevator, Depreor, Adductor, and Abductor Oculi, agreed with thoe of the Humane Eye and an Ape's, as Julius Caerius Placentinus Figures them Tab. 4. Organi Viûs, Fig. XII. & XIII. Nor was there any Muculus Septimus Brutorum in this Animal. The Aloe Nai of the Pygmie being mall, thoe Mucles only appear'd, which from their Office are call'd Contrictores Alarum Nai, ac Depreores Labij uperioris.

The Quadratus Genae, or Platuma Myoides, by reaon of the Leannes of the Subject, (as I upect) did not appear Flehy. The Buccinator (Fig.3.7.) was longer than that in Man. Nor was it any where intertext with various orders of Fibres, as Anatomits commonly repreent it in Man; or eem'd to arie from any other Parts, but the Proceus Corone; from whence it's Fibres had a trait progres to the Angle of the Lips; as in Men: This and the former Mucles, are counted Common Mucles to the Cheeks and Lips.

The Mucles Common to both Lips, are the Zygomaticus, (Fig. 3. 3.) Elevator, Depreor, and Contritor Labiorum, which were not o conpicuous, as in Men. The Proper Mucles of the upper and under Lip, were very ditinct in this Animal, (viz.) the Elevator and Depreor Labij Superioris, (Fig. 3. 4.) the lat of which is mentioned above, and called Contrictor Aloe Nai; the Depreor and Elevator Labij Superioris, (Fig. 3.5.)

Tho' the Auricula or Outward Ear of this Animal was as large, if not larger than that of a Man, yet I could not oberve any Mucle, which erv'd for it's Motion. I could not examine the Mucles of the Tympanum and Stapes, by reaon the Bones were kept entire for a Sceleton.

The Sternohyoideus, Coracohyoideus, Mylohyoideus and Geniohyoideus, did not differ from thoe in Men; which Drelincourt has alo oberved of the former in the Female Ape. The Stylohyoideus did not arie from the Styliform Proces; that Proces being wanting in this Animal, or at leat did not appear, by reason it was young; this Mucle therefore eem'd to arie from the Os Petroum.

The Genioglous, by reaon of the length of the Lower Jaw, was longer than that in Man. The Ceratoglous and Styloglous differ'd not; except that the latter aries from the Os Petroum, like the Stylohyoideus. The other Mucles appear'd in this Animal belonging to it's Tongue. The Sternothyroideus, Hyothyroideus, Cricothyroideus, Cricoarytaenoideus, Poticus and Lateralis; the Thyroarytaenoideus, and Arytaenoideus varied not from thoe in Men. The Mycles of the Fauces alo, differ'd not from thoe in Man, (viz.) The Stylopharyngaeus, Pterygopharyngaeus, Oeophagaeus and Vaginalis Gulae. The following Mucles of the Gargareon were exactly like the Humane, (viz.) the Sphenotaphylinus and Pterygotaphylinus.

Now all the Mucles of the Lower Jaw may be een without incommoding any hereafter mentioned. The Temporalis (Fig. 3. 1.) and Maeter (Fig. 3. 6.) eem'd omewhat larger than the Humane, and as they are commonly in Brutes, by reaon their lower Jaw-bones are larger than thoe of Men; yet thee Mucles were not o trong, as thoe of Monkeys, as the Pariians repreent them. The Superior Salival Duct pat over the Maeter, and entred the Muculus Buccinator of the Pygmie, as in Man. The Digatricus aroe not from the Mammiform Proces, as in Men; but prang from the Occipital-bone; it's progres in this Animal agreed exactly with that in a Humane Body. Drelincourt decribes it in Apes thus, Ven line a habet intermedium pollice longum, & gracilem, enacitur, autem •• n ab • pophye Styloide, ed ab oe Bailari.

The Mucles of the Thorax which appear on the fore-part come next. The Inter ••
• ales externi and interni, (Fig. 4.32.) Triangularis, Scalenus Primus, S •• undus and Tertius; Subelavius (Fig. 3. 34.) Serratus minor anticus (Fig. 3. 35.) Serratus major anticus, (Fig. 3. 37.) All thee were like the Humane. The Pariians tell us, That the Great Serratus did in in their Monkeys arie from the fourth, fifth, and ixth Vertebra of the Neck; but it was not o in the Pygmie: The like is taken notice of by Drelincourt in Apes. The Diaphragma was larger in this Animal, than in
Man, agreeable to the Capacity of its Thorax: The ret of the Mucles of the Thorax appear on it's Back-part, which we hall mention hereafter.

Before I pas to the Mucles on the Back-part of our Pygmie, I hall take notice of a Pair of Mucles, that do not appear in Humane Bodies; which from their Ue may be call'd Elevatores Clavicularum, (Fig. 3. 12.) Either of them aries Flehy from the Tranvere Procees of the econd and third Vertebra of the Neck; and decends obliquely outwards to it's broad Inertion at the upper part of the Clavicula; when it Acts, it draws up the Clavicle, aiting the Elevator Scapulae, and upper part of the Cucularis, in raiing the whole Shoulder. The ituation of this Mucle, is not unlike the upper part of that repreented by Vealius in his ixth Table of the Mucles O. T. P. Q. which he ays is found in Dogs and Apes, and decribed by Galen in Humane Bodies, in whom it is not exitent. Drelincourt calls it Levator Omoplatae, (adding) ab Apophyibus tranveris cervicalibus in Acromion & extremum claviculae extenditur.

The Mucles imploy'd in the Motion of the Scapula, are the Cucularis. (Fig.4. 1.1.1.) Rhomboides (Fig.4.6.) Levator Scapulae (ib.5.) Thee alo agreed with the Humane: The like being taken notice of by Drelincourt of the Cucularis, in the Female Ape. The ret of the Mucles of the Thorax, are the Serratus uperior poticus, (Fig. 4. 7.) the Serratus inferior poticus (Fig. 4. 32. 32.) Thee differ'd not from thoe in Men. The Sacrolumbalis (Fig, 4. 29.) was not o thick as in Men, but was every way lenderer.

The Mucles imploy'd in the Motion of the Head of the Pygmie, differed very little from thoe in Man; as the Splenius, (Fig. 4. 2.) Complexus, (Fig. 4.4.) Rectus major, Rectus minor, Obliquus Superior, and Obliquus Inferior, neither was this Inferior Oblique Mucle larger than in Man; as Vealius, Lib. II. Cap. XXVIII. aures us, it is in Apes and Dogs. The Matoideus (Fig. 3.8. 8.) was chiefly inerted to the Occipital-bone, as the Pariians oberve it in Monkeys. The Rectus internus major, not commonly decribed by Authors in Humane Bodies, tho' it is very plain and contant in all thoe, I have hitherto lookt for it, was alo in the Pygmie.
