The Rectus internus minor, or Muculus Annuens, ometimes oberved by me in Humane Bodies, was alo in this Animal; and o was the Rectus Lateralis decribed by Falloppius in Men. Nor was any of thoe Mucles I have dicovered in Humane Bodies, wanting in this Animal, but the Interpinales Colli.

The Longi Colli of this Animal, appear'd to be longer and larger than thoe of Humane Bodies. The Spinalis Colli and Tranveralis Colli were like thoe in Humane Bodies. The Interpinales Colli, which I have elewhere decribed in Men, did not appear in this Animal. The Longiimus
Dori (Fig. 4. 28.) nor unlike the Sacrolumbalis above noted, was not o thick and flehy at it's Origin from the Os Ilium, Sacrum, and Vertebrae of the Loins; nor was it's external Surface in the Pygmie o tendinous, as in Humane Bodies; but was omewhat broader. The Quadratus Lumborum was longer than in Men, agreeable to the pace between the Spine of the Os Ilium, and lower Rib of this Animal. See the Figure of the Sceleton. The Sacer, and Semipinatus, differ'd not from the Humane, as I have repreented them in my Myotomia Reformata, pag.135.

The Mucles of the Superior Parts and Trunk of the Body being dipatch't, we come next to thoe of the Limbs; and firt of the Arm or Os Humeri. The Pectoralis (Fig. 3. 33.) was much broader at it's Original, from the Sternum, than in Man: it's Fibres were decuated near it's Inertion. Galen and Jacobus Sylvius take notice of another Mucle under the Pectoralis in Apes, which is implanted into the Arm near the Pectoral Mucle. The Deltoides (Fig. 3. 15. and 4. 12.) was alo broader at it's Original. Jac. Sylvius tells us, this Mucle in Apes is like that of a Man. The Suprapinatus (Fig. 4. 8.) agreed with the Humane in it's ituation; but was omewhat broader at it's Origin from the upper part of the Bais Scapulae. The Infrapinatus, as the former Mucle was broader at it's Original from the Scapula, this on the contrary was there narrower than the Humane. Sylvius and Drelincourt mention thee Mucles in Apes; but whether they reemble thoe of Men, or this Animal, do's not appear by their Accounts. Teres minor, (Fig. 4. 10.) this is ometimes wanting in Men: it was omewhat horter and thicker in this Animal. The Teres major, (Fig. 4. 11.) was very large in the Pygmie. The Latiimus Dori agreed with the Humane in it's Original and Progres towards the Arm; but when it arrived at the Axilla, it parted with a flehy Portion, which decended on the inide of the Arm, with the Muculus Biceps, and becoming a lender Tendon is inerted to the internal protuberance of the Os Humeri: (vide Fig. 8. C.) which repreents the production of this Mucle. This Appendix or Acceory Mucle of the Latiimus Dori, is not peculiar to this Animal; the like being found in Apes according to Jacobus Sylvius, who, I am inclin'd to think is mitaken, in repreenting it's Inertion at the Olecranum of that Animal: This part of the Latiimus Dori eems a proper Intrument in turning the Os Humeri to a prone Poition, when thee Animals go on all four, for the more advantagious tepping with the Fore-feet, by raiing the Os Humeri, and turning it backwards. Galen in Lib. de Muculis, Cap. XIX. decribes this Appendix of the Latiimus Dori, under the Title of a mall Mucle found in the Articulation of the Shoulder. The Coracobrachialis was like that in Man, but had no diviion in it for any Nerve ro pas through. The Subcapularis was alo like that in Man.

The Mucles employed in Bending and Extending the Cubit, differ'd very little from the Humane, viz. Biceps, (Fig. 3.16.16.) Brachiaeus internus, (ib. 18.) Gemellus, (Fig. 4. 14.) Brachiaeus externus, Anconaeus, (Fig. 4. 15. 15.) The like is oberved of thee Mucles by Sylvius in Apes, who only adds that the Extenders are remarkably large in that Animal. The Biceps in the Pygmie, had the ame double tendinous Termination, as in Man.

The Caro Muculoa Quadrata appear'd in the Palm of the Pygmie: nor was there any flehy Belly, and long Tendon to the Palmaris; yet there was a Tendon or Ligament extended in the Palm; the like has been often taken notice of in Men, as Realdus Columbus alo oberves. The Pariians tell us, the Palmaris in Monkeys is extraordinary large.

The Mucles of the four Fingers were, the Perforatus,(Fig. 3. 24.) Perforans, (Fig. 3. 25.) Lumbricales; (ib. 31.) thee agreed exactly with the Humane; but the Extenor Digitorum Communis (Fig 4. 21.) was larger and ditinct from the Extenor minimi Digiti, as in Men and Apes, which Drelincourt observes. The Extenor Indicis, Abductor Indicis, (Fig. 3.30.) Extenor minimi digiti, (Fig. 4.20.) Abductor minimi digitis (Fig. 4. 25.) and Interoij Manûs, differ'd not from thoe in Men. All the Mucles of the Thumb reembled thoe in Men, (viz.) the Flexor tertij internodij pollicis, Abductor Pollicis, (Fig. 3. 28.) Fiexor primi & ecundi ois pollicis, (ib. 29.) Adductor Pollicis, (Fig. 4. 27.) Extenor Primi internodij Pollicis, (ib. 23.) Extenor ecundi ois Pollicis, and Extenor tertij ois pollicis. The Mucles of the Wrist alo agreed with thoe in Men; viz. the Flexor Carpi Radialis, (Fig. 3. 23.) and lnaris, (ib. 26.) the Extenor Carpi Radialis, (ib. 19.) and lnaris; (ib. 20.) The two lat Drelincourt ays, are alo like the Humane in the Male-Ape.

The Mucles employ'd in the Pronation and Supination of the Radius in the Pygmie, were larger in proportion than thoe in Men. The Pronator Radij teres (Fig. 3.20.) had a double Origin; the one from the internal Protuberance of the Os Humeri, the other from the upper part of the lna: the Pronator Radij Quadratus. The Supinator Radij Longus is taken notice of by Drelincourt in Apes to be like that of Men. The Supinator Radij bravis, (Fig. 4. 24.) agreed exactly with the Humane.

The Mucles of no part diagreed o much from thoe in Men, as thoe of the Thigh of this Animal: Here was no Glutaeus minor; nor did the Glutaeus maximus (Fig. 4. 33. 33.) reemble the Humane: It was meerly Tendinous at it's Origin, from the whole Spine of the Os Ilium; it was much longer, and not o thick as in Man; nor were it's flehy Fibres o divided: This Sylvius decribes for the Membranous in Apes. The Pariians give a very imperfect account of the Muculi Glutaei in Monkeys, where they tell us, The Mucles of the Buttock had a Figure differing from
thoe in Men, being horter, by reaon the Oa Ilium in Apes are much traiter than in Man. The Glutaeus medius was alo longer than that in Man. The Poas magnus was alo longer; which Sylvius (from it's Figure I uppoe) calls Lumbaris Biceps in Apes. The Poas parvus was alo longer and larger, than in Man. Beides this, the Pariians tell us of two other little Mucles in Monkeys, which have the ame Origin as the Poas; and were inerted into the upper and inward part of the Os Pubis. The Iliacus Internus was long, conformable to the Figure of the Os Ilium of this Animal; (Vide Fig. 5. 28. 28) The Pectineus was not very ditinct. The Triceps (Fig. 4. 37.) had no Tendinous Termination at the lower Appendix of the Thigh-bone internally. Jacobus Sylvius ays in Apes, Tricipitis pars longiima à Tubere in Condylum: altera portio inignis, à Tubere etiam nata, potico cruri propè toti aixa, ad uque Cavitatem inter duos condylos mediam: tertia minima & breviima ois pubis in medium & poticum Os Cruris. The Pyriformis (Fig. 4. 35.) was like the Humane; nor did it appear les in proportion, as the Pariians repreent it, in Monkeys, who ay, This Mucle, intead of taking it's rie from the lower and external part of the Os Sacrum, it proceeded from the Ichium near the Cavitas Cotyloides. The Marupialis had it's Marupium much broader than in Men. The Quadratus Femoris was les than in Man. The Obturator extrorum was much larger.

The Common Mucles of the Thigh and Leg, agreed in their Situation and Number, with thoe of Men. The Membranous (Fig. 3.41.) had not o trong a Tendon to cover the Mucles of the Thighs and Tibia, as in Man. The Sartorius (Fig. 3. 42.) agreed with the Humane. The Gracilis (Fig 3 48.) was thicker and larger near it's Origin. The Seminervous (Fig. 4. 40.) and Semimembranous, differ'd not from the Humane. The Biceps (Fig. 4. 41.)had it's econd beginning, omewhat lower, than in Men: The Pariians tell us, The Biceps in Monkeys had not a double Origin as in Man, but proceeded intire, from the Knob of the Ichium, and was inerted to the upper part of the Perona. This ingle Head was in requital very thick and trong. The Rectus had a double order of Fibres, as in Man. The Popliteus, I mut confes ecap't my notice. Sylvius tells us, in Apes, it agrees with Men. The ret of the Mucles of this part, which we eteem Proper to the Tibia, and arie from the Os Femoris, were much les than the Humane, as the Vatus Internus, (Fig. 3. 44.) Crureus, and Vatus externus.

The Mucles of the Tarus or Foot, agreed in Number and Situation with the Humane; but varied in their Figure. The Gaterocnemius externus (Fig. 4. 43.) had not o large a Belly, nor were it's Fibres o variouly dipoed; but it continued flehy much lower, than in Man. Sylvius tells us in Apes, Capita Gemellorum (meaning this Mucle) Oae Seamoidca habent, firmantia in Condylis Crus cum Tibia. The Plantaris differ'd not from that in Man. The Gaterocnemius internus, or oleus,
(Fig. 4. 44.) continued flehy to the Os Calcis, as Sylvius oberved it in Apes. The Tibialis Anticus (Fig. 3. 49.) was much larger, and continued flehy much lower, than in Man. Sylvius oberv'd an Os Seamoides in the Tendon of this Mucle in Apes. The Peroneus primus (Fig. 3. 51.) differ'd very little from that in Man; its Tendon having the ame progres in the Bottom of the Foot, to the Bone of the Metatarus of the Great Toe; which is nevertheles denied by Galen to be exitent in Man; for which Vealius, lib. 2. cap. 59. everely Cenures him. I have more than once, een a Boney body, placed in this Tendon at it's Flexure on the Os Cuboides in Humane Bodies: The like is taken notice of by Sylvius in an Ape. The Peroncus ecundus differ'd not from that in Man. The Tibialis Poticus (Fig. 4. 45.) was not o large as in Man.

The Mucles of the Great Toe differ'd from the Humane. The F •• enor Pollicis longus (Fig. 3. 52.) had a more Oblique progres, and was flehy lower. The Extenor Pollicis brevis (Fig. 3. 53.) was mu ••• arger, and it's progres on the Foot almot tranvere. The Flexor Po •• i • cis longus was pretty large. The Flexor Pollicis brevis (Fig. 4. 47.) was very large, and ineparably joined with the Abductor, which was very little. The Pariians tell us, The Great Toes of the Monkeys had Mucles like thoe, of a Ma • s Thumb. The Extenor Digitorum Pedis longus (Fig. 3.53.) had no Tendon implanted on the Os Metatari of the Little Toe. The Perforatus (Fig. 4. 46.) Perforans, (ib. 48.) Lumbricales, and Abductor Minimi Digiti, differ'd very little from thoe in Men. The Muculus Extenor Digitorum brevis, and Tranveralis Pedis did not appear in this Animal.

I hall not at preent give the Reader the trouble of the Reflections, that I intended, upon the Obervations made in the Anatomy of this remarkable Creature; ince I am concious (having been o tedious already) that 'twill but farther tire him, and my elf too. I hall therefore now conclude this Dicoure, with a brief Recapitulation of the Intances I have given, wherein our Pygmie, more reembled the Humane kind, than Apes and Monkeys do: As likewie um up thoe, wherein it differ'd from a Man, and imitated the Ape-kind. The Catalogues of both are o large, that they ufficiently evince, That our Pygmie is no Man, nor yet the Common Ape; but a ort of Animal between both; and tho' a Biped, yet of the Quadrumanus-kind; tho' ome Men too, have been oberved to ue their Feet like Hands, as I have een everal.

div.head: The Orang-Outang or Pygmie more reembled a Man, than Apes and Monkeys do.

list.item: 1. IN having the Hair of the Shoulder tending downwards; and that of the Arm, upwards.
2. In the Face 'twas liker a Man; having the Forehead larger, and the Rotrum or Chin horter.
3. In the outward Ear likewie except as to it's Cartilage, which was thinner as in Apes.
4. In the Fingers; which were much thicker than in Apes.
5. In being in all repects deigned by Nature, to walk erect; whereas Apes and Monkeys want a great many Advantages to do o.
6. The Nates or Buttocks larger than in the Ape-kind.
7. It had Calves in it's Legs.
8. The Shoulders and Breast were more pread.
9. The Heel was longer.
10. The Membrana Adipoa placed here, next to the Skin.
11. The Peritonaeum in the Groin entire; and not perforated, or protruded, as in Apes and Monkeys.
12. The Intetines or Guts much longer.
13. The Intetines being very different in their bignes, or largenes of their Canalis.
14. In having a Caecum or Appendicula Vermiformis, which Apes and Monkeys have not: and in not having the beginning of the Colon o projected or extended, as Apes and Monkeys have.
15. The Inertion of the Ductus Bilarius and the Ductus Pancreaticus in a Man, the Pygmie, and an Ape was at the ame Orifice. In a Monkey there was two Inches ditance.
16. The Colon was here longer.
17. The Liver not divided into Lobes, as in Apes and Monkeys; but entire, as in Man.
18. The Biliary Veels, the ame as in Man.
19. The Spleen the ame.
20. The Pancreas the ame.
21. The Number of the Lobes of the Lungs, the ame as a Man's.
22. The Pericardium fatened to the Diaphragm, as in Man; but is not o in Apes and Monkeys.
23. The Cone of the Heart, not o pointed, as in Apes.
24. It had not thoe Pouches in the Chaps, as Apes and Monkeys have.
25. The Brain was abundantly larger than in Apes; and all it's Parts exactly formed like the Humane Brain.
26. The Cranium more globous; and twice as big as an Ape's or Monkey's.
27. All the Sutures here, like the Humane: And in the Lambdoidal uture were the Oa triquetra Wormiana. In Apes and Monkeys 'tis otherwie,
28. It had an Os Cribriforme, and the Crita Galli; which Monkeys have not.
29. The Sella Equina here, the ame as in Man; in the Ape-kind 'tis more riing and eminent.
30. The Proceus Pterygoides, as in Man: In Apes and Monkeys they are wanting.
31. The Oa Bregmatis and Temporum here the ame as in Man. In Monkeys they are different.
32. The Os Zygomaticum in the Pygmie was mall; in the Monkey and Apes 'tis bigger.
33. The Shape of the Teeth more reembled the Humane, epecially the Dentes Canini and Molares.
34. The Tranvere Apophyes of the Vertebrae of the Neck, and the Sixth and Seventh Vertebra, were liker the Humane, than thee Parts in Apes and Monkeys are.
35. The Vertebrae of the Neck had not thoe Foramina for tranmitting the Nerves; which Apes have and Man has not.
36. The Vertebrae of the Back, and their Apophyes Rectae like the Humane: and in the lower Vertebrae but two Apophyes infernae; not four, as in Apes.
37. There were but five Vertebrae of the Loins here, as in Man: in Apes and Monkeys there are ix.
38. The Spines of the Lumbal Vertebrae trait, as in Man.
39. The Os Sacrum was compoed of five Vertebrae, as in Man: in Apes and Monkeys there are but three Vertebrae.
40. The Os Coccygis had but four Bones, and thee not perforated, as 'tis in Man: In Monkeys there are more Bones, and they are perforated.

41. In the Pygmie there were but even Cotae verae; and the Extreams of the Nothae were Cartilaginous; and the Ribs were articulated to the body of the Vertebrae. In Apes and Monkeys there are eight Cotae verae; and the Extreams of the Nothae are oious; and the Articulation is in the Intertices of the Vertebrae.
42. The Os Sterni in the Pygmie was broad, as in a Man: in the Monkey 'tis narrow.
43. The Bones of the four Fingers much larger than in the Ape-kind.
44. The Thigh-bone in it's Articulation, and all other repects, like the Humane.
45. The Patella round, not long; ingle, not double; as 'tis aid to be in Apes.
46. In the Heel, the Tarus, and Metatarus, the Pygmie was like a Man.
47. The middle Toe in the Pygmie was not the longet, as 'tis in the Ape-kind.

48. Thee Mucles, viz. The Obliquus Inferior Capitis, the Pyriformis and Biceps Femoris, were like the Humane; whereas the ame in Apes and Monkeys are different. And Note, That all the other Mucles that are not otherwie pecified in the following Catalogue, were like the Humane alo; but whether all the ame Mucles in Apes and Monkeys reemble the Humane, Could not be determined, for want of a Subject to compare them with, or Obervations made by others.

div.head: The Orang-Outang or Pygmie differ'd from a Man, and reembled more the Ape and Monkey-kind.

list.item: 1. IN the littlenes of it's Stature.
2. In the flatnes of the Noe and the lit in the Alae Narium.
3. In having a riing Ridge of the Cranium under the Eye-brows.
4. In being more hairy behind, than before.
5. In having the Thumb o little, tho' larger than in the Ape-kind.
6. In having the Palm of the Hand longer and narrower.
7. In the length of the Toes.
8. In having the Great Toe et at a ditance from the other, like a Thumb; and being Quadrumanus, like the Ape-kind.
9. In having the Shoulder and Thigh horter.
10. In having the Arms longer.
11. In having no pendulous Scrotum.
12. In the largenes of the Omentum.
13. The Gall-Bladder long and lender.
14. The Kidneys rounder than in Men; and the Tubuli rinarij different.
15. The Bladder of rine longer.
16. In having no Fraenum to the Praeputium.
17. In having the Bony Orbit of the Eye o much protruded inwards, towards the Brain.
18. It had not thoe two Cavities under the Sella Turcica, as in Man.
19. The Proceus Matoides and Styloides very mall, almot wanting.
20. The Bones of the Noe flat.
21. In the Number of the Teeth, it reembled the Ape-kind.
22. The Vertebrae of the Neck, hort as in the Ape-kind and flat before, not round; and their Spines, not bifide, as in Man.
23. In the firt Vertebra of the Neck; there was no Spine.
24. In an Ape the Tenth Vertebra of the Back; in a Man the Twelfth; in the Pygmie the Thirteenth Vertebra, infra • prave ucipitur.
25. The Os Sacrum altogether like the Ape-kind, only in the number of the Vertebrae.
26. In having Thirteen Ribs on a ide: a Man has but Twelve.
27. The Bone of the Thumb but mall.
28. The Os Ilium perfectly like the Ape-kind; being longer, narrower, and not o Concave as in Man.
29. The Bones of the Toes in their length, and the Great Toe in it's Structure imitated the Ape-kind.

30. Thee Mucles were wanting in the Pygmie, which are always found in Men; viz. Occipitales, Frontales, Dilatatores Alarum Nat, eu Elevatores Labij Superioris, Interpinales Colli, Glutaei minimi, Extenor Digitorum Pedis brevis, and Tranveralis Pedis.

31. Thee Mucles did not appear in the Pygmie, and are ometimes wanting too in Humane Bodies; viz. Pyramidales; Caro muculoa Quadrata; the long Tendon and flehy Belly of the Palmaris; Attollens Auriculam; and Retrahens Auriculam.
32. The Elevatores Clavicularum are in the Pygmie and the Ape-kind, and not in Man.

33. Thee Mucles reembled thoe in Apes and Monkeys, and differ'd from the Humane, viz. Longus Colli, Pectoralis, Latiimus Dori Glutaeus maximus & medius, Poas magnus & parvus, Iliacus internus, and the Gaterocnemius internus.
34. Thee Mucles differ'd likewie from the Humane, viz. the Deltoides; the Pronator Radij teres; the Extenor Pollicis brevis.

div.head: Figure the Firt
div.p:
REpreents the Fore-parts of the Orang-Outang or Pygmie, in an Erect Poture: Where you may oberve the largenes of the Head; and broadnes of the Forehead; the jutting out of the Eye-brows; the Eyes omewhat unk; the Noe flat; the Face without hair and wrinkled; the Teeth like the Humane; the Chin hort; the Ears tanding off from the Head; the Head hairy; the Shoulders pread and large; the Arms and Palms of the Hands long; the Nails like thoe in a Man; the Hair of the Shoulder inclining downwards, and that on the Arms, upwards; the Fingers large; the Thumb little; the Breat full cheted and pread; the Mammae or Teats placed as in Man; the Belly flat; the Navil as in Man; the Penis half-way covered with the Prepuce, which had no Fraenum; no pendulous Scrotum here; the Thighs a little divaricated; the
Legs long and with Calves; the Foot like a Hand, having long Toes, and the Great Toe placed at a ditance from the others, like a Thumb; the Feet, Hands, Face, Ears, and Penis without Hair; and all the Foreparts of the Body rather les hairy than here repreented; and the Head is too much hrunk down between the Shoulders.

div.head: The Second Figure
div.p: REpreents the Hinder Parts of the Pygmie in an Erect Poture likewie; where may be oberved the Globous Figure of the Head; the traitnes of the Back; and that 'tis more hairy behind, than before; the Fingers of the right Hand are repreented bending, to hew the Action, when, it goes on all four; for then it places only the Knuckles, not the Palms of the Hands to the Ground. The Sole of the left Foot, by reaon of the length of the Toes, and the etting on of the Great Toe, looks like the Palm of the Hand: but the right, having o long a Heel, and its Toes being hid, appears rather like a Foot, and upon occaion performs the Office of both, either of a Foot or Hand. A little above the Anus, there is a black Spot, which repreents a mall Protuberance of the Os Coccygis.

div.p: A PHILOLOGICAL ESSAY Concerning the PYGMIES, THE CYNOCEPHALI, THE SATYRS and SPHINGES OF THE ANCIENTS,
Wherein it will appear that they were all either APES or MONKEYS; and not MEN, as formerly pretended.
By Edward Tyon M. D.

div.head: A Philological Eay Concerning the PYGMIES OF THE ANCIENTS.
div.p: HAVING had the Opportunity of Diecting this remarkable Creature, which not only in the outward hape of the Body, but likewie in the tructure of many of the Inward Parts, o nearly reembles a Man, as plainly appears by the Anatomy I have here given of it, it uggeted the Thought to me, whether this ort of Animal, might not give the Foundation to the Stories of the Pygmies? and atord an occaion not only to the Poets, but Hitorians too, of inventing the many Fables and wonderful and merry Relations, that are tranmitted down to us concerning them? I mut cones, I could never before entertain any other Opinion about them, but that the whole was a Fiction: and as the firt Account we have of them, was from a Poet, o that they were only a Creature of the Brain, produced by a warm and wanton Imagination, and that they never had any Exitence or Habitation elewhere.

In this Opinion I was the more confirmed, becaue the mot diligent Enquiries of late into all the Parts of the inhabited World, could never dicover any uch Puny diminutive Race of Mankind. That they hould be totally detroyed by the Cranes, their Enemies, and not a Straggler here and there left remaining, was a Fate, that even thoe Animals that are contantly preyed upon by others, never undergo. Nothing therefore appeared to me more Fabulous and Romantick, than their Hitory, and the Relations about them, that Antiquity has delivered to us. And
not only Strabo of old, but our greatet Men of Learning of late, have wholly exploded them, as a meer igment; invented only to amu •• and divert the Reader with the Comical Narration of their Atchievements, believing that there were never any uch Creatures in Nature.

This Opinion had o fully obtained with me, that I never thought it worth the Enquiry, how they came to invent uch Extravagant Stories: Nor hould I now, but upon the Occaion of Diecting this Animal: For oberving that 'tis call'd even to this day in the Indian or Malabar Language, Orang-Outang, i.e. a Man of the Woods, or Wild-men; and being brought from Africa, that part of the World, where the Pygmies are aid to inhabit; and it's preent Stature likewie tallying o well with that of the Pygmies of the Ancients; thee Coniderations put me upon the earch, to inform my elf farther about them, and to examine, whether I could meet with any thing that might illutrate their Hitory. For I thought it trange, that if the whole was but a meer Fiction, that o many ucceeding Generations hould be o fond of preerving a Story, that had no Foundation at all in Nature; and that the Ancients hould trouble themelves o much about them. If therefore I can make out in this Eay, that there were uch Animals as Pygmies; and that they were not a Race of Men, but Apes; and can dicover the Authors, who have forged all, or mot of the idle Stories concerning them; and hew, how the Cheat in after Ages has been carried on, by embalming the Bodies of Apes, then expoing them for the Men of the Country, from whence they brought them: if I can do this, I hall think my time not wholly lot, nor the trouble altogether ueles, that I have had in this Enquiry.

My Deign is not to jutifie all the Relations that have been given of this Animal, even by Authors of reputed Credit; but, as far as I can, to ditinguih Truth from Fable; and herein, if what I aert amounts to a Probability, 'tis all I pretend to. I hall accordingly endeavour to make it appear, that not only the Pygmies of the Ancients, but alo the Cynocephali, and Satyrs and Sphinges were only Apes or Monkeys, not Men, as they have been repreented. But the Story of the Pygmies being the greatet Impoture, I hall chiefly concern my elf about them, and hall be more concie on the others, ince they will not need o trict an Examination.

We will begin with the Poet Homer, who is generally owned as the firt Inventor of the Fable of the Pygmies, if it be a Fable, and not a true Story, as I believe will appear in the Account I hall give of them. Now Homer only mentions them in a Simile, wherein he compares the Shouts that the Trojans made, when they were going to joyn Battle with the Graecians, to the great Noie of the Cranes, going to fight the Pygmies: he faith Homer. Iliad. lib. 3. ver. 4.,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet > . i. e.
Quae imul ac fugere Imbres, Hyememque Nivalem
Cum magno Oceani clangore ferantur ad undas
Pygmaeis pugnamque Viris, caedeque ferentes.

Or as Helius Eobanus Heus paraphraes the whole Homeri Ilias Latino Carmine reddita ab Helio Ecbano Heo..
Potquam ub Ducibus digeta per agmina tabant
Quaeque uis, Equitum turmae, Peditumque Cohortes,
Obvia torquentes Danais vetigia Troës
Ibant, ublato Campum clamore replentes:
Non ecus ac cuneata Gruum ublime volantum
Agmina, dum fugiunt Imbres, ac rigora Brumae,
Per Coelum matutino clangore feruntur,
Oceanumque petunt, mortem exitiumque cruentum
Irrita Pigmaeis moturis arma ferentes.

By < in non-Latin alphabet > therefore, which is the Paage upon which they have grounded all their fabulous Relations of the Pygmies, why may not Homer mean only Pygmies or Apes like Men. Such an Expreion is very allowable in a Poet, and is elegant and ignificant, epecially ince there is o good a Foundation in Nature for him to ue it, as we have already een, in the Anatomy of the Orang-Outang. Nor is a Poet tied to that trictnes of Expreion, as an Hitorian or Philoopher; he has the liberty of pleaing the Reader's Phancy, by Pictures and Repreentations of his own. If there be a becoming likenes, 'tis all that he is accountable for. I might therefore here make the ame Apology for him, as Strabo Strabo Geograph. lib. 1. p. m. 25. do's on another account for his Geography,
< in non-Latin alphabet > , That he aid it, not thro' Ignorance, but to pleae and delight: Or, as in another place he exprees himelf Strabo ibid. p. m. 30., < in non-Latin alphabet > . Homer did not make this lip thro' Ignorance of the true Hitory, but for the Beauty of his Poem. So that tho' he calls them Men Pygmies, yet he may mean no more by it, than that they were like Men. As to his Purpoe, 'twill erve altogether as well, whether this bloody Battle be fought between the Cranes and Pygmaean Men, or the Cranes and Apes, which from their Stature he calls Pygmies, and from their hape Men; provided that when the Cranes go to engage, they make a mighty terrible noie, and clang enough to fright thee little Wights their mortal Enemies. To have called them only Apes, had been
flat and low, and leened the grandieur of the Battle. But this Periphrais of them, < in non-Latin alphabet > , raies the Reader's Phancy, and urpries him, and is more becoming the Language of an Heroic Poem.

But how came the Cranes and Pygmies to fall out? What may be the Caue of this Mortal Feud, and contant War between them? For Brutes, like Men, don't war upon one another, to raie and encreae their Glory, or to enlarge their Empire. Unles I can acquit my elf herein, and aign ome probable Caue hereof, I may incur the ame Cenure as Strabo Strabo Geograph. lib. 2. p. m. 48. paed on everal of the Indian Hitorians,
< in non-Latin alphabet > , for reviewing the Homerical Fight of the Cranes and Pygmies, which he looks upon only as a fiction of the Poet. But this had been very unbecoming Homer to take a Simile (which is deigned for illutration) from what had no Foundation in Nature. His Betrachomyomachia, 'tis true, was a meer Invention, and never otherwie eteemed: But his Geranomachia hath all the likelyhood of a true Story. And therefore I hall enquire now what may be the jut Occaion of this Quarrel.

Athenaeus Athenaei Deipnooph. lib. 9. p. m. 393. out of Philochorus, and o likewie AElian AElian. Hit. Animal. lib. 15. cap. 29., tell us a Story, That in the Nation of the Pygmies the Male-line failing, one Gerana was their Queen; a Woman of an admired Beauty, and whom the Citizens worhipped as a Goddes; but he became o vain and proud, as to prefer her own, before the Beauty of all the other Goddees, at which they grew enraged; and to punih her for her Inolence, Athenaeus tells us that 'twas Diana, but AElian aith 'twas Juno that transformed her into a Crane, and made her an Enemy to the Pygmies that worhipped her before. But ince they are not agreed which Goddes 'twas, I hall let this pas.

Pomponius Mela will have it, and I think ome others, that thee cruel Engagements ue to happen, upon the Cranes coming to devour the Corn the Pygmies had owed; and that at lat they became o victorious, as not only to detroy their Corn, but them alo: For he tells us Pomp. Mela de itu Orbis, lib. 3. cap. 8., Fuere interiùs Pygmaei, minutum genus, & quod pro atis frugibus contra Grues dimicando, defecit. This may eem a reaonable Caue of a Quarrel; but it not being certain that the Pygmies ued to ow Corn, I will not init on this neither.

Now what eems mot likely to me, is the account that Pliny out of Megatheues, and Strabo from Oneicritus give us; and, provided I be not obliged to believe or jutifie all that they ay, I could ret atisfied in great part of their Relation: For Pliny Plinij Hit. Nat. lib. 7. cap. 2. p. m. 13 tells us, Veris tempore univero
agmine ad mare decendere, & Ova, Pulloque earum Alitum conumere: That in the Spring-time the whole drove of the Pygmies go down to the Sea ide, to devour the Cranes Eggs and their young Ones. So likewie Oneicritus Strab. Geograph. lib. 15. pag. 489.
< in non-Latin alphabet > i.e. That there is a fight between the Pygmies and the Cranes (as Homer relates) and the Partridges, which are as big as Geee; for thee Pygmies gather up their Eggs, and detroy them; the Cranes laying their Eggs there; and neither their Eggs, nor their Nets, being to be found any where ele. 'Tis plain therefore from them, that the Quarrel is not out of any Antipathy the Pygmies have to the Cranes, but out of love to their own Bellies. But the Cranes finding their Nets to be robb'd, and their young Ones prey'd on by thee Invaders, no wonder that they hould o harply engage them; and the leat they could do, was to fight to the utmot o mortal an Enemy. Hence, no doubt, many a bloody Battle happens, with various ucces to the Combatants; ometimes with great laughter of the long-necked Squadron; ometimes with great effuion of Pygmaean blood. And this may well enough, in a Poet's phancy, be magnified, and repreented as a dreadful War; and no doubt of it, were one a Spectator of it, 'twould be diverting enough.
— Si videas hoc
Gentibus in notris, riu quatiere: ed illic,
Quanquam eadem aiduè pectantur Proelia, ridet
Nemo, ubi tota cohors pede non est altior uno Juvenal. Satyr. 13. ver. 170..

This Account therefore of thee Campaigns renewed every year on this Provocation between the Cranes and the Pygmies, contains nothing but what a cautious Man may believe; and Homer's Simile in likening the great houts of the Trojans to the Noie of the Cranes, and the Silence of the Greeks to that of the Pygmies, is very admirable and delightful. For Aritotle Aritotle. Hit. Animal. lib. 8. cap. 15. Edit. Scalig. tell us, That the Cranes, to avoid the hardhips of the Winter, take a Flight out of Scythia to the Lakes about the Nile, where the Pygmies live, and where 'tis very likely the Cranes may lay their Eggs and breed, before they return. But thee rude Pygmies making too bold with them, what could the Cranes do les for preerving their Off-pring than fight them; or at leat by their mighty Noie, make a hew as if they would. This is but what we may oberve in all other Birds. And thus far I think our Geranomachia or Pygmaeomachia looks like a true Story; and there is nothing in Homer about it, but what is credible. He only exprees himelf, as a Poet hould do; and if Readers will mitake his meaning, 'tis not his fault.

'Tis not therefore the Poet that is to be blamed, tho' they would father it all on him; but the fabulous Hitorians in after Ages, who have o odly dret up this Story by their fantatical Inventions, that there is no knowing the truth, till one hath pull'd off thoe Masks and Viages, wherewith they have diguied it. For tho' I can believe Homer, that there is a fight between the Cranes and Pygmies, yet I think I am no ways obliged to imagine, that when the Pygmies go to thee Campaigns to fight the Cranes, that they ride upon Partridges, as Athenaeus from Bailis an Indian Hitorian tells us; for, aith he Arhenaei Diepn • oph. lib. p. 9. m. 390., < in non-Latin alphabet > . For preently afterwards he tells us from Menecles, that the Pygmies not only fight the Cranes, but the Partridges too, < in non-Latin alphabet > . This I could more readily agree to, becaue Oneicritus, as I have quoted him already confirms it; and gives us the ame reaon for this, as for ighting the Cranes, becaue they rob their Nets. But whether thee Partridges are as big as Geee, I leave as a Quaere.

Megathenes methinks in Pliny mounts the Pygmies for this Expedition much better, for he ets them not on a Pegaus or Partridges, but on Rams and Goats: Fama est (aith Pliny Plinij Nat. Hit. lib. 7. cap. 2. p. 13.) inedentes Arietum Caprarumque doris, armatis agittis, veris tempore univero agmine ad mare decendere. And Oneicritus in Strabo tells us, That a Crane has been often oberved to fly from thoe parts with a bras Sword fixt in him, < in non-Latin alphabet >
Strabo Geograph. lib. 15. p. 489.. But whether the Pygmies do wear Swords, may be doubted. 'Tis true, Cteias tells us Vide Photij Biblioth., That the King of India every fifth year ends fifty Thouand Swords, beides abundance of other Weapons, to the Nation of the Cynocephali, (a ort of Monkeys, as I hall hew) that live in thoe Countreys, but higher up in the Mountains: But he makes no mention of any uch Preents to the poor Pygmies; tho' he aures us, that no les than three Thouand of thee Pygmies are the King's contant Guards: But withal tells us, that they are excellent Archers, and o perhaps by dipatching their Enemies at a ditance, they may have no need of uch Weapons to lye dangling by their ides. I may therefore be mitaken in rendering < in non-Latin alphabet > a Sword; it may be any other harp pointed Intrument or Weapon, and upon econd Thoughts, hall uppoe it a ort of Arrow thee cunning Archers ue in thee Engagements.

Thee, and a hundred uch ridiculous Fables, have the Hitorians invented of the Pygmies, that I can't but be of Strabo's mind Strabo Geograph. lib. 11. p. m. 350.
< in non-Latin alphabet > i.e. That one may ooner believe Heiod, and Homer, and the Tragick Poets peaking of their
Hero's, than Cteias and Herodotus and Hellanicus, and uch like. So ill an Opinion had Strabo of the Indian Hitorians in general, that he cenures them all as fabulous Strabo ibid. lib. 2. p. m. 48.; < in non-Latin alphabet > i.e. All who have wrote of India, for the most part, are fabulous, but in the highest degree Daimachus; then Megathenes, Oneicritus, and Nearchus, and uch like. And as if it had been their greatet Ambition to excel herein, Strabo Strabo ibid. lib. 1. p. m. 29. brings in Theopompus, as bragging, < in non-Latin alphabet >
That he could foist in Fables into Hitory, better than Herodotus and Cteias and Hellanicus, and all that have wrote of India. The Satyrist therefore had reaon to ay,
-Et quicquid Graecia mendax
Audet in Hitoria Juvenal, Satyr. X. ver • 174..

Aritotle Aritotle Hit. Animal. lib. 8. cap. 28. 'tis true, tells us, < in non-Latin alphabet > i.e. That generally the Beats are wilder in Aia, tronger in Europe, and of greater variety of hapes in Africa; for as the Proverb aith, Africa always produces omething new. Pliny Plin. Nat. Hit. lib. 6. cap. 30. p. m. 741. indeed acribes it to the Heat of the Climate, Animalium, Hominumque effigies montriferas, circa extremitates ejus gigni, minimè mirum, artifici ad formanda Corpora, effigieque caelandas mobilitate igneâ. But Nature never formed a whole Species of Monters; and 'tis not the heat of the Country, but the warm and fertile Imagination of thee Hitorians, that has been more productive of them, than Africa it elf; as will father appear by what I hall produce out of them, and particularly from the Relation that Cteias makes of the Pygmies.

I am the more willing to intance in Cteias, becaue he tells his Story roundly; he no ways minces it; his Invention is trong and fruitful; and that you may not in the leat mitrut him, he pawns his word, that all that he writes, is certainly true: And o uccesful he has been, how Romantick oever his Stories may appear, that they have been handed down to us by a great many other Authors, and of Note too; tho ome at the ame time have look'd upon them as meer Fables. So that for the preent, till I am better informed, and I am not over curious in it, I hall make Cteias, and the other Indian Hitorians, the Inventors of the extravagant Relations we at perent have of the Pygmies, and not old Homer. He calls them, 'tis true, from omething of Reemblance of their hape, < in non-Latin alphabet > : But thee Hitorians make them to peak the Indian Language; to ue the ame Laws; and to be o coniderable a Nation
and o valiant, as that the King of India makes choice of them for his Corps de Guards; which utterly poils Homer's Simile, in making them o little, as only to fight Cranes.
Cteias's Account therefore of the Pygmies (as I find it in Photius's Bibliotheca Photij Bibliothec. Cod. 72. p. m. 145., and at the latter end of ome Editions of Herodotus) is this:

q.p: Narrat praeter ita, in media India homines reperiri nigros, qui Pygmaei appellentur. Eadem hos, qua Inda reliqui, lingua uti, ed valde ee parvos, ut maximi duorum cubitorum, & plerique unius duntaxat cubiti cum dimidio altitudinem non excedant. Comam alere longiimam, ad ipa uque genua demiam, atque etiam infra, cum barba longiore, quàm apud ullos hominum. Quae quidem ubi illis promiior ee coeperit, nulla deinceps vete uti: ed capillos multò infra genua à tergo demios, barbámque praeter pectus ad pedes uque defluentem, per totum corpus in orbem contipare & cingere, atque ita pilos ipis uos vetimenti loco ee. Veretrum illis ee craum ac longum, quod ad ipos quoque pedum malleolos pertingat. Pygmeos hoce imis ee naribus, & deformes. Iporum item oves agnorum notrorum intar ee; boves & ainos, arietum ferè magnitudine, equos item multóque & caetera jumenta omnia nihilo ee notris arietibus majora. Tria horum Pygmaeorum millia Indorum regem in uo comitatu habere, quòd agittarij int peritiimi. Summos ee jutitiae cultores, iidémque quibus Indi reliqui, legibus parere. Venari quoque lepores vulpéque, non canibus, ed corvis, milvis, cornicibus, aquilis adhibitis.

In the middle of India (aith Cteias) there are black Men, they are call'd Pygmies, uing the ame Language, as the other Indians; they
are very little, the tallet of them being but two Cubits, and mot of them but a Cubit and a half high. They have very long hair, reaching down to their Knees and lower; and a Beard larger than any Man's. After their Beards are grown long, they wear no Cloaths, but the Hair of their Head falls behind a great deal below their Hams; and that of their Beards before comes down to their Feet: then laying their Hair thick all about their Body, they afterwards gird themelves, making ue of their Hair for Cloaths. They have a Penis o long, that it reaches to the Ancle, and the thicknes is proportionable. They are flat noed, and ill favoured. Their Sheep are like Lambs; and their Oxen and Aes carce as big as Rams; and their Hores and Mules, and all their other Cattle nor bigger. Three thouand Men of thee Pygmies do attend the King of India. They are good Archers; they are very jut, and ue the ame Laws as the Indians do. They kill Hares and Foxes, not with Dogs, but with Ravens, Kites, Crows, and Eagles.

div.p: Well, if they are o good Sports-men, as to kill Hares and Foxes with Ravens, Kites, Crows and Eagles, I can't ee how I can bring off Homer, for making them fight the Cranes themelves. Why did they not fly their Eagles againt them? thee would make greater Slaughter and Execution, without hazarding themelves. The only Excue I have is, that Homer's Pygmies were real Apes like Men; but thoe of Cteias were neither Men nor Pygmies; only a Creature begot in his own Brain, and to be found no where ele.

Cteias was Phyician to Artaxerxes Mnemon as Diodorus Siculus Diodor. Siculi Bibliothec. lib. 2. p. m. 118. and Strabo Strabo Geograph. lib. 14. p. 451. inform us. He was contemporary with Xenophon, a little later than Herodotus; and Helvicus in his Chronology places him three hundred eighty three years before Christ: He is an ancient Author, 'tis true, and it may be upon that core valued by ome. We are beholden to him, not only for his Improvements on the Story of the Pygmies, but for his Remarks likewie on everal other parts of Natural Hitory; which for the mot part are all of the ame tamp, very wonderful and incredible; as his Mantichora, his Gryphins, the horrible Indian Worm, a Fountain of Liquid Gold, a Fountain of Hon • y, a Fountain whoe Water will make a Man confes all that ever he did, a Root he calls < in non-Latin alphabet > , that will attract Lambs and Birds, as the Loadtone does filings of Steel; and a great many other Wonders he tells us: all which are copied from him by AElian, Pliny, Solinus, Mela, Philotratus and others. And Photius concludes Cteias's Account of India with this paage; < in non-Latin alphabet > i.e. Thee things (aith he) Cteias writes and feigns, but he
himelf ays all he has wrote is very true. Adding, that ome things which be decribes, he had een himelf; and the others, he had learn'd from thoe that had een them: That he had omitted a great many other things more wonderful, becaue he would not eem to thoe that have not een them, to write incredibilities. But notwithtanding all this, Lucian L •• ian lib. 1. verae Hitor. p. m. 373. will not believe a word he aith; for he tells us that Cteias has wrote of India, A < in non-Latin alphabet > , What he neither aw himelf, nor ever heard from any Body ele. And Aritotle tells us plainly, he is not fit to be believed: Ev < in non-Latin alphabet >
Arit. Hit. Animal. lib. 8. cap. 28.. And the ame Opinion A. Gellius A. Gellij Noctes Attic. lib. 9. cap. 4. eems to have of him, as he had likewie of everal other old Greek Hitorians which happened to fall into his hands at Brunduium, in his return from Greece into Italy; he gives this Character of them and their performance: Erant autem iti omnes libri Graeci, miraculorum fabularumque pleni: res inauditae, incredulae, Scriptores veteres non parvae authoritatis, Ariteas Proconneius, & Iagonus, & Nicaeenis, & Cteias, & Oneicritus, & Polytephanus, & Hegeias. Not that I think all that Cteias has wrote is fabulous; For tho' I cannot believe his peaking Pygmies, yet what he writes of the Bird he calls Bí •• oe
• that it would peak Greek and the Indian Language, no doubt is very true; and as H. Stephens Hen • . Stephani de Cteia Hitorico antiquiimo diquiitio, ad finem Herodoti. oberves in his Apology for Cteias, uch a Relation would eem very urpriing to one, that had never een nor heard of a Parrot.

But this Story of Cteias's peaking Pygmies, eems to be confirm'd by the Account that Nonnous, the Emperour Jutinian's Ambaador into AEthiopia, gives of his Travels. I will trancribe the Paage, as I find it in Photius Photij <>
ccd. 3. p. m. 7., and 'tis as follows:

q.p:
Naviganti à Phara Nonnoo, & ad extremam uque inularum delato, tale quid occurrit, vel ipo auditu admirandum. Incidit enim in quodam forma quidem & figura humana, ed breviimos, & cutem nigros, totúmque piloos corpus. Sequebantur viros aequales foeminae, & pueri adhuc breviores. Nudi omnes agunt, pelle tantum brevi adultiores verenda tecti, viri pariter ac foeminae: agrete nihil, neque efferum quid prae e ferentes. Quin & vox illis humana, ed omnibus, etiam accolis, prorus ignota lingua, multoque amplius Nonnoi ociis. Vivunt marinis otreis, & picibus è
è mari ad inulam projectis. Audaces minimè unt, ut notris conpectis hominibus, quemadmodum nos via ingenti fera, metu perculi fuerint.

That Nonnous ailing from Phara, when he came to the farthermot of the Ilands, a thing, very trange to be heard of, happened to him; for he lighted on ome (Animals) in hape and appearance like Men, but little of tature, and of a black colour, and thick covered with hair all over their Bodies. The Women, who were of the ame tature, foolowed the Men: They were all naked, only the Elder of them, both Men and Women, covered their Privy Parts with a mall Skin. They eemed not at all fierce or wild; they had a Humane Voice, but their Dialect was altogether unknown to every Body that lived about them; much more to thoe that were with Nonnous. They liv'd upon Sea Oyters, and Fih that were cat out of the Sea, upon the Iland. They had no Courage; for eeing our Men, they were frighted, as we are at the ight of the greatet wild Beat.

div.p: < in non-Latin alphabet > I render here, they had a Humane Voice, not Speech: for had they poke any Language, tho' their Dialect might be omewhat different, yet no doubt but ome of the Neighbourhood would have undertood omething of it, and not have been uch utter Strangers to it. Now 'twas oberved of the Orang-Outang, that it's Voice was like the Humane, and it would make a Noie like a Child, but never was oberved to peak, tho' it had the Organs of Speech exactly formed as they are in Man; and no Account that ever has been given of this Animal do's pretend that ever it did. I hould rather agree to what Pliny Plinij Nat. Hit. lib. 6. cap. 30. p. m. 741. mentions, Quibudam pro Sermone nutus motuque Membrorum et and that they had no more a Speech, than Cteias his Cynocephali which could only bark, as the ame Pliny Plinij Nat. Hit. lib. 7. cap. 2. p. m. 11. remarks; where he aith, In multis autem Montibus Genus Hominum Capitibus Caninis, ferarum pellibus velari, pro voce latratum edere, unguibus armatum venatu & Aucupio veci, horum upra Centum viginti Millia fuie prodente e Cteias cribit. But in Photius I find, that Cteias's Cynocephali did peak the Indian Language as well as the Pygmies. Thoe therefore in Nonnous ince they did not peak the Indian, I doubt, opke no Language at all; or at leat, no more than other Brutes do.

Cteias I find is the only Author that ever undertood what Language 'twas that the Pygmies pake: For Herodotus Herodot. in Melpomene. pag. 283. owns that they ue a ort of Tongue like to no other, but creech like Bats. He aith,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet > i.e. Thee Garamantes hunt the Troglodyte AEthiopians in Chariots with four Hores. The Troglodyte AEthiopians are the wiftest of foot of all Men that ever he heard of by any Report. The Troglodytes eat Serpents and Lizards, and uch fort of Reptiles. They ue a Language like to no other Tongue, but creech like Bats.

Now that the Pygmies are Troglodytes, or do live in Caves, is plain from Aritotle Arit. Hit. Animal. lib. 8. cap. 15. p. m. 913., who aith, < in non-Latin alphabet > . And o Philetratus Philotrat in vita Apollon. Tyanaei, lib. 3. cap. 14. p. m. 152.
< in non-Latin alphabet > . And methinks Le Compte's Relation concerning the wild or avage Man in Barneo, agrees o well with this, that I hall trancribe it: for he tells us, Lewis le Compte Memoirs and Obervations on China, p. m. 510. That in Borneo this wild or avage Man is indued with extraordinary trength; and notwithtanding he walks but upon two Legs, yet he is o wift of foot, that they have much ado to outrum him. People of Quality coure him, as we do Stags here: and this ort of hunting is the King's uual divertiement. And Gaendus in the Life of Peiresky, tells us they commonly hunt them too in Angola in Africa, as I have already mentioned. So that very likely Herodotus's Troglodyte AEthiopians may be no other than our Orang-Outang or wild Man. And the rather, becaue I fancy their Language is much the ame: for an Ape will chatter, and make a noie like a Bat, as his Troglodytes did: And they undergo to this day the ame Fate of being hunted, as formerly the Troglodytes ued to be by the Garamantes.

Whether thoe < in non-Latin alphabet > which the Naamones met with (as Herodotus Hcrodotus in Euterpe eu lib. 2. p. m. 102. relates) in their Travels to dicover Libya, were the Pygmies; I will not determine: It eems the Naamones neither undertood their Language, nor they that of the Naamones. However, they were o kind to the Naamones as to be their Guides along the Lakes, and afterwards brought them to a City, < in non-Latin alphabet > i.e. in which all were of the ame tature with the Guides, and black. Now ince they were all little black Men, and their Language could not be undertood, I do upect they may be a Colony of the Pygmies: And that they were no farther Guides to the Naamones, than that being frighted at the ight of them, they ran home, and the Naamones followed them.

I do not find therefore any good Authority, unles you will reckon Cteias as uch, that the Pygmies ever ued a Language or Speech, any
more than other Brutes of the ame Species do among themelves, and what we know nothing of, whatever Democritus and Melampodes in Pliny Plnij Nat. Hit. lib. 10. cap. 49., or Apollonius Tyanaeus in Porphyry Porphyrius de Abtinentia, lib. 3. pag.m. 103. might formerly have done. Had the Pygmies ever poke any Language intelligible by Mankind, this might have furnihed our Hitorians with notable Subjects for their Novels; and no doubt but we hould have had plenty of them.

But Albertus Magnus, who was o lucky as to gues that the Pygmies were a ort of Apes; that he hould afterwards make thee Apes to peak, was very unfortunate, and poiled all; and he do's it, methinks, o very awkardly, that it is as difficult almot to undertand his Language as his Apes; if the Reader has a mind to attempt it, he will find it in the Margin Si qui Homines unt Silvetres, icut Pygmeus, non ecundum unam rationem nobicum dicti unt Homines, ed aliquod habent Hominis in quadam deliberatione & Loquela, &c. A little after adds, Voces quaedam (c. Animalia) formant ad diveros conceptus quos habent, icut Homo & Pygmaeus; & quaedam non faciunt hoc, icut multitudo fere tota aliorum Animalium. Adhuc autem eorum quae e • ratione cogitativa formant voces, quaedam unt uccumbentia, quaedam autem non uccumbentia. Dico autem uccumbenti • , à conceptu Animae cadentia & mota ad Narurae Intinctum, icut Pygmeus, qui non, euqitur rationem Loquelae ed Naturae Intinctum; Homo autem non uccumbit ed equitur rationem. Albert. Magn. de Animal. lib 1. cap. 3. p.m. 3..

Had Albertus only aerted, that the Pygmies were a ort of Apes, his Opinion poibly might have obtained with les difficulty, unles he could have produced ome body that had heard them talk. But lyes Aldrovandus
ly. Aldrovandi Ornitholeg. lib. 20. p.m. 344. is o far from believing his Ape Pygmies ever poke, that he utterly denys, that there were ever any uch Creatures in being, as the Pygmies, at all; or that they ever fought the Cranes. Cum itaque Pygmaeos (aith he) dari negemus, Grues etiam cum iis Bellum gerere, ut fabulantur, negabimus, & tam pertinaciter id negabimus, ut ne jurantibus credemus.

I find a great many very Learned Men are of this Opinion: And in the firt place, Strabo Strabo Geograph. lib. 17. p. m. 565. is very poitive; < in non-Latin alphabet > i.e. No Man worthy of belief did ever ee them. And upon all occaions he declares the ame. So Julius Caear Scaliger Jul. Cae. Scaliger. Comment. in Arit. Hist. Animal. lib. 8. §. 126. p. m. 914. makes them to be only a Fiction of the Ancients, At haec omnia (aith he) Antiquorum igmenta & merae Nugae, i extarent, reperirentur. At cum univerus Orbis nunc nobis cognitus it, nullibi haec Naturae Excrement • reperiri certiimum est. And Iaac Caanbon Iaac Cauabo • Notae & Catigat. in lib. 1. Strabonis Geograph. p. m. 38. ridicules uch as pretend to jutiie them: Sic notra aetate (aith he) non deunt, qui eandem de Pygmaeis lepidam fabellam renovent; ut qui etiam è Sacris Literis, i Deo placet, fidem illis conentur atruere. Legi etiam Bergei cujudam Galli Scripta, qui e vidie diceret. At non ego credulus illi, illi inquam Omnium Bipedum mendaciimo. I hall add one Authority more, and that is of
Adrian Spigelius, who produces a Witnes that had examined the very place, where the Pygmies were aid to be; yet upon a diligent enquiry, he could neither find them, nor hear any tidings of them. Spigelius Adrian. Spigelij de Corporis Humani fabrica, lib. 1. cap. 7. p. m. 15. therefore tells us, Hoc loco de Pygmaeis dicendum erat, qui < in non-Latin alphabet > dicti à tatura, quae ulnam non excedunt. Verùm ego Poetarum fabulas ee crediderim, pro quibus tamen Aritoteles minimè haberi vult, ed veram ee Hitoriam. 8. Hit Animal. 12. aeverat. Ego quo minùs hoc tatuam, tum Authorilate primùm Doctiimi Strabonis 1. Geograph. coactus um, tum potiimùm nunc moveor, quod notro tempore, quo nulla Mundi pars et, quam Nautarum Indutria non perlutrarit, nihil tamen unquam imile aut vium est, aut anditum. Accedit quod Francicus Alvarez Luitanus, qui ea ipa loca peragravit, circa quae Aritoteles Pygmaeos ee cribit, nullibi tamen tam parvam Gentam à e conpectam tradidit, ed Populum ee Mediocris taturae, & AEthiopes tradit.

I think my elf therefore here obliged to make out, that there were uch Creatures as Pygmies, before I determine what they were, ince the very being of them is called in quetion, and utterly denied by o great Men, and by others too that might be here produced. Now in the doing this, Aritotle's Aertion of them is o very poitive, that I think there needs not a greater or better Proof; and it is o remarkable a one, that I find the very Enemies to this Opinion at a los, how to hift it off. To leen it's Authority they have interpolated the Text, by oiting into the Tranlation what is not in the Original; or by not tranlating at all the mot material poage, that makes againt them; or by mierably gloing it, to make him peak what he never intended: Such unfair dealings plainly argue, that at any rate they are willing to get rid of a Proof, that otherwie they can neither deny, or anwer.

Aritotle's Text is this, which I hall give with Theodorus Gaza's Tranlation: for dicouring of the Migration of Birds, according to the Seaon of the Year, from one Country to another, he aith Aritotel. Hit. Animal lib. 8. cap. 12.:

q.p:
Jam ab Autumnali AEquinoctio ex Ponto, Locique frigidis fugiunt Hyemem futuram. A Verno autem ex tepida Regione ad frigidam ee conferunt, aetûs metu futuri: & alia de locis vicinis dicedunt, alia de ultimis, prope dixerim, ut Grues faciunt, quae ex Scythicis Campis ad Paludes AEgypto uperiores, unde Nilus profluit, veniunt, quo in loeo pugnare cum Pygmaeis dicuntur. Non enim id
fabula est, ed certè, genus tum hominum, tum etiam Equorum putillum (ut dicitur) est, deguntque in Cavernis, unde Nomen Troglodytae à ubeundis Cavernis accepere.

In Englih 'tis thus: At the Autumnal AEquinox they go out of Pontus and the cold Countreys to avoid the Winter that is coming on. At the Vernal AEquinox they pas from hot Countreys into cold ones, for fear of the enuing Heat; ome making their Migrations from nearer places; others from the mot remote (as I may ay) as the Cranes do: for they come out of Scythia to the Lakes above AEgypt, whence the Nile do's flow. This is the place, whereabout the Pygmies dwell: For this is no Fable, but a Truth. Both they and the Hores, as 'tis aid, are a mall kind. They are Troglodytes, or live in Caves.

div.p: We may here oberve how poitive the Philoopher is, that there are Pygmies; he tells us where they dwell, and that 'tis no Fable, but a Truth. But Theodorus Gaza has been unjut in tranlating him, by foiting in,Quo in loco pugnare cum Pygmaeis dicuntur, whereas there is nothing in the Text that warrants it: As likewie, where he exprees the little Stature of the Pygmies and the Hores, there Gaza has rendered it, Sed certè Genus tum. Hominum, tum etiam Equorum puillum. Aritotle only aith, < in non-Latin alphabet > He neither makes his Pygmies Men, nor aith any thing of their fighting the Cranes; tho' here he had a fair occaion, dicouring of the Migration of the Cranes out of Scythia to the Lakes above AEgypt, where he tells us the Pygmies are. Cardan Cardan de Rerum varietate, lib. 8. cap. 40. p. m. 153. therefore mut certainly be out in his gues, that Aritotle only aerted the Pygmies out of Complement to his Friend Homer; for urely then he would not have forgot their fight with the Cranes; upon which occaion only Homer mentions them Apparet ergo (aith Cardan) Pygmaeorum Hitoriam ee fabuloam, quod & Strabo entit, & noird aetas, cum omnia nunc fermè orbis mirabilia innotuerint, declarat. Sed quod tantum Philoophum decepit, fuit Homeri Auctoritas non apudillum levis. I hould rather think that Aritotle, being enible of the many Fables that had been raied on this occaion, tudiouly avoided the mentioning this fight, that he might not give countenance to the Extravagant Relations that had been made of it.

But I wonder that neither Caaubon nor Duvall in their Editions of Aritotle's Works, hould have taken notice of thee Mitakes of Gaza, and corrected them. And Gener, and Aldrovandus, and everal other Learned Men, in quoting this place of Aritotle, do make ue of this faulty Tranlation, which mut necearily lead them into Mitakes, Sam. Bochartus Bocharti Hierozoic. S. de Animalib. S. Script. part. Poterior. lib. 1. cap. 11. p. m. 76. tho' he gives Aritotle's Text in Greek, and adds a new
Tranlation of it, he leaves out indeed the Cranes fighting with the Pygmies, yet makes them Men, which Aritotle do's not; and by anti-placing, it aiunt, he renders Aritotle's Aertion more dubious; Neque enim (aith he in the Tranlation)
• est fabula, ed reverâ, ut aiunt, Genus ibi parvum est tam Hominum quàm Equorum. Julius Caear Scaliger in tranlating this Text of Aritotle, omits both thee Interpretations of Gaza; but on the other hand, is no les to be blamed in not tranlating at all the mot remarkable paage, and where the Philoopher eems to be o much in earnet; as, < in non-Latin alphabet > , this he leaves wholly out, without giving us his reaon for it, if he had any: And Scaliger's Scaliger. Comment. in Arit. Hit. Animal. lib. 8. p. m. 914. ininuation in his Comment, viz. Negat ee fabulam de his (o. Pygmeis) Herodotus, at Philoophus emper moderatus & prudens ctiam addidit,
< in non-Latin alphabet > , is not to be allowed. Nor can I aent to Sir Thomas Brown's Sir Thomas Brouns Peudodoxia, or, Enquiries into Vulgar Errors, lib. 4. cap. 11. remark upon this place; Where indeed (aith he) Aritotle plays the Aritotle; that is, the wary and evading Aertor; for tho' with non et fabula he eems at firt to confirm it, yet at lat he claps in, icut aiunt, and hakes the belief he placed before upon it. And therefore Scaliger (aith he) hath not tranlated the first, perhaps uppoing it urreptitious, or unworthy o great an Aertor. But had Scaliger known it to be urreptitious, no doubt but he would have remarked it; and then there had been ome Colour for the Glos. But 'tis unworthy to be believed of Aritotle, who was o wary and cautious, that he hould in o hort a paage, contradict himelf; and after he had o poitively affirmed the Truth of it, preently doubt it. His < in non-Latin alphabet > therefore mut have a Reference to what follows, Puillum genus, ut aiunt, ipi atque etiam Equi, as Scaliger himelf tranlates it.

I do not here find Aritotle aerting or confirming any thing of the fabulous Narrations that had been made about the Pygmies. He does not ay that they were < in non-Latin alphabet > or < in non-Latin alphabet > or < in non-Latin alphabet > ; he only calls them < in non-Latin alphabet > . And dicouring of the Pygmies in a place, where he is only treating about Brutes, 'tis reaonable to think, that he looked upon them only as uch. This is the place where the Pygmies are; this is no able, aith Aritotle, as 'tis that they are a Dwarfih Race of Men; that they peak the Indian Language; that they are excellent Archers; that they are very Jut; and abundance of other Things that are fabulouly reported of them; and becaue he thought them Fables, he does not take the leat notice of them, but only aith, This is no Fable, but a Truth, that about the Lakes of Nile uch Animals, as are called Pygmies, do live. And, as if he had foreeen, that the abundance of Fables that Cteias (whom he aith is not to be believed) and the Indian Hitorians had invented about them, would make the whole Story to appear as a Figment, and render it doubtful, whether there were ever uch Creatures as Pygmies
in Nature; he more zealouly aerts the Being of them, and aures us, That this is no Fable, but a Truth.

I hall therefore now enquire what ort of Creatures thee Pygmies were; and hope, o to manage the Matter, as in a great meaure, to abate the Paion thee Great Men have had againt them: for, no doubt, what has incened them the mot, was, the fabulous Hitorians making them a part of Mankind, and then inventing a hundred ridiculous Stories about them, which they would impoe upon the World as real Truths. If therefore they have Satisfaction given them in thee two Points, I do not ee, but that the Buines may be accommodated very fairly; and that they may be allowed to be Pygmies, tho' we do not make them Men.

For I am not of Gener's mind, Sed veterum millus (aith he Gener. Hitor. Quadruped. p. m. 885.) aliter de Pygmaeis cripit, quàm Homunciones ee. Had they been a Race of Men, no doubt but Aritotle would have informed himelf farther about them. Such a Curioity could not but have excited his Inquiitive Genius, to a trictrer Enquiry and Examination; and we might eaily have expected from him a larger Account of them. But finding them, it may be, a ort of Apes, he only tells us, that in uch a place thee Pygmies live.

Herodotus Herodot. Melpomene eu lib. 4. p. m. 285. plainly makes them Brutes: For reckoning up the Animals of Libya, he tells us, < in non-Latin alphabet > (in the Margin 'tis < in non-Latin alphabet > ) < in non-Latin alphabet > i.e. That there are here prodigious large Serpents, and Lions, and Elephants, and Bears, and Aps, and Aes that have horns, and Cynocephali, (in the Margin 'tis Acephali) that have Eyes in their Breat, (as is reported by the Libyans) and wild Men, and wild Women, and a great many other wild Beats that are not fabulous. 'Tis evident therefore that Herodotus his < in non-Latin alphabet > are only < in non-Latin alphabet > or wild Beats; and tho' they are call'd < in non-Latin alphabet > , they are no more Men than our Orang-Outang, or Homo Sylvetris, or wild Man, which has exactly the ame Name, and I mut cones I can't but think is the ame Animal: and that the ame Name has been continued down to us, from his Time, and it may be from Homer's.

So Philotratus peaking of AEthiopia and AEgypt, tells us Philotratus in vita Apollon. Tyanaei, lib. 6. cap. 1. p. m. 258., < in non-Latin alphabet > i. e. Here are bred wild Beats that are not in other places; and black Men, which no other Country affords:
and amongt them is the Nation of the Pygmies, and the BARKERS, that is, the Cynocephali. For tho' Philotratus is pleaed here only to call them Barkers, and to reckon them, as he does the Black Men and the Pygmies amongt the wild Beats of thoe Countreys; yet Cteias, from whom Philotratus has borrowed a great deal of his Natural Hitory, tiles them Men, and makes them peak, and to perform mot notable Feats in Merchandiing. But not being in a merry Humour it may be now, before he was aware, he peaks Truth: For Caelius Rhodiginus's Caelij Rhadigini Lection. Antiq. lib. 17. cap. 13. Character of him is, Philotratus omnium qui unquam Hitoriam concriperunt, mendaciimus.

Since the Pygmies therefore are ome of the Brute Beats that naturally breed in thee Countries, and they are pleaed to let us know as much, I can eaily excue them a Name. < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Orang-Outang, is alike to me; and I am better pleaed with Homer's < in non-Latin alphabet > than if he had called < in non-Latin alphabet > . Had this been the only Intance where they had miapplied the Name of Man, methinks I could be o good natur'd, as in ome meaure to make an Apology for them. But inding them o extravagantly looe, o wretehedly whimical, in abuing the Dignity of Mankind, by giving the Name of Man to uch montrous Productions of their idle Imaginations, as the Indian Hitorians have done, I do not wonder that wie Men have upected all that comes out of their Mint, to be fale and counterfeit.

Such are their' < in non-Latin alphabet > or < in non-Latin alphabet > , that want Noes, and have only two holes above their Mouth; they eat all things, but they mut be raw; they are hort lived; the upper part of their Mouths is very prominent. The < in non-Latin alphabet > whoe Ears reach down to their Heels, on which they lye and leep. The < in non-Latin alphabet > , that have no Mouths, a civil ort of People, that dwell about the Head of the Ganges; and live upon melling to boil'd Meats and the Odours of Fruits and Flowers; they can bear no ill cent, and therefore can't live in a Camp. The < in non-Latin alphabet > or < in non-Latin alphabet > that have but one Eye, and that in the middle of their Foreheads; they have Dogs Ears; their Hair tands an end, but mooth on the Breats. The < in non-Latin alphabet > , that have Eyes in their Breats. The < in non-Latin alphabet > with Heads like Wedges. The < in non-Latin alphabet > with great Heads. The < in non-Latin alphabet > , who live a Thouand years. The < in non-Latin alphabet > , o wift, that they will out-run a Hore. The < in non-Latin alphabet > that go with their Heels forward, and their Toes backwards. The < in non-Latin alphabet > , The < in non-Latin alphabet > The < in non-Latin alphabet > , who have one Leg, but will jump a great way, and are call'd Sciapodes, becaue when they lye on their Backs, with this Leg they can keep off the Sun from their Bodies.

Now Strabo Strabo Geograph. lib. 15. p. m. 489. & lib. 2. p. 48. & alibi., from whom I have collected the Decription of thee Montrous orts of Men, and they are mentioned too by Pliny, Solinus, Mela, Philotratus, and others; and Munster in his Comography Munter Comograph. lib. 6. p. 1151. has given a figure of ome of them; Strabo, I ay, who was an Enemy to all uch fabulous Relations, no doubt was prejudiced likewie againt the Pygmies, becaue thee Hitorians had made them a Puny Race of Men, and invented o many Romances about them. I can no ways therefore blame him for denying, that there were ever any uch Men Pygmies; and do readily agree with him, that no Man ever aw them: and am o far from dienting from thoe Great Men, who have denied them on this account, that I think they have all the reaon in the World on their ide. And to hew how ready I am to cloe with them in this Point, I will here examine the contrary Opinion, and what Reaons they give for the upporting it: For there have been ome Moderns, as well as the Ancients, that have maintained that thee Pygmies were real Men. And this they pretend to prove, both from Humane Authority and Divine.

Now by Men Pygmies we are by no means to undertand Dwarfs. In all Countries, and in all Ages, there has been now and then oberved uch Miniture of Mankind, or under-ized Men. Cardan Cardan de ubtilitate, lib. 11. p. 458. tells us he aw one carried about in a Parrot's Cage, that was but a Cubit high. Nicephorus Nicephor. Hitor. Eccleiat. lib. 12. cap. 37. tells us, that in Theodoius the Emperour's time, there was one in AEgypt that was no bigger than a Partridge; yet what was to be admired, he was very Prudent, had a weet clear Voice, and a generous Mind; and lived Twenty Years. So likewie a King of Portugal ent to a Duke of Savoy, when he married his Daughter to him, an AEthiopian Dwarf but three Palms high Happetius in Relat. curiois, No. 85. p. 677.. And Thevenot Thevenot. Voyage de Levant. lib. 2. c. 68. tells us of the Preent made by the King of the Abyins, to the Grand Seignior, of everal little black Slaves out of Nubia, and the Countries near AEthiopia, which being made Eunuchs, were to guard the Ladies of the Seraglio. And a great many uch like Relations there are. But thee being only Dwarfs, they mut not be eteemed the Pygmies we are enquiring about, which are repreented as a Nation, and the whole Race of them to be of the like tature. Dari tamen integras Pumilionum Gentes, tam falum est, quàm quod faliimum, aith Harduin Jo. Harduini Notae in Plinij Nat. Hit. lib. 6. cap. 22. p. 688..

Neither likewie mue it be granted, that tho' in ome Climates there might be Men generally of les tature, than what are to be met with in other Countries, that they are preently Pygmies. Nature has not fixed the ame tandard to the growth of Mankind in all Places alike, no more
than to Brutes or Plants. The Dimenions of them all, according to the Climate, may differ. If we conult the Original, viz. Homer that firt mentioned the Pygmies, there are only thee two Characteritics he gives of them. That they are < in non-Latin alphabet >
eu Cubitales; and that the Cranes did ue to fight them. 'Tis true, as a Poet, he calls them < in non-Latin alphabet > , which I have accounted for before. Now if there cannot be found uch Men as are Cubitales, that the Cranes might probably fight with, notwithtanding all the Romances of the Indian Hitorians, I cannot think thee Pygmies to be Men, but they mut be ome other Animals, or the whole mut be a Fiction.

Having premied this, we will now enquire into their Aertion that maintain the Pygmies to be a Race of Men. Now becaue there have been Giants formerly, that have o much exceeded the uual Stature of Man, that there mut be likewie Pygmies as defective in the other extream from this Standard, I think is no concluive Argument, tho' made ue of by ome. Old Capar Bartholine Capar. Bartholin Opuculum de Pygmaeis. tells us, that becaue J. Caanius and others had wrote de Gygantibus, ince no Body ele had undertaken it, he would give us a Book de Pygmaeis; and ince he makes it his deign to prove the Exitence of Pygmies, and that the Pygmies were Men, I mut confes I expected great Matters from him.

But I do not find he has informed us of any thing more of them, than what Jo. Talentonius, a Profeor formerly at Parma, had told us before in his Variarum & Reconditarum Rerum Theaurus Jo. Talentonij Variar. & recondit. Rerum Theaurus, lib. 3. cap. 21., from whom he has borrowed mot of this Tract. He has made it a little more formal indeed, by dividing it into Chapters; of which I will give you the Titles; and as I ee occaion, ome Remarks thereon: They will not be many, becaue I have prevented my elf already. The first Chapter is, De Homuncionibus & Pumilionibus eu Nanis à Pygmaeis ditinctis. The econd Chapter, De Pygmaeinominibus & Etymologia. The third Chapter, Duplex ee Pygmaeorum Gemus; & primum Genus aliquando dari. He means Dmarfs, that are no Pygmies at all. The fourth Chapter is, Alterum Genus, nempe Gentem Pygmaeorum ee, aut altem aliquando fuie Autoritatihus Humanis, ide tamen dignorum aeritur. 'Tis as I find it printed; and no doubt an Error in the printing. The Authorities he gives, are, Homer, Cteias, Aritotle, Philotratus, Pliny, Juvenal, Oppian, Baptita Mantuan, Sr. Autin and his Scholiat. Ludovic. Vives, Jo. Laurentius Anania, Job. Caanius, Job. Talentonius, Gellius, Pomp. Mela, and Olaus Magnus. I have taken notice of mot of them already, as I hall of St. Autin and Ludovicus Vives by and by. Jo. Laurentius Anania Joh. Laurent. Anania prope finem tractatus primi uae Geograph. ex Mercatorum relatione tradit (aith Bartholine) eos (c. Pygmaeos) in Septentrionali Thraciae Parte reperiri, (quae Scythiae est proxima) atque ibi cum Gruibus pugnare. And Job. Caanius Joh. Caanius libello de Gygantibas, p. 73. (as he is here quoted) aith,
De Pygmaeis fabuloa quidem ee omnia, quae de iis narrari olent, aliquando exitimavi. Verùm cum videam non unum vel alterum, ed complures Claicos & probatos Autores de his Homunculis multa in eandem fere Sententiam tradidie; eò adducor ut Pygmaeos fuie inficiari non auim. He next brings in Jo. Talentonius, to whom he is o much beholden, and quotes his Opinion, which is full and home, Contare arbitror (aith Talentonius) Jo. Talentonius Variar. & recondit. Rerum Theaurus, lib 3. cap. 21. p. m. 515. debere concedi, Pygmaeos non olùm olim fuie, ed nunc etiam ee, & homines ee, nec parvitatem illis impedimento ee quo minùs int & homines int. But were there uch Men Pygmies now in being, no doubt but we mut have heard of them; ome or other of our Saylors, in their Voyages, would have lighted on them. Tho' Aritotle is here quoted, yet he does not make them Men; So neither does Anania: And I mut own, tho' Talentonius be of this Opinion, yet he takes notice of the faulty Tranlation of this Text of Aristotle by Gaza: and tho' the parvity or lownes of Stature, be no Impediment, becaue we have frequently een uch Dwarf-Men, yet we did never ee a Nation of them: For then there would be no need of that Talmudical Precept which Job. Ludolphus Job Ludolphi Comment. in Hitoriam AEthiopic. p. m. 71. mentions, Nanus ne ducat Nanam, ne fortè oriatur ex iis Digitalis (in Bechor. fol. 45.)

I had almot forgotten Olaus Magnus, whom Bartholine mentions in the cloe of this Chapter, but lays no great tres upon his Authority, becaue he tells us, he is fabulous in a great many other Relations, and he writes but by hear-ay, that the Greenlanders fight the Cranes; Tandem (aith Bartholine) neque ideo Pygmaei unt, i fortè agittis & hatis, icut alij homines, Grues conficiunt & occidunt. This I think is great Partiality: For Cteias, an Author whom upon all turns Bartholine makes ue of as an Evidence, is very poitive, that the Pygmies were excellent Archers: o that he himelf owns, that their being uch, illutrates very much that Text in Ezekiel, on which he pends good part of the next Chapter, whoe Title is, Pygmaeorum Gens ex Ezekiele, atque rationibus probabilibus adtruitur; which we will conider by and by. And tho' Olaus Magnus may write ome things by hear-ay, yet he cannot be o fabulous as Cteias, who (as Lucian tells us) writes what he neither aw himelf, or heard from any Body ele. Not that I think Olaus Magnus his Greenlanders were real Pygmies, no more than Cteias his Pygmies were real Men; tho' he vouches very notably for them. And if all that have copied this Fable from Cteias, mut be look'd upon as the ame Evidence with himelf; the number of the Tetimonies produced need not much concern us, ince they mut all tand or fall with him.

The probable Reaons that Bartholine gives in the fifth Chapter, are taken from other Animals, as Sheep, Oxen, Hores, Dogs, the Indian Formica and Plants: For oberving in the ame Species ome exceive large,
and others extreamly little, he infers, Quae certè cum in Animalibus & Vegetabilibus fiant; cur in Humana pecie non it probabile, haud video: imprimis cum detur magnitudinis exceus Gigantaeus; cur non etiam dabitur Defectus? Quia ergo dantur Gigantes, dabuntur & Pygmaei. Quam conequentiam ut firmam, admittit Cardanus, Cardan • de Rerum varietate, lib. 8. cap. 40. licet de Pygmaeis hoc tantùm concedat, qui pro miraculo, non pro Gente. Now Cardan, tho' he allows this Conequence, yet in the ame place he gives everal Reaons why the Pygmies could not be Men, and looks upon the whole Story as fabulous. Bartholine concludes this Chapter thus: lteriùs ut Probabilitatem fulciamus, addendum Sceleton Pygmaei, quod Dredae vidimus inter alia, plurima, ervatum in Arce ereni. Electoris Saxoniae, altitudine infra Cubitum, Oium oliditate, proportioneque tum Capitis, tum aliorum; ut Embrionem, aut Artificiale quid Nemo rerum peritus upicari poit. Addita inuper est Incriptio Veri Pygmaei. I hereupon looked into Dr. Brown's Travels into thoe Parts, who has given us a large Catalogue of the Curioities, the Elector of Saxony had at Dreden, but did not find amongt them this Sceleton; which, by the largenes of the Head, I upect to be the Sceleton of an Orang-Outang, or our wild Man. But had he given us either a Figure of it, or a more particular Decription, it had been a far greater Satisfaction.

The Title of Bartholine's ixth Chapter is, Pygmaeos ee aut fuie ex variis eorum adjunctis, accidentibus, &c. ab Authoribus decriptis otenditur. As firt, their Magnitude: which he mentions from Cteias, Pliny, Gellias and Juvenal; and tho' they do not all agree exactly, 'tis nothing. Autorum hic dienus nullus est (aith Bartholine) etenim icut in notris hominibus, it a indubiè in Pygmaeis non omnes ejudem magnitudinis. 2. The Place and Country: As Cteias (he aith) places them in the middle of India; Aritotle and Pliny at the Lakes above AEgypt; Homer's Scholiat in the middle of AEgypt; Pliny at another time aith they are at the Head of the Ganges, and ometimes at Gerania, which is in Thracia, which being near Scythia, confirms (he aith) Anania's Relation. Mela places them at the Arabian Gul; and Paulus Jovius docet Pygmaeos ultra Japonem ee; and adds, has Autorum dieniones facile fuerit conciliare; nec mirum diveras relationes à Plinio auditas. For (aith he) as the Tartars often change their Seats, ince they do not live in Houes, but in Tents, fo 'tis no wonder that the Pygmies often change theirs, fince intead of Houes they live in Caves or Huts, built of Mud, Feathers, and Egghels. And this mutation of their Habitations he thinks is very plain from Pliny, where peaking of Gerania, he aith, Pygmaeorum Gens fuie (non jam ee) proditur, creduntque à Gruibus fugatos. Which paage (aith Bartholine) had Adrian Spigelius conidered, he would not o oon have left Aritotle's Opinion, becaue Franc. Alvares the Portuguee did not find them in the place where Aritotle left them; for the Cranees, it
may be, had driven them thence. His third Article is, their Habitation, which Aristotle aith is in Caves; hence they are Troglodytes. Pliny tells us they build Huts with Mud, Feathers, and Egg-hells. But what Bartholine adds, Eò quod Terrae Cavernas inhabitent, non injuriâ dicti unt olim Pygmaei, Terrae filii, is wholly new to me, and I have not met with it in any Author before: tho' he gives us here everal other ignifications of the word Terrae filij from a great many Authors, which I will not trouble you at preent with. 4.
