The Form, being flat noed and ugly, as Cteias. 5. Their Speech, which was the ame as the Indians, as Cteias; and for this I find he has no other Author. 6. Their Hair; where he quotes Cteias again, that they make ue of it for Clothes. 7. Their Vertues and Arts; as that they ue the ame Laws as the Indians, are very jut, excellent Archers, and that the King of India has Three thouand of them in his Guards. All from Cteias. 8. Their Animals, as in Cteias; and here are mentioned their Sheep, Oxen, Aes, Mules, and Hores. 9. Their various Actions; as what Cteias relates of their killing Hares and Foxes with Crows, Eagles, &c. and fighting the Cranes, as Homer, Pliny, Juvenal.

The eventh Chapter in Bartholine has a promiing Title, An Pygmaei int homines, and I expected here omething more to our purpoe; but I find he rather endeavours to anwer the Reaons of thoe that would make them Apes, than to lay down any of his own to prove them Men, And Albertus Magnus's Opinion he thinks aburd, that makes them part Men part Beats; they mut be either one or the other, not a Medium between both; and to make out this, he gives us a large Quotation out of Cardan. But Cardan Cardan. de Rerum varietate, lib. 8. cap. 40. in the ame place argues that they are not Men. As to Sueanus Sueanus Comment, in Arit. de Hitor. Animal. lib. 8. cap. 12. his Argument, that they want Reaon, this he will not grant; but if they ue it les, or more imperfectly than others (which yet, he aith, is not certain) by the ame parity of Reaon, Children, the Boeotians, Cumani and Naturals may not be reckoned Men; and he thinks, what he has mentioned in the preceding Chapter out of Cteias, &c. hews that they have no mall ue of Reaon. As to Sueanus's next Argument, that they want Religion, Jutice, &c. this, he aith, is not confirmed by any grave Writer; and if it was, yet it would not prove that they are not Men. For this defect (he aith) might hence happen, becaue they are forced to live in Caves for fear of the Cranes; and others beides them, are herein faulty. For this Opinion, that the Pygmies were Apes and not Men, he quotes likewie Benedictus Varchius Benedict. Varcbius de Montris. lingua vernacula., and Job. Tinnulus Job. Tinnulus in GlattoChrjio., and Paulus Jovius Paulus Jovius lib. de Mucovit. Legatione., and everal others of the Moderns, he tells us, are of the ame mind. Imprimis Geographici quos non puduit in Mappis Geographicis loco Pygmaeorum imias cum Gruibus pugnantes ridiculè dipinxie.

The Title of Bartholine's eighth and lat Chapter is, Argumenta corum qui Pygmaeorum Historiam fabuloam cenent, recitantur & refutantur. Where he tells us, the only Peron amongt the Ancients that thought the Story of the Pygmies to be fabulous was Strabo; but amongt the Moderns there are everal, as Cardan, Budaeus, Aldrovandus, Fullerus and others. The firt Objection (he aith) is that of Spigelius and others; that ince the whole World is now dicovered, how happens it, that thee Pygmies are not to be met with? He has even Anwers to this Objection; how atisfactory they are, the Reader may judge, if he pleaes, by peruing them amongt the Quotations Repondes 1. Contrarium tetari Mercatorum Relationem apud Ananiam upra Cap. 4. 2. Et licet non invent • eent vivià quolibet, pari j • re Mono • erota & alia negare liceret. 3. Qui maria pernavigant, vix eras pa • cas maritimas lutrant, adeo non terras omnes à mari diitas. 4. Neque in Oris illos habitare maritimis ex Capite quinto manietum et. 5. Quis tetatum eomnem adhibuie diligentiam in inquirendo eos ut inve •••• et. 6 Ita in terra habitant, ut in Antris vitam tolerare dicantur. 7. Si vel maximè omni ab omni
••
•• igertia quaeiti fuient, nec inventi; fieri potet, ut intar Gigantum jam deierint nec int ampliùs.. Cardan's econd Objection (he aith) is, that they live but eight years, whence everal Inconveniences would happen, as Cardan hews; he anwers that no good Author aerts this; and if there was, yet what Cardan urges would not follow; and intances out of Artemidorus in Pliny Pinij Hit. Nat. lib. 7. cap. 2. p. m. 14., as a Parallel in the Calingae a Nation of India, where the Women conceive when five years old, and do not live above eight. Gener peaking of the Pygmies, aith, Vitae autem longitudo anni arciter octo ut Albertus refert. Cardan perhaps had his Authority from Alberius, or it may be both took it from this paage in Pliny, which I think would better agree to Apes than Men. But Artemidorus being an Indian Hitorian, and in the ame place telling other Romances, the les Credit is to be given to him. The third Objection, he aith, is of Cornelius à Lapide, who denies the Pygmies, becaue Homer was the firt Author of them. The ourth Objection he aith is, becaue Authors dier about the Place where they hould be: This, he tells us, he has anwered already in the fifth Chapter. The fifth and lat Objection he mentions is, that but few have een them. He anwers, there are a great many Wonders in Sacred and Profane Hitory that we have not een, yet mut not deny. And he intances in three; As the Formicae Indicae, which are as bigs as great Dogs: The Cornu Plantabile in the Iland Goa, which when cut off from the Beat, and flung upon the Ground, will take root like a Cabbage: And the Scotland Geee that grow upon Trees, for which he quotes a great many Authors, and o concludes.

Now how far Bartholine in this Treatie has made out that the Pygmies of the Ancients were real Men, either from the Authorities he has quoted, or his Reaonings upon them, I ubmit to the Reader. I hall proceed now (as I promied) to conider the Proof they pretend from Holy
Writ: For Bartholine and others init upon that Text in Ezekiel (Cap. 27. Ver. 11.) where the Vulgar Tranlation has it thus; Filij Arvad cum Exercitu tuo upra Muros tuos per circuitum, & Pygmaei in Turribus tuis fuerunt; Scuta ua upenderunt upra Muros tuos per circuitum. Now Talentonius and Bartholine think that what Cteias relates of the Pygmies, as their being good Archers, very well illutrates this Text of Ezekiel: I hall here trancribe what Sir Thomas Brown Sir Thomas Brown's Enquivies into Vulgar Errors, lib. 4. cap. 11. p. 242. remarks upon it; and if any one requires farther Satisfaction, they may conult Job Ludolphus's Comment on his AEthiopic Hitory Comment. in H • t. AEthiopic. p. 73..

The econd Tetimony (aith Sir Thomas Brown) is deduced from Holy Scripture; thus rendered in the Vulgar Tranlation, Sed & Pygmaei qui erant in turribus tuis, pharetras uas upenderunt in muris tuis per gyrum: from whence notwithtanding we cannot infer this Aertion, for firt the Tranlators accord not, and the Hebrew word Gammadim is very variouly rendered. Though Aquila, Vatablus and Lyra will have it Pygmaei, yet in the Septuagint, it is no more then Watchmen; and o in the Arabick and HighDutch. In the Chalde, Cappadocians, in Symmachus, Medes, and in the French, thoe of Gamed. Theodotian of old, and Tremellius of late, have retained the Textuary word; and o have the Italian, Low Dutch and Englih Tranlators, that is, the Men of Arvad were upon thy Walls round about, and the Gammadims were in thy Towers.

Nor do Men only dient in the Tranlation of the word, but in the Expoition of the Sene and Meaning thereof; for ome by Gammadims undertand a People of Syria, o called from the City of Gamala; ome hereby undertand the Cappadocians, many the Medes: and hereof Forerius hath a ingular Expoition, conceiving the Watchmen of Tyre, might well be called Pygmies, the Towers of that City being o high, that unto Men below, they appeared in a Cubital Stature. Others expound it quite contrary to common Acception, that is not Men of the least, but of the largest ize; o doth Cornelius contrue Pygmaei, or Viri Cubitales, that is, not Men of a Cubit high, but of the larget Stature, whoe height like that of Giants, is rather to be taken by the Cubit than the Foot; in which phrae we read the meaure of Goliah, whoe height is aid to be ix Cubits and a pan. Of affinity hereto is alo the Expoition of Jerom; not taking Pygmies for D •• arfs, but tout and valiant Champions; not taking the ene of < in non-Latin alphabet > , which ignifies the Cubit meaure, but that which expreeth Pugils; that is, Men fit for Combat and the Exercie of the Fist. Thus can there be no atisfying illation from this Text, the diverity, or rather contrariety of Expoitions and Interpretations, ditracting more than confirming the Truth of the Story.

But why Aldrovandus or Capar Bartholine hould bring in St. Autin as a Favourer of this Opinion of Men Pygmies, I ee no Reaon. To me
he eems to aert quite the contrary: For propoing this Quetion, An ex propagine Adam vel filiorum Noe, quaedam genera Hominum Montroa prodierunt? He mentions a great many montrous Nations of Men, as they are decribed by the Indian Hitorians, and amongt the ret, the Pygmies, the Sciopodes, &c. And adds, Quid dicam de Cynocephalis, quorum Canina Capita atque ipe Latratus magis Betias quàm Homines confitentur? Sed omnia Genera Hominum, quae dicuntur ee, ee credere, non et necee. And afterwards o fully exprees himelf in favour of the Hypotheis I am here maintaining, that I think it a great Confirmation of it. Nam & Simias (aith he) & Cercopithecos, & Sphingas, i neciremus non Homines ee, ed Betias, poent iti Hitorici de ua Curioitate gloriantes velut Gentes aliquas Hominum nobis impunitâ vanitate mentiri. At lat he concludes and determines the Quetion thus, Aut illa, quae talia de quibudam Gentibus cripta unt, omnino nulla unt, aut i unt, Homines non unt, aut ex Adam unt i homines unt.

There is nothing therefore in St. Autin that jutifies the being of Men Pygmies, or that the Pygmies were Men; he rather makes them Apes. And there is nothing in his Scholiat Ludovicus Vives that tends this way, he only quotes from other Authors, what might illutrate the Text he is commenting upon, and no way aerts their being Men. I hall therefore next enquire into Bochartus's Opinion, who would have them to be the Nubae or Nobae. Hos Nubas Troglodyticos (aith Sam. Bochart. Geograph. Sacrae, Part. 1. lib. 2. cap. 23. p.m. 142. he) ad Avalitem Sinum ee Pygmaeos Veterum multa probant. He gives us five Reaons to prove this. As, 1. The Authority of Heychius, who aith < in non-Latin alphabet > . 2. Becaue Homer places the Pygmies near the Ocean, where the Nubae were. 3. Aritotle places them at the Lakes of the Nile. Now by the Nile Bochartus tells us, we mut undertand the Ataboras, which the Ancients thought to be a Branch of the Nile, as he proves from Pliny, Solinus and AEthicus. And Ptolomy (he tells us) places the Nubae hereabout 4. Becaue Aritotle makes the Pygmies to be Troglodytes, and o were the Nubae 5. He urges that Story of Nonnous which I have already mentioned, and thinks that thoe that Nonnous met with, were a Colony of the Nubae; but afterwards adds, Quos tamen abit ut putemus Staturâ fuie Cubitali, prout Poetae fingunt, qui omnia in majus augent. But this methinks poils them from being Pygmies; everal other Nations at this rate may be Pygmies as well as thee Nubae. Beides, he does not inform us, that thee Nubae ued to fight the Cranes; and if they do not, and were not Cubitales, they can't be Homer's Pygmies, which we are enquiring after. But the Notion of their being Men, had o poeed him, that it put him upon fancying they mut be the Nubae; but 'tis plain that thoe in Nonnous could not be a Colony of the Nubae; for then the Nubae mut have undertood their Language, which the
Text aith, none of the Neighbourhood did. And becaue the Nubae are Troglodytes, that therefore they mut be Pygmies, is no Argument at all. For Troglodytes here is ued as an Adjective
• and there is a ort of Sparrow which is called Paer Troglodytes. Not but that in Africa there was a Nation of Men called Troglodytes, but quite different from our Pygmies. How far Bochartus may be in the right, in gueing the Lakes of the Nile (whereabout Aritotle places the Pygmies) to be the Fountains of the River Ataboras, which in his decription, and likewie the Map, he places in the Country of the Avalitae, near the Moylon Emporium; I hall not enquire. This I am certain of, he mirepreents Aristotle where he tells us Bocharti Hierozoici pars Poterior, lib. 1. cap. 11. p. 76., Quamvis in ea fabula hoc altem verum ee aerat Philoophus, Puillos Homines in iis locis degere: for as I have already oberved; Aritotle in that Text aith nothing at all of their being Men: the contrary rather might be thence inferred, that they were Brutes. And Bochart's Tranlation, as well as Gaza's is faulty here, and by no means to be allowed, viz. t aiunt, genus ibi parvum est tam Hominum, quàm Equorum; which had Bochartus conidered, he would not have been o fond it may be of his Nubae. And if the < in non-Latin alphabet > in Heychius are uch Pygmies as Bochartus makes his Nubae, Quos tamen abit ut putemus taturâ fuie Cubitali, it will not do our buines at all; and neither Homer's Authority, nor Aritotle's does him any Service.

But this Fable of Men Pygmies has not only obtained amongt the Greeks and Indian Hitorians: the Arabians likewie tell much uch Stories of them, as the ame learned Bochartus informs us. I will give his Latin Tranlation of one of them, which he has printed in Arabick alo: Arabes idem (aith Bochartus ibid. p.m. 77. Bochartus) referunt ex cujudam Graeculi ide, qui Jacobo Iaaci filio, Sigarieni fertur it a narrae. Navigabam aliquando in mari Zingitano, & impulit me ventus in quandam Inulam. In cujus Oppidum cum deveniem, reperi Incolas Cubitalis ee taturae, & pleroque Coclites. Quorum multitudo in me congregata me deduxit ad Regem uum. Juit is, ut Captivus detinerer; & in quandam Caveae peciem conjectus um; eos autem aliquando ad bellum intrui cum viderem, dixerunt Hotem imminere, & fore ut propediem ingruerèt. Nec multò pot Gruum exercitus in eos inurrexit. Atque ideo erant Coclites, quod eorum oculos hae confodient. Atque Ego, virgâ aumptâ, in eas impetum feci, & illae avolârunt atque aufugerunt; ob quod facinus in honore fui apud illos. This Author, it eems, repreents them under the ame Misfortune with the Poet, who firt mentioned them, as being blind, by having their Eyes peck'd out by their cruel Enemies. Such an Accident poibly might happen now and then, in thee bloody Engagements, tho' I wonder the Indian Hitorians have not taken notice of it. However the Pygmies hewed themelves grateful to their Deliverer, in heaping Honours on him. One would gues,
for their own akes, they could not do les than make him their Generaliimo; but our Author is modet in not declaring what they were.

p.U: eems to unettle all, and endeavours utterly to ruine the whole Story: for he tells us, If you travel all over Africa, you hall not meet with either a Crane or Pygmie: Se mirari (aith Iaac Voius de Nili aliorumque flumimnum Origine, Cap. 18. Iaac Voius) Aritotelem, quod tam eriò affirmet non ee fabellam, quae de Pygmaeis & Bello, quod cum Gruibus gerant, narrantur. Si quis totam pervadat Africam, nullas vel Grues vel Pygmaeos inveniet. Now one would wonder more at Voius, that he hould aert this of Aritotle, which he never aid. And ince Voius is o mitaken in what he relates of Aritotle; where he might o eaily have been in the right, 'tis not improbable, but he may be out in the ret too: For who has travelled all Africa over, that could inform him? And why hould he be o peremptory in the Negative, when he had o poitive an Affirmation of Aritotle to the contrary? or if he would not believe Aritotle's Authority, methinks he hould Aritophanes's, who tells us Aritophanes in Nubibus., < in non-Latin alphabet > . 'Tis time to ow when the noiy Cranes take their flight into Libya. Which Obervation is likewie made by Heiod, Theognis, Aratus, and others. And Maximus Tyrius (as I find him quoted in Bochartus) aith, < in non-Latin alphabet > . i. e. Grues per aetatem ex AEgypto abcedentes, quia Calorem pati non pount, alis velorum intar expanis, per aerem ad Scythicam plagam rectà feruntur. Which fully confirms that Migration of the Cranes that Aritotle mentions.

div.p: But Voius I find, tho' he will not allow the Cranes, yet upon econd Thoughts did admit of Pygmies here: For this Story of the Pygmies and the Cranes having made o much noie, he thinks there may be omething of truth in it; and then gives us his Conjecture, how that the Pygmies may be thoe Dwarfs, that are to be met with beyond the Fountains of the Nile; but that they do not fight Cranes but Elephants, and kill a great many of them, and drive a coniderable Traffick for their Teeth with the Jagi, who ell them to thoe of Congo and the Portuguee. I will give you Voius's own words; Attamen (aith Iaac Voius ibid: he) ut olent fabellae non de nihilo fingi & aliquod plerunque continent veri, id ipum qnoque • .ìc factum ee exitimo. Certum quippe est ultra Nili fontes multos reperiri Nanos, qui tamen non cum Gruibus, ed cum Elephantis perpetuum gerant bellum. Praecipuum quippe Eboris commercium in regno magni Macoki per itos tranigitur Homunciones; habitant in Sylvis, & mira dexteritate Elephantos agittis conficiunt. Carnibus vecuntur, Dentes verò Jagis divendunt, illi autem Congentibus & Luitanis.

Job Ludolphus Job Ludolphus in Comment. in Hitoriam AEthiopicam, p.m. 71. in his Commentary on his AEthiopick Hitory remarks, That there was never known a Nation all of Dwarfs. Nani quippe (aith Ludolphus) Naturae quodam errore ex aliis jutae taturae hominibus generantur. Qualis verò ea Gens it, ex qua ita Naturae Ludibria tantâ copiâ proveniant, Voium docere oportebat, quia Pumiliones Pumiles alios non gignunt, ed plerunque teriles unt, experientia tete; ut planè non opus habuerunt Doctores Talmudici Nanorum matrimonia prohibere, ne Digitales ex iis nacerentur. Ludolphus it may be is a little too trict with Voius for calling them Nani; he may only mean a ort of Men in that Country of les Stature than ordinary. And Dapper in his Hitory of Africa, from whom Voius takes this Account, decribes uch in the Kingdom of Mokoko, he calls Mimos, and tells us that they kill Elephants. But I ee no reaon why Voius hould take thee Men for the Pygmies of the Ancients, or think that they gave any occaion or ground for the inventing this Fable, if there was no other reaon, this was ufficient, becaue they were able to kill the Elephants. The Pygmies were carce a Match for the Cranes; and for them to have encountred an Elephant, were as vain an Attempt, as the Pygmies were guilty of in Philotratus Philotratus. Icon, lib. 2. p.m. 817., who to revenge the Death of Antaeus, having found Hercules napping in Libya, mutered up all their Forces againt him. One Phalanx (he tells us) aaulted his left hand; but againt his right hand, that being the tronger, two Phalanges were appointed. The Archers and Slingers beieged his feet, admiring the hugenes of his Thighs: But againt his Head, as the Arenal, they raied Batteries, the King himelf taking his Pot there. They et fire to his Hair, put Reaping-hooks in his Eyes; and that he might not breath, clapp'd Doors to his Mouth and Notrils; but all the Execution that they could do, was only to awake him, which when done, deriding their folly, he gather'd them all up into his Lion's Skin, and carried them (Philotratus thinks) to Eurithenes. This Antaeus was as remarkable for his height, as the Pygmies were for their lownes of Stature: For Plutarch Plutarch. in vita Q. Sertorij. tells us, that Q. Sertorius not being willing to trut Common Fame, when he came to Tingis (now Tangier) he caued Antaeus's Sepulchre to be opened, and found his Corps full threecore Cubits long. But Sertorius knew well enough how to impoe upon the Credulity of the People, as is evident from the Story of his white Hind, which Plutarch likewie relates.

But to return to our Pygmies; tho' mot of the great and learned Men would eem to decry this Story as a Fiction and meer Fable, yet there is omething of Truth, they think, mut have given the firt rie to it, and that it was not wholly the product of Phancy, but had ome real foundation, tho' diguied, according to the different Imagination and Genius
of the Relator: 'Tis this that has incited them to give their everal Conjectures about it. Job Ludolphus finding what has been offered at in Relation to the Pygmies, not to atisfie, he thinks he can better account for this Story, by leaving out the Cranes, and placing in their tead, another ort of Bird he calls the Condor. I will give you his own words: Sed ad Pygmaeos (s;aith Job Ludolphus Comment. in Hitoriam uam AEthiopic. p. 73. Ludolphus) revertamur; fabula de Geranomachia Pygmaeorum eu pugna cum Gruibus etiam aliquid de vero trahere videtur, i pro Gruibus Condoras intelligas, Aves in interiore Africa maximas, ut fidem penè excedat; aiunt enim quod Ales ita vitulum Elephanti in Aererm extollere poit; ut infra docebimus. Cum his Pygmaeos pugnare, ne pecora ua rapiant, incredibile non est. Error ex eo natus videtur, quod primus Relator, alio vocabulo detitutus, Grues pro Condoris nominârit, icuti Plautus Picos pro Gryphibus, & Romani Boves lucas pro Elephantis dixere.

'Tis true, if what Juvenal only in ridicule mentions, was to be admitted as a thing really done, that the Cranes could fly away with a Pygmie, as our Kites can with a Chicken, there might be ome pretence for Ludovicus's Condor or Cunctor: For he mentions afterwards J • b Ludolphus ibi... pag. 164. out of P. Job. dos Santos the Portuguee, that 'twas oberved that one of thee Condors once flew away with an Ape, Chain, Clog and all, about ten or twelve pounds weight, which he carried to a neighbouring Wood, and there devoured him. And Garcilao de la Vega Garcilao de la Vega Royal Comment. of Peru. relates that they will eize and fly away with a Child ten or twelve years old. But Juvenal Juvenal Satyr. 13. • e •• . 167. only mentions this in ridicule and merriment, where he aith,
Ad ubitas Thracum volucres, nubemque onoram
Pygmaeos parvis currit Bellator in armis:
Mox impar hoti, raptuque per aera curvis
nguibus à aevâ fertur Grue.

Beides, were the Condors to be taken for the Cranes, it would utterly poil the Pygmaeomachia; for where the Match is o very unequal, 'tis impoible for the Pygmies to make the leat hew of a fight. Ludolphus puts as great hardhips on them, to fight thee Condors, as Voius did, in making them fight Elephants, but not with equal Succes; for Voius's Pygmies made great Slaughters of the Elephants; but Ludolphus his Cranes weep away the Pygmies, as eaily as an Owl would a Moue, and eat them up into the bargain; now I never heard the Cranes were o cruel and barbarous to their Enemies, tho' there are ome Nations in the World that are reported to do o.

Moreover, thee Condor's I find are very rare to be met with; and
when they are, they often appear ingle, or but a few. Now Homer's, and the Cranes of the Ancients, are always repreented in Flocks. Thus Oppian Oppian. lib. 1. de Pij •• bus. as I find him tranlated into Latin Vere:
Et velut AEthiopum veniunt, Nilique fluenta
Turmatim Palamedis Aves, celaeeque per altum
Aera labentes fugiunt Athlanta nivoum,
Pygmaeos imbelle Genus, parvumque fatigant,
Non perturbato procedunt ordine denae
Intruct is volucres obcurant aëra Turmis.
To imagine thee Grues a ingle Gigantick Bird, would much leen the Beauty of Homer's Simile, and would not have erved his turn; and there are none who have borrowed Homer's fancy, but have thought o. I will only farther intance in Baptita Mantuan:
Pygmaei breve vulgus, iners Plebecula, quando
Convenere Grues longis in praelia rotris,
Sublato clamore fremunt, dumque agmine magno
Hotibus occurrit, tellus tremit Indica, clamant
Littora, arenarum nimbis abconditur aër;
Omnis & involvit Pulvis olemque, Polumque,
Et Genus hoc Hominum naturâ imbelle, quietum,
Mite, facit Mavors pugnax, immane Cruentum.

Having now conidered and examined the various Opinions of thee learned Men concerning this Pygmaeomachia; and repreented the Reaons they give for maintaining their Conjectures; I hall beg leave to ubjoyn my own: and if what at preent I offer, may eem more probable, or account for this Story with more likelyhood, than what hath hitherto been advanced, I hall not think my time altogether mipent: But if this will not do, I hall never trouble my head more about them, nor think my elf any ways concerned to write on this Argument again. And I had not done it now, but upon the occaion of Diecting this Orang-Outang, or wild Man, which being a Native of Africa, and brought from Angola, tho' firt taken higher up in the Country, as I was informed by the Relation given me; and oberving o great a Reemblance, both in the outward hape, and, what urprized me more, in the Structure likewie of the inward Parts, to a Man; this Thought was eaily uggeted to me, That very probably this Animal, or ome other uch of the ame Species, might give the firt rie and occaion to the Stories of the Pygmies. What has been the < in non-Latin alphabet > , and rendered this Story o difficult to be believed, I find hath been the Opinion that has generally
obtained, that thee Pygmies were really a Race of little Men. And tho' they are only Brutes, yet being at firt call'd wild Men, no doubt from the Reemblance they bear to Men; there have not been wanting thoe epecially amongt the Ancients, who have invented a hundred ridiculous Stories concerning them; and have attributed thoe things to them, were they to be believed in what they ay, that necearily conclude them real Men.

To um up therefore what I have already dicoured, I think I have proved, that the Pygmies were not an Humane Species or Men. And tho' Homer, who firt mentioned them, calls them < in non-Latin alphabet > , yet we need not undertand by this Expreion any thing more than Apes: And tho' his Geranomachia hath been look'd upon by mot only as a Poetical Fiction; yet by aigning what might be the true Caue of this Quarrel between the Cranes and Pygmies, and by diveting it of the many fabulous Relations that the Indian Hitorians, and others, have loaded it with, I have endeavoured to render it a true, at leat a probable Story. I have intanced in Cteias and the Indian Hitorians, as the Authors and Inventors of the many Fables we have had concerning thém: Particularly, I have Examined thoe Relations; where Speech or Language is attributed to them; and hewn, that there is no reaon to believe, that they ever pake any Language at all. But thee Indian Hitorians having related o many extravagant Romances of the Pygmies, as to render their whole Hitory upected, nay to be utterly denied, that there were ever any uch Creatures as Pygmies in Nature, both by Strabo of old, and mot of our Learned Men of late, I have endeavoured to aert the Truth of their being, from a Text in Aritotle; which being o poitive in affirming their Exitence, creates a difficulty, that can no ways be got over by uch as are of the contrary Opinion. This Text I have vindicated from the fale Interpretations and Gloes of everal Great Men, who had their Minds o prepoeed and prejudiced with the Notion of Men Pygmies, that they often would quote it, and miapply it, tho' it contain'd nothing that any ways favoured their Opinion; but the contrary rather, that they were Brutes, and not Men.

And that the Pygmies were really Brutes, I think I have plainly proved out of Herodotus and Philotratus, who reckon them amongt the wild Beats that breed in thoe Countries: For tho' by Herodotus they are call'd < in non-Latin alphabet > , and Philotratus calls them < in non-Latin alphabet > , yet both make them < in non-Latin alphabet > or wild Beats. And I might here add what Pauanias Pauanias in Atticis, p. m. 21. relates from Euphemus Car, who by contrary Winds was driven upon ome Ilands, where he tells us, < in non-Latin alphabet > , but when he comes to decribe them, tells us that they had no Speech;
that they had Tails on their Rumps; and were very lacivious toward the Women in the Ship. But of thee more, when we come to dicoure of Satyrs.

And we may the les wonder to find that they call Brutes Men, ince 'twas common for thee Hitorians to give the Title of Men, not only to Brutes, but they were grown o wanton in their Inventions, as to decribe everal Nations of Montrous Men, that had never any Being, but in their own Imagination, as I have intanced in everal. I therefore excue Strabo for denying the Pygmies, ince he could not but be convinced, they could not be uch Men, as thee Hitorians have decribed them. And the better to judge of the Reaons that ome of the Moderns have given to prove the Being of Men Pygmies, I have laid down as Potulata's, that hereby we mut not undertand Dwarfs, nor yet a Nation of Men, tho' omewhat of a leer ize and tature than ordinary; but we mut oberve thoe two Characteriticks that Homer gives of them, that they are Cubitales, and fight Cranes.

Having premied this, I have taken into conideration Capar Bartholine Senior his Opuculum de Pygmaeis, and Jo. Talentonius's Diertation about them; and upon examination do find, that neither the Humane Authorities, nor Divine that they alledge, do any ways prove, as they pretend, the Being of Men Pygmies. St. Autin, who is likewie quoted on their ide, is o far from favouring this Opinion, that he doubts whether any uch Creatures exit, and if they do, concludes them to be Apes or Monkeys; and cenures thoe Indian Hitorians for impoing uch Beats upon us, as ditinct Races of Men. Julius Caear Scaliger, and Iaac Caaubon, and Adrian Spigelius utterly deny the Being of Pygmies, and look upon them as a Figment only of the Ancients, becaue uch little Men as they decribe them to be, are no where to be met with in all the World. The Learned Bochartus, tho' he eteems the Geranomachia to be a Fable, and lights it, yet thinks that what might give the occaion to the Story of the Pygmies, might be the Nubae or Nobae, as Iaac Voius conjectures that it was thoe Dwarfs beyond the Fountains of the Nile, that Dapper calls the Mimos, and tells us, they kill Elephants for to make a Traffick with their Teeth. But Job Ludolphus alters the Scene, and intead of Cranes, ubtitutes his Condors, who do not fight the Pygmies, but fly away with them, and then devour them.

Now all thee Conjectures do no ways account for Homer's Pygmies and Cranes, they are too much forced and train'd. Truth is always eaie and plain. In our preent Cae therefore I think the Orang-Outang, or wild Man, may exactly upply the place of the Pygmies, and without any violence or injury to the Story, ufficiently account for the whole Hitory of the Pygmies, but what is mot apparently fabulous; for what has been the greatet difficulty to be olved or atisfied, was their being
Men; for as Gener remarks (as I have already quoted him) Sed veterum nullus aliter de Pygmaeis cripit, quàm Homunciones ee. And the Moderns too, being byaed and miguided by this Notion, have either wholly denied them, or contented themelves in offering their Conjectures what might give the firt rie to the inventing this Fable. And tho' Albertus, as I find him frequently quoted, thought that the Pygmies might be only a ort of Apes, and he is placed in the Head of thoe that epoued this Opinion, yet he poils all, by his way of reaoning, and by making them peak; which was more than he needed to do.

I cannot ee therefore any thing that will o fairly olve this doubt, that will reconcile all, that will o eaily and plainly make out this Story, as by making the Qrang-Outang to be the Pygmie of the Ancients; for 'tis the ame Name that Antiquity gave them. For Herodotus's
< in non-Latin alphabet > , what can they be ele, than Homines Sylvetres, or wild Men? as they are now called. And Homer's
< in non-Latin alphabet > , are no more an Humane Kind, or Men, than Herodotus's
< in non-Latin alphabet > , which he makes to be < in non-Latin alphabet > , or wild Beats: And the < in non-Latin alphabet > or < in non-Latin alphabet > (as they are often called) were jut the ame. Becaue this ort of Apes had o great a reemblance to Men, more than other Apes or Monkeys; and they going naturally erect, and being deigned by Nature to go o, (as I have hewn in the Anatomy) the Ancients had a very plauible ground for giving them this denomination of < in non-Latin alphabet > or < in non-Latin alphabet > , but commonly they added an Epithet; as < in non-Latin alphabet > , or ome nch like. Now the Ancient Greek, and Indian Hitorians, tho' they might know thee Pygmies to be only Apes like Men, and not to be real Men, yet being o extreamly addicted to Mythology, or making Fables, and finding this o fit a Subject to engraft upon, and invent Stories about, they have not been wanting in furnihing us with a great many very Romantick ones on this occaion. And the Moderns being impoed upon by them, and miguided by the Name of < in non-Latin alphabet > or < in non-Latin alphabet > , as if thereby mut be always undertood an Humane Kind, or real Men, they have altogether mitaken the Truth of the Story, and have either wholly denied it, or rendered it as improbable by their own Conjectures.

This difficulty therefore of their being called Men, I think, may fairly enough be accounted for by what I have aid. But it may be objected that the Orang-Outang, or thee wild or avage Men are not < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Tripithami, that is, but two Foot and a quarter high, becaue by ome Relations that have been given, it appears they have been oberved to be of a higher tature, and as tall as ordinary Men. Now tho' this may be allowed as to thee wild Men that are bred in other places; and probably enough likewie, there are uch in ome Parts of the Continent of Africa; yet 'tis ufficient to our buines if there are any there, that will come within our Dimenions; for our Scene lies in Africa; where Strabo oberves, that generally the Beats are of a les ize than ordinary; and
this he thinks might give the rie to the Story of the Pygmies. For, aith he Strabo Geograph. lib. 17. p. m. 565., < in non-Latin alphabet > . i.e. That their Beats are mall, as their Sheep, Goats and Oxen, and their Dogs are mall, but hairy and fierce: and it may be (aith he) from the
< in non-Latin alphabet >
or littlenes of the tature of thee Animals, they have invented and impoed on us the Pygmies. And then adds, That no body fit to be believed ever aw them; becaue he fancied, as a great many others have done, that thee Pygmies mut be real Men, and not a ort of Brutes. Now ince the other Brutes in this Country are generally of a les ize than in other Parts, why may not this ort of Ape, the Orang-Outang, or wild Man, be o likewie. Aritotle peaking of the Pygmies, aith, < in non-Latin alphabet >
That both they and the Hores there are but mall. He does not ay their Hores, for they were never mounted upon Hores, but only upon Partridges, Goats and Rams. And as the Hores, and other Beats are naturally les in Africa than in other Parts, o likewie may the Orang-Outang be. This that I diected, which was brought from Angola (as I have often mentioned) wanted omething of the jut tature of the Pygmies; but it was young, and I am therefore uncertain to what tallnes it might grow, when at full Age: And neither Tulpius, nor Gaendus, nor any that I have hitherto met with, have adjuted the full tature of this Animal that is found in thoe Parts from whence ours was brought: But 'tis mot certain, that there are orts of Apes that are much les than the Pygmies are decribed to be. And, as other Brutes, o the Ape-kind, in different Climates, may be of different Dimenions; and becaue the other Brutes here are generally mall, why may not they be o likewie. Or if the difference hould be but little, I ee no great reaon in this cae, why we hould be over-nice, or crupulous.

As to our Ape Pygmies or Orang-Outang fighting the Cranes, this, I think, may be eaily enough made out, by what I have already oberved; for this wild Man I diected was Carnivorous, and it may be Omnivorous, at leat as much as Man is; for it would eat any thing that was brought to the Table. And if it was not their Hunger that drove them to it, their Wantonnes, it may be, would make them apt enough to rob the Cranes Nets; and if they did o, no doubt but the Cranes would make noie enough about it, and endeavour what they could to beat them off, which a Poet might eaily make a Fight: Tho' Homer only makes ue of it, as a Simile, in comparing the great Shouts of the Trojans to the Noie of the Cranes, and the Silence of the Greeks to that of the Pygmies when they are going to Engage, which is natural enough, and very jut, and contains nothing, but what may eaily be believed; tho'
upon this account he is commonly expoed, and derided, as the Inventor of this Fable; and that there was nothing of Truth in it, but that 'twas wholly a Fiction of his own.

Thoe Pygmies that Paulus Jovius (w) Paui. Jovij de Legatione Muchovitar. lib. p.m. 489. decribes, tho' they dwell at a great ditance from Africa, and he calls them Men, yet are o like Apes, that I cannot think them any thing ele. I will give you his own words: ltra Lapones (aith he) in Regione inter Corum & Aquilonem perpetuâ opprea Caligine Pygmaeos reperiri, aliqui eximiae fidei tetes rctulerunt; qui potquàm ad ummum adoleverint, notratis Pueri denum annorum Menuram vix excedunt. Meticuloum genus hominum, & garritu Sermonem exprimens, adeo ut tam Simiae propinqui, quàm taturâ ac enibus ab jutae Proceritatis homine remoti videantur. Now there is this Advantage in our Hypotheis, it will take in all the Pygmies, in any part of the World, or wherever they are to be met with, without uppoing, as ome have done, that 'twas the Cranes that forced them to quit their Quarters; and upon this account everal Authors have decribed them in different places: For unles we uppoe the Cranes o kind to them, as to wat them over, how came we to find them often in Ilands? But this is more than can be reaonably expected from o great Enemies.

I hall conclude by oberving to you, that this having been the Common Error of the Age, in believing the Pygmies to be a ort of little Men, and it having been handed down from o great Antiquity, what might contribute farther to the confirming this Mitake, might be, the Impoture of the Navigators, who ailing to thee Parts where thee Apes are, they have embalmed their Bodies, and brought them home, and then made the People believe that they were the Men of thoe Countries from whence they came. This M. P. Venetus aures us to have been done; and 'tis not unlikely: For, aith he M. Pauli Veneti de Regionibus Orieneal. lib. 3. cap. 15. p.m. 390., Abundat quoque Regio ipa (c. Baman in Java majori) diveris Simiis magnis & parvis, hominibus imillimis, hos capiunt Venatores & totos depilant, nii quòd in barba & in loco ecreto Pilos relinquunt, & occios peciebus Aromaticis condiunt, & potea deiccant, venduntque Negociatoribus, qui per diveras Orbis Partes Corpora illa deferentes, homines peruadent Tales Homunciones in Maris Inulis reperiri. Joh. Jonton Jo. Jonten. Hit. Nat. de Quadruped. p.m. 139. relates the ame thing, but without quoting the Author; and as he is very apt to do, commits a great mitake, in telling us, pro Homunculis marinis venditant.

div.head: A Philological Eay Concerning the CYNOCEPHALI OF THE ANCIENTS.
Of the Cynocephali of the Ancients.
div.p: TIS not that I think there are any at preent o mitaken, as to believe the Cynocephali to be a Race of Men, that I write this Eay: 'tis o notoriouly known that they are Monkeys, or rather Baboons, that 'tis needles to go about to prove it, 'tis what even the Ancients themelves have ufficiently confeed. That which induces me to mention them, is to hew how fond the Ancients were of inventing Fables; and Cteias, who hath told us uch fine Stories of the Pygmies, whom he makes to be little Men, tho' indeed they are only a ort of Apes; when he comes to dicoure of the Cynocephali, which are a ort of Baboons, and far les like Men than the Pygmies are, to perwade us that thee likewie are a Race of Men; he is obliged to exercie his Inventive Faculty with more force, to ue much bolder trokes, and by roundly aerting o many incredible Things, to amue our Imaginations, he hopes at leat to give the Reader Entertainment, tho' he mies his Deign of gaining our belief.

I will give you Cteias's own words, that you may ee I do not abue
him, as he hath done Mankind, in mot of the Natural Hitory that he hath left us; for as Photij Bibliothec. Cod. 72. de Indicis, p. m. 149, &c. Photius informs us, Cteias tells us

q.p: Degere iidem hice in montibus homines memorat canino capite, qui ferarum pellibus vetiantur. Sermone hos nullo uti, canum tantùm more latratum edere, atque ita mutuò ee intelligere. Dentes illis ee quàm canibus majores, & caninos imiliter ungues, ed longiores, ac rotundiores. Montes incolere ad Indum fluvium uque, & colore ee nigro, inignéque jutitiae cultores, ceterorum Indorum more, inter quos verentur. Intelligere quoque quae ab Indis dicantur, licet ipi loqui minimè point, ut propterea latratu, manibus, atque digitis igna dent, quemadmodum ferè urdi ac muti olent. Vocari hos ab Indis Calytrios, quod Graeci dicerent < in non-Latin alphabet > , id et, Canicipites, [carnibus eodem veci crudis] totiúque gentis capita numerari ad centum & viginti millia.

div.p: And a little afterwards he adds,

q.p:
Narrat inuper hos Cynocephalos in montibus habitantes nullum exercere opificium; ed de venatione vivere, feráque quas occiderint ad olem torrere. Magnam nihilominus pecoris copiam alere, caprarúmque & ovium: quarum quidem ovium lac atque oxygala pro potu illis it. Veci tamen etiam Sipachorae fructu;è qua, uti dictum et, arbore uccinum emanat. dulcem enim illum ee. Hunc item illos fructum arefactum in corbes contipare, ad eum modum quo uvas paas Graeci. Eodem illos Cynocephalos ratem quo
que extemporariam contruere, qua impoitum hujus fructus onus, ut & purpurae (ed purgato prius ejus flore) itémque electri, ad ducenta & exagintatalenta
quotannis avehunt; additis talentis totidem illius Pigmenti, quo infectores puniceum colorem inducunt. Electri praeterea mille talenta quotannis ad Indorum regem advehere. Immò & alia plura devehere ad Indos venalia, pro quibus viciim panes, farinam, & xylinas vetes accipiant. Habere quoque enes venales, quibus ipi ad venatum utuntur, cum arcubus & jaculis. Peritiimos enim ee jaculandi atque agittandi: & praeterea ctiam, quod montes habitent altos atque inacceos, bello inuperabiles. Regem ipis pro munere quinto quoque anno praebere trecenta arcuum, totidémque jaculorum millia; jam peltarum centum viginti, & gladiorum quinquaginta millia. Nullas item apud hos ee domos, ed in antris degere. In venatione jaculis potiimum feras, vel agittis petere; eademque perequendo, quòd curus velocitate praetent, etiam aequi. Horum uxores emel duntaxat per menem, cùm mentrua patiuntur, lavare; aliâs nunquam. Neque viros unquam omnino lavare, ed manus tantummodò abluere. Oleo tamen ex lacte confecto ter altem menibus ingulis ungi, & pellibus deinde abtergi. Vete ad haec uti, non villoa, ed è glabris macerati
que pellibus quàm tenuiimis, ipos aequè atque uxores. Exceptis fortè ditiimis inter eos, & iis quidem paucis, qui lineos getent amictus. Nec item lectorum novie uum eos, qui extemporaneos ibi toros extruant. Hunc apud eos ditiimum haberi, qui plurimum habeat pecoris, ac reliquas opes his propemodum ee imiles. Caudam inuper habere omnes, tam viros quàm mulieres, upra clunes, caninae, imilem, nii quòd major it, & pilis denior. Quadrupedes item hos, canum more, cum mulieribus congredi aliúmque congrediendi modum omnem pro turpi habere. Jutiimos eodem ee, vitae
que reliquos inter homines longiimae. Vivere nam
que ad centeimum u
que & eptuageimum, nonnullo
que ad ducentiimum quo
que annum.

i. e. In thee Mountains (aith Cteias) live certain Men, who have Heads like Dogs, are cloathed with Skins of wild Beats, peak no Language, but bark like Dogs, and thereby undertand one another. They have Teeth larger than Dogs; and Nails like Dogs, but longer and rounder. They dwell up in the Mountains, as far as the River Indus; they are black and very jut, as are the other Indians with whom they are mixt; and they undertand what is aid to them, tho' they cannot peak themelves. But by their Barking, and their Hands and Fingers, they ignifie their Minds, as Deaf and Dumb Men do. They are called by the Indians, Calytrij, which in Greek is Cynocephali. The whole Nation is an hundred and twenty Thouand in number.

Thee Cynocephali that inhabit the Mountains, do not work, but live upon Hunting; and when they kill any wild Beat, they rot it in the Sun. They breed a great many Sheep, Goats and Aes; and drink the Milk and Butter-milk of the Sheep. They eat likewie the Fruit of the Sipachora Tree, from whence comes Ambar, the Fruit whereof is weet, which having dried, they put up in Baskets, as the Greeks do Raiins. Thee Cynocephali having made a Boat, they load it with this Fruit, and with Purpura, the Flower being firt picked, and with Ambar, to the quantity of Two hundred and ixty Talents, which they every Year hip off, and as much too of the Drug, with which the Dyers dye the Scarlet; and they carry every Year a Thouand Talents of Ambar to the King of India, and they take with them other Commodities, which they ell to the Indians; for which they receive Bread, and Meal, and Cotton Garments. And the Indians ell them likewie Swords, which they ue in taking the wild Beats; and Bows and Darts, for they are very skilful Archers and Darters. They are invincible, becaue they inhabit very high, and inacceible Mountains. Every fifth year, the King betows upon them Three hundred thouand Bows, and as many Darts: Alo an Hundred and twenty thouand Shields, and Fifty thouand Swords. They have no Houes, but live in Caves. In hunting the wild Beats, they ue their Bows and Darts, and puruing them, they take them; for they run very wift. The Women bathe only once a Month, when they have their Catamenia, otherwie not. The Men don't bathe, but only wah their hands; but they anoint themelves three times in a Month with Oyl made of Milk, and rub themelves with Hides. The Cloaths both of the Men and Women are not hairy, but Skins macerated mooth, and made very thin. The richet of them wear Linnen, but thoe are but few. They have no Beds, but lye upon Straw or Leaves. He is eteemed the richet amongt them, who hath mot Sheep, or uch like Subtance, They have all, both Men and Women, Tails on their Rumps, like Dogs, but larger and more hairy; and, like Dogs too, they lye with their Women on all four, and they think itunbecoming to do otherwie. They are
jut, and the longet lived of any Men, for they live an Hundred and eventy, and ome of them Two hundred years.

div.p: Had not Cteias made uch a Solemn Aeveration of the Truth of all that he had wrote, that Apology that Strabo Strabo Geograph. lib. 1. p.m. 29. makes for the Poets, might excue him, < in non-Latin alphabet > (aith Strabo) < in non-Latin alphabet > i.e. Statim enim apparet eos fabulas admicere, non ob verorum ignorationem, ed delectationis caua, montra & alia quae ee non pount, fingentes. For our Hitorian had as good a Talent at Fiction as any of the Poets. And tho' AEchylus, as the ame Strabo there tells us, firt invented the Story of the Cynocephali, or Canicipites, as likewie the Pectoroculati and the noculi, as Heiod and Homer did that of the Pygmies; yet I can't but think he hath as far out-done the Original in what he relates of the Cynocephali, as he did in the Account he gives of the Pygmies.

Thee Cynocephali by AElian. Hit. de Animal. lib. 10. cap. 25. p.m. 601. AElian are called
< in non-Latin alphabet > , and he gives this Relation of them, as I find him tranlated by Conrad. Gener, who is more faithful in rendering him than Pet. Gillius, ltra Oain AEgypti, olitudo maxima ad eptem dierum iter extenditur. Eam excipit Regio quam Cynoproopi Homines incolunt, in via AEthiopiam verus. Vivunt illi Caprarum & Bubalidum venatu. Apectus iis niger, Caput & Dentes Canis. Quod Animal, quum referant, non aburda eorum (quamquam Hominum) hoc in loco exitimanda et mentio. Nam & Sermonis uu carent, & acuto quodam tridore onant. Barbam infra upraque os gerunt, Draconum quadam imilitudine. Manus eorum validis & acutiimis unguibus armantur. Corpus omne hirutum est, hoc etiam intar Canum. Sunt autem perniciimi, & aquas Regionis norunt; atque eam ob cauam, difficiles captu.

Now tho AElian calls them here Men, yet where he decribes them before, even out of Cteias, he plainly tells us they are not Men, but only Brutes, becaue they cannot peak, but only bark. I will give you AElian. H •• t. de Animal. lib. 4. cap. 46. p.m. 239. Gener's Tranlation of this Paage: In eodem Indiae tractu, ubi Canthari Thee Canthari are that ort of Scaribaeus we call a Lady-Cow, and I have formerly given a Figure of, in Philooph. Tranact. N. 175. p. 1202. from the Worm or Chry • alis of which, come the Cochineel, for dying Scarlet, of which there is a good account here in AElian out of Cteias. jam dicti, Cynocephali etiam reperiuntur: quibus à facie & Corporis pecie nomen inditum, caetera fere humana habent: & vetiti pellibus ferarum ingrediuntur. Juti unt, Hominum nemini moleti aut injurij, non Sermone ed ululatu onant. Indorum tamen linguam intelligunt. Venatione Animalium ferorum vivunt, quae ut unt celerrimi, facile conecuti interimunt, & frutatim divia ad olem aunt. Capras etiam & oves alunt, ut
ex lacte potu fruantur. Horum inter Animantes rationis expertes non temerè mentionem feci, articulato enim, dicretoque & humano Sermone non utuntur • .

But 'twas for want of Education, it may be, and by their living wild in the Woods, they lot their Learning and their Speech; for the AEgyptians in the time of the Ptolomies took more care of them; and as the ame AElian relates, they taught them Letters, and to Dance, and to play upon Muick: Nor were they ungrateful to their Maters; for they beg'd a great deal of Money, which they carefully put up into a Bag, to reward them for the pains they had taken with them. For thus, aith AElian. Hit. de Anim. lib. 6. cap. 10. p. 331. AElian, as Gener tranlates him; Animalia Diciplinae idonea haec ee percepi. Regnantibus Ptolomeis Cynocephalos AEgyptij literas, & altare, & pulare Citharam docebant. Tum verò unuquipiam Cynocephalorum mercedem, Domini nomine ic citè tanquam peritus aliquis Mendicus exigebat. Et id quod dabatur in Marupium, quod ferebat, appenum, congerebat.

I could not but take the more notice of this paage in AElian, becaue the Cynocephali are always repreented to be of a fierce and untractable Nature; which eems their particular Character: For aith Aritotle, as I have quoted him already Vid. pag. 3. & 7. of the Anatomy. , < in non-Latin alphabet >
i. e. The Cynocephali are of the ame hape with Monkeys, but they are bigger and tronger, and they have a Face more like a Dog's, and are of a fiercer Nature, and have Teeth more like a Dog's, and tronger. And o Pt • ij Hit. Nat. lib. 8. cap. 54. p. 243. Pliny, Efferacior Cynocephalis Natura icut Satyris: And Solini Polyhitor. cap. 27. p. m. 39. Solinus, Cynocephali & ipi unt è numero imiarum, in AEthiopiae parte frequentiimi: violenti ad altum, feri moru, nunquam ita manueti, ut non int magis rabidi. And Diodori Siculi Biblioth. Hitor. lib. 3. p.m. 168. Diodorus Siculus decribes them after the ame manner: < in non-Latin alphabet >
i. e. Qui Cynocephali (à Canino Capite) dicuntur, Corporis apectum Hominum deformium intar habent, quorum vocem muitatione tantùm exprimunt. Apprimè ferox et hoc Animal, nec ullo cicurationem pacto admittit, & vultum à uperciliis auterioribus praefert. Singulare quiddam faemellis accidit; quod vulvam perpetuò extra Corpus projectam habent. And Agatharcides in Photij Biblioth. Cap. 38. Cod. 250. p.m. 1364. Photius gives jut the ame decription of them: < in non-Latin alphabet > (aith he) < in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet >
i. e. In Cynocephalo Hominis Corpus, pecie turpis, adumbratur. Canina ei facies, vocem tridori Muris non diimilem exprimit. Sed immodicè ferum et Animal, nec ullo modo cicuratur: vultumque à uperciliis & oculis auterum prodit. Ita Mas comparatus et. Foemineo generi hoc et proprium, ut uterum extra Corpus getet, eoque habitu totam exigat vilam.

Salmaius Salmaij Exercitat. Plinian. Cap. 27. p. 267. remarks that Agatharcides borrowed this Paage, as he hath ome others likewie, from Diodorus Siculus. But that thee Relations of Cteias that are o extravagant and wild, hould be copied from him, by o many and noted Authors too, eems omewhat trange. Yet we find AElian, Pliny, Solinus, and a great many others have done it; tho' they have added by it little Credit to their Hitories, and no doubt much leened their own Reputation by trancribing the Errors of their Predeceors. In the Hitory therefore of Nature we mut not depend upon the Authority of the Number of thoe that only trancribe the ame thing, without duly examining the Matter themelves: For the Authority here wholly depends on the veracity of the firt Relator: And it what Cteias aith is fale, tho' never o many ay the ame thing from him, they mut all be in the wrong. Epecially in trancribing the Ancients, and believing their Reports, we ought to be very cautious, ince 'twas a common Practice amongt them to diguie and conceal the Truths they would deliver, in AEnigmatical and Mythological Repreentations. Many times there is omething of Truth contained in their Relations, but 'tis under uch Vails, that you will not dicover it, till you have taken them off. And tho' there are no uch Men, as Cteias's Cynocephali, and Pygmies; yet there are Apes, and Monkeys, and Baboons, that afforded him a ground for his Invention.

Now what ort of Monkey thee Cynocephali were, I hall not at preent enquire; that they are of the Monkey-kind is evident, becaue they have Tails: and Aritotle tells us, that they are bigger and tronger, and therefore I make them of the Baboon-kind. But not having een any of them my elf, I hall refer my Reader to the Authors who have wrote about them. 'Tis ufficient to my preent purpoe that they are a ort of Monkeys, and not Men, as formerly repreented.

div.head: A Philological Eay Concerning the SATYRS OF THE ANCIENTS.
Of the SATYRS of the Ancients.
div.p:
TLPIS and Bontius indeed think the Orang-Outang to be the Satyr of the Ancients; but if we enquire into their Hitory, and examine what Opinion the Ancients had concerning them, we hall find it no les involved in Fables, than that of the Pygmies; and upon this account everal of our Learned Men of late, have wholly denied them, and look upon all the Stories concerning them to be only a Fiction of the Poets and Painters, and that there were never any uch Beings in Nature. The Learned Caaubon de Poei Satyricâ, lib. 1. cap. 2. Caaubon is clearly of this Mind, Quicquid de Satyris legimus (aith he) ex Poetarum Pictorumque fingendi Licentia Originem ducere. Nihil hujus reverà in Rerum Naturâ exitere. So I • Voij Comment • d Pompon. Melam. lib. 1. c. 8. p.m. 46. Iaac Voius peaking of the AEgipanes tells us, Sanè neque in forma hujus montri conveniunt, i tamen montris accenenda unt ea, quae unt mera Graeculorum Commenta. And the Learned Bocharti Hierozoic. eu de Animal. Sacrae Scripturae. part. pot. lib. 6. cap. 7. p. 829. Bochartus aith, Abit interim ut ex his locis Quiquam colligat, ullos aut jam extare, vel unquam extitie in Rerum Natura Satyros. However, I do not doubt but to make it plainly appear, that there were
uch Animals in Africa which the Ancients called Satyrs. And tho' they ometimes called them Men, and for the mot part worhipped them as Gods, yet I hall hew, that they were only a ort of Monkeys, and likewie Evince, that the Orang-Outang was not this ort of Monkey or Satyr of the Ancients.

Having propoed thee as the Heads of my enuing Dicoure, it will not be expected of me to give an Account of ail that has been aid on this Argument. I hall rather apply my elf to make out what I have here aerted. And tho' on this occaion, it may be, the Poets have Enigmatically repreented ome Nobler Secrets of Philoophy, by what they relate under the Fables they have made of thee Satyrs, the Fauni, the Nymphae, Pan, AEgipan, Sylvanus, Silenus, or any other Name they have given of this ort of Animal; yet I think my elf no farther concerned at preent, than to hew what might give the firt rie to and occaion of thee Inventions: or rather to prove that the Satyrs were neither Men, nor Demi-gods, nor Daemons; but Monkeys or Baboons, that in Africa were worhipped as the Gods of the Country; and being o, might give the Poets the Subject of the Stories which they have forged about them.

The Satyrs therefore are generally repreented like Men in the upper Parts, but with Horns on their Heads; and in their lower Parts or Legs like Goats: hence they are called Capripedes, or < in non-Latin alphabet > , as Herodotus exprees it. And Pliny (as I hall hew) where he decribes them as Brutes; and aith, they are ometimes Quadrupeds, ometimes Bipeds, yet tells us, they are Humanâ Effigie. Diodorus Siculus Diodorus Siculus Bibliothec. Hit. lib. 1. p.m. 16. informs us, that when Oiris went into AEthiopia,
< in non-Latin alphabet > , &c. i.e. Dum in AEthiopia veratur (Oiris) Gens Satyrorum ei adducitur, quas pilos in lumbis (Ophye) habere ferunt. Riûs enim amator erat Oiris & Muicae Chorei
que gaudebat, &c. Satyri igitur quia ad tripudia, & decantationem Carminum, omnemque hilaritatem & luum apti erant, in partem Militiae venerunt. He makes them likewie the Companions of Bacchus, and for the ame reaon Diodorus Siculus ibid. lib. 4. p.m. 213., < in non-Latin alphabet > i.e. Ita Satyri ludicris & ad rium compoitis getibus & actionibus, vitam Dionyo beatam, Gratiique delibutam, reddunt. And they are always repreented as Jocoe and Sportful, but Scurrilous and Lacivious; and wonderful Things they relate of their Revellings by Night, their Dancing, Muick, and their wanton Frolicks. For thus Pliny Plinij Hit. Nat. lib. 5. cap. 1. p.m. 523. decribing the Parts about the Mountain Atlas in Africa, informs us, Incolarum neminem interdiu cerni: ilere omnia, non alio quam olitudinum horrore: ubire tacitam
Religionem animos propriùs accedentium, praeterque horrorem elati (c. Montis) uper nubila, atque in viciniam Lunaris circuli. Eundem noctibus micare crebris ignibus, AEgipanum, Satvrorumque lacivia impleri, Tibiarum ac Fitulae Cantu, & Cymbalorum Sonitu trepere. And then adds, Haec celebrati Authores prodidere. And o Pomp. Mela de itu Orbis, lib. 3.cap. 9. p.m. 63. Pomponius Mela, ltra hunc inum Mons altus (ut Graeci vocant) < in non-Latin alphabet > , perpetuis ignibus flagrat: ultra montem viret Collis longo tractu, longis littoribus obductus, unde viuntur patentes magis Campi, quâm ut propici point, Panum, Satyrorumque. Hinc opinio ea fidem cepit, quòd cum in his nihil culti it, nullae habitantium Sedes, nulla Vetigia, olitudo in diem Vata, & ilentium Vatius, nocte crebri ignes micant, & veluti Catra late jacentia otenduntur, Crepant Cymbala & Tympana, audiunturque Tibiae Sonantes majus humanis. Where we may oberve that what Pliny calls AEgipanes, Mela calls here Panes. And the Satyrs being commonly called Fauni, I can't but think, that the idle Stories we have about the Fairies, mut come from hence: For they likewie have their Revellings, Dancing, and Muick by Night. And as even to this day, to fright Children, they tell them Stories of Fairies and Hobgoblins, o the Ancients did ue to call any great udden Fear, as we do now, a Panick Fear, from this Pan. For as Pauanias in Phocicis. Pauanias tells us,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
i. e. Eâ nocte Panicus illos inceit terror. Terrores enim nulla ex caua Ortos ab eo (c. Pane) immitti aiunt. And o Euripides in Rhaeo. Euripides:
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
Saturnij (Senis) Panis tremendo flagello (Ictus) trepidas.
And o Dionyij Halicarna. lib. 5. cap. 3. Dionyius Halicarnaeus peaking of the Faunus, ays,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
i. e. Huic enim Romani Panicos terrores adcribunt, & quaecunque alia Spectra, quae varias induentia formas in Hominum conpectum veniunt, & Metum ipis incutiunt, And Ovid in Phaedra. Ovid:
—Faunique bicornes
Numine contactas attonuere uo.
How jolly therefore oever and merry the Satyrs may be by night amongt themelves, with their Dancing and Muick: yet they have been frightful to Men formerly, as the Stories of the Fairies and Hobgoblins are (as I aid before) to Children now; and indeed, the telling Children Stories of this
kind, is a very michievous Cutom; for they are thereby impreed with uch Fears, as perhaps they cannot conquer all their Life time. But the Account that Phurnutus de Natura Deorum Cap. de Pane, p. m. 70. Phurnutus gives of thee Panick Fears, I think is natural; for he tells us, < in non-Latin alphabet > i. e. Nihil prohibet quin etiam Panicos tumultus dicamus, qui ubito & ine ratione certa exoriuntur: ic enim interdum armenta & greges terrentur, dum onus quidam ubitus è Sylva, aut ex Antris aut ex Terrae voraginibus affertur.

Now Lucretius thinks that all this Muick of Pipes, Flutes, Cymbals and Drums, that is aid to be made by the Jollity and Revellings of the Satyrs, Fauni, Panes, &c. in this dreadful Mountain by Night, is meer Romance and Fiction; and that 'tis nothing but the Ecchoing of the whitling boiterous Winds amongt thoe hideous Rocks: For peaking of Eccho's, he tells us T. Lucretij de Rerum Naturâ, lib. 4. verf. 581.,
Sex etiam, aut eptem loca vidi reddere voces
nam cum jaceres: ita colles collibus ipis
Verba repulantes iterabant dict a referre.
Haec loca Capripedes Satyros, Nymphaque tenere
Finitimi fingunt, & Faunos ee loquuntur;
Quorum noctivago trepitu, Ludoque jocanti
Adfirmant volgo taciturna ilentia rumpi,
Chordarumque Sonos fieri, dulceique querelas,
Tibia quas fundit digitis pulata canentum:
Et genus Agricolûm late enticere, cum Pan
Pinea emiferi Capitis velamina quaans,
nco aepe labro calamos percurrit hianteis,
Fitula Silvetrem ne ceet fundere Muam.
Caetera de genere hoc montra, ac Portenta loquuntur,
Ne lo • a deerta ab Divis quoque forte putentur
Sola tenere: ideo jactant miracula dictis
Aut aliqua ratione alia ducuntur, ut omne
Humanum Genus est avidum nimis auricularum.
Which the Ingenious Mr. Creech hath thus rendered:
— And I my elf have known
Some Rocks and Hills return ix words for one:
The dancing words from Hill to Hill rebound,
They all receive, and all retore the ound.
The Vulgar, and the Neighbours think, and tell,
That there the Nymphs, and Fauns, and Satyrs dwell;
And that their wanton port, their loud delight
Breaks thro' the quiet ilence of the Night:
Their Muick's oftet Ayrs fill all the Plains,
And mighty Pan delights the litning Swains;
The Goat-fac'd Pan, whilt Flocks ecurely feed,
With long-hung lip he blows his Oaten Reed;
The horn'd, the half-beat God, when brisk and gay
With Pine-leaves crown'd, provokes the Swains to play,
Ten thouand uch Romants the Vulgar tell,
Perhaps leat Men hould think the Gods will dwell
In Towns alone, and corn their Plains and Cell
Or omewhat; for Man credulous and vain
Delights to hear trange things, delights to feign.

Lucretius here attributes the Invention of thee Fables to the upertitious Notions Men had of Deities, and the Itching Ears Mankind generally hath for hearing Novelties and Wonders; and no donbt, the atisfying this Humour put the Ancients upon inventing mot of thee Stories. But we may take notice that Lucretius places together the Satyrs, the Nymphs, the Fauni and Pan; and generally I oberve, where mention is made of them, everal are joyned together: As Ovid. Metamorph. lib. 6. ver. 392. Ovid,
Illum Ruricolae, Sylvarum Numina, Fauni
Et Satyri fratres, & tunc quoque clarus Olympus
Et Nymphae flerunt.
The Fauni therefore and Satyrs I find are near akin. And Ovid. Metamorph. lib. 14. ver. 637. Ovid in another place aith,
Quid non & Satyri Saltatibus apta juventus
Fecere, & Pinu praecincti Cornua Panes.
Silvanuque uis emper juvenilior annis.
And elewhere he tells us Ovid. • .1. Fatorum., Panes & in Venerem Satyrorum prona juventus. The Satyrs therefore and Fauni eem to be young ones, and the elder, the Panes and Silvani, according to that of Virgil. Georg. 1. 2. ver. 494. Virgil,
—Deos qui novit agretes
Panaque, Silvanumque Senem Nymphaque Sorores.
And Plutarch. in Parallelis. Plutarch tells us that what the Greeks called AEgipan, the Romans called Silvanus. And Pauan. in Attic. p.m. 21. Pauanias exprely tells us, that when the Satyrs
grow old, they are called Sileni: < in non-Latin alphabet > . And by Virgil's Expreion Nymphaque Sorores, 'tis very evident, that the Nymphs likewie were of this Family, and nearly related. Ovid Ovid. Metamorph. lib. 1. ver. 193. joyns them together.
Sunt mihi Semidei, unt Rutica Numina Nymphae,
Faunique, Satyrique, & monticulae Silvani.

Now what difference there is amongt all thee, unles as to their Age and Sex, I will not undertake at preent to determine. The Poets and the Painters of old, if we nicely enquire into them, have been pleaed, as their fancy govern'd them, to make, or not make a ditinction between them. Thoe that have a mind to atisfie their Curioity farther in this Matter, may conult Salmaius, Bochart, Gerard, and Iaac Voius, and everal others, who have largely wrote about them. I am apt to think that Pan, AEgipan, Silvanus and Silenus, were all the ame; as were the Satyri and the Fauni; only thee were younger than the former; and the Nymphs were the Females of the Kind. But 'tis ufficient to • my buines, if I make it appear, notwithtanding all this, that the Satyrs were not Men, nor Demi-Gods, nor Daemons, but only Brutes of the Monkeykind; which is plain enough even from the Ancients, who have invented o many Fables about them.

For Herodot. in Melpomene, p.m. 229. Herodotus tells us, and he is apt enough oftetimes to be overcredulous,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
for they are neither Men, nor have they uch Feet. Satyri de hominibus nihil aliud praeferunt quàm figuram, aith Solinus Poly •• t. cap. 34. Solinus. Satyrus praeter Effigiem nihil humani, aith P • mp. Mela de itu Orbis, lib. 1. cap. 8. p. 11. Mela. Pliny gives us a larger decription of them; Sunt & Satyri (faith Plinij Hit. Nat. lib. 7. cap. 2. he) ubolanis Indorum montibus (Catharcludorum dicitur Regio) pernicioiimum Animal: Cùm Quadrupedes tum rect • incedentes, humanâ effigie, propter velocitatem, nii Senes aut aegri, non capiuntur. Choromandarum Geniem vocat Tauron, Silvetrem, ine voce, tridoris horrendi, hirtis Corporibus, oculis glaucis, dentibus caninis. You may here perceive they have omething of the hape of Men, but can't peak, they are hairy, they go ometimes upon all four, ometimes erect, they have Dogs Teeth, they are wild michievous Animals. But AElian is a little more expres: Finitimos Indiae montes (aith AE ••• n. Hit. Animal. lib. 16. cap. 21. he) tranmittenti, ad intimum latus deniimas convalles videri aiunt, & Corudam locum nominari: ubi Betiae Satyrorum imilitudinem formamque gerentes, & toto Corpore hirutae, verantur: atque Equina Cauda praeditae dicuntur. Eae quum non à venatorilus agitantur, in opacis & piis Sylvis olent ex frondibus (& fructibus) vivere. Quùm autem Venantium trepitum entiunt, & Canum
latratus exaudiunt, in Montium vertices incredibili celeritate excurrunt: nam per montes iter conicere auetae unt. Contra eos qui e inequuntur pugnant, de ummis montibus axa devolventes, quorum impetu aepe multi depreheni pereunt. Itaque difficillimè capiuntur: Et ex iis nonnullae, ed aegerrimè tandem, aut aegrotantes nimirum, aut gravidae c • mprehenduntur. Illae quidem propter morbum; hae verò ob gravitatem. Captae autem ad Praios deferuntur. AElian here tells us that they have Tails like Hores, therefore they mut be of the Monkey or Baboon kind. And Pauanias, who made it his Buines to enquire more particularly about them, informs us they have uch Tails, but Can't peak, but are very Lacivious and Lutful, as they are oberved to be to this day. I will give you Pauanias's words; < in non-Latin alphabet > (aith Pauanias in Atticis, p.m. 21. he) < in non-Latin alphabet > . Which Gener. de Animal. p. 855. Conrad. Gener. I find hath thus tranlated; Caeterum de Satyris, quinam int, cùm plura quàm alij cire laborem, cum multis ea de re um collocutus: Dixit autem Euphemus Car, e quùm in Italiam navigaret curu ee excuum vi ventorum, & ad mare extimum, quod navigari non item oleat portatum. Inulas autem ibi multas ee ac deertas, & viris agretibus incoli. Ad alias verò aiebat nautas deflectere recuae, quòd antea quoque cò appuli, Incolarum Inhumanitatem eent experti. Tempetatis denique violentia cò pervenie. Inulas eas à Nautis vocari Satyrias. Incolas inee rubicundos, & caudas imo doro habere, Equinis non multò minores. Hos, ubi enerant, ad navigium accurrie, nullamque vocem edidie, ed mulieribus Navi unà advectis manus injecie. Nautas verò timore correptos, Barbaram Mulierem in Inulam tandem Projecie. Eam Satyros, non olum qua parte conuetudo permittat, verùm etiam toto corpore libidinosè violâe, referebat.

It appears therefore plainly that the Satyrs have Tails. But that there might not the leat Scruple remain what ort of Animals thee Satyrs were, I hall produce a Paage out of Philotorgij Hit. Eccleiatic. lib. 3. cap. 11. p. 41. Philotorgius which is very expres, and comes fully up to our Buines: For he tells us, < in non-Latin alphabet > (c. Satyrus) < in non-Latin alphabet > . i.e. That a Satyr is a ort of Ape with a red face, wift of motion, and having
a Tail. Where you may oberve that Philotorgius and Pauanias both agree, that they have a red Face, which may be ome mark, by which to know them again. And Galen. Adminitr. Anat. lib. 4. cap. 3. p.m. 94. Galen hath given us another, viz. that their Rotrum or Chin is longer than an Apes, but not o long as that of the Cynocephalus, as appears in that Paage I have already quoted Vid. Anat. of the Orang-Outang, pag. 94., viz. That a Man in proportion to his Body hath the hortest Chin of any Animal; next to a Man, an Ape; then the Lynx and Satyrs; and after thee the Cynocephali. Now none of thee Marks agree to the Orang-Outang; for it had no Tail, it had not a red Face, and his Chin was horter than any other ort of Apes. So that Bontius was mitaken in calling it a Satyr. And Tulpius was too haty in laying down this Concluion, In ummâ (aith Nic. Tulpij Oberv. Med. lib. 4. cap. 56. p.m. 274. he) vel Nullus est in Rerum Naturâ Satyrus: aut i quis est, erit proculdubio illud Animal, quod in Tabellâ hic à nobis depictum. Had Tulpius a mind to have made his Orang-Outang a Satyr, he hould not have compared him to a Courtier, nor intanced in uch Niceties as he oberves, of his drinking, and going to bed: For, Efferatior Cynocephalis Natura, icut Satyris, aith Pliny Nat. Hit. lib. 8. cap. 54. p. 243. Pliny. And in another Place he tells us, Satyris praeter figuram nihil moris humani Plinj ibid. lib. 5. cap. 8. p.m. 549.. But the Orang-Outang had very tender Paions, and was very gentle and loving. Another very remarkable difference that I find between the Satyrs and the Orang-Outang, is, that the Satyrs have Pouches in their Chops as Monkeys have; but the Orang-Outang, as I have hewn in the Anatomy, had none. Condit (aith Plinij Nat. Hit. lib. 10. cap. 72. p.m. 466. Pliny) in Theauros Maxillarum Cibum Sphingiorum & Satyrorum genus: mox inde enim ad mandendum, manibus expromit: & quod formicis in annum olenne est, his in dies vel horas. The Orang-Outang therefore cannot be the Satyrs of the Ancients, as Tulpius, and Bontius, and Dapperimagined.

By what has been aid, I think it fully appears that there were uch Animals as the Ancients called Satyrs; and that they were a ort of Monkeys or Apes with Tails: And this Account that I have given of them, will very well make out thoe Texts in Iaih; as Chapter 13. vere 21. But wild Beats of the Deart hall lye there, and their Haues hall be full of doleful Creatures, and Owls hall dwell there, and Satyrs hall dance there. And Chapter 34. ver. 14. The wild Beats of the Deart hall alo meet with the wild Beats of the Iland; and the Satyr hall cry to his Fellow; the Schrich-Owl alo hall ret there, and find for her elf a place of rest. For ince the Text calls them wild Beats, I ee no reaon why we hould fancy the Satyrs here to be Daemons, as the Learned Bochartus and others eem to do. I agree with Bochart, that what is told us in the Life of St. Paul the Hermite by St. Jerome, and in that of St. Anthony by St. Anataius of a Satyr meeting St. Anthony in the Deart, and dicouring with him, may be
fabulous or a Deluion. Non aentior (aith Bochart. Hierozoic. part. poter. lib. 6. cap. 7. p. 829. Bochartus) narrationi Magni Scriptoris, in qua Satyrus introducitur Antonium in Eremo rogans, ut proe communem Deum deprecetur, tanquam Salutis in Chrito particeps futurus. Non alios ervat Chritus, quàm quos aumpit. At non aumpit Angelos, multò minùs Daemones aut Satyros qui nuquam unt, ed emen Abrahae. And tho' St. Jerome, to confirm this Relation, adds, That in Contantine's time one of thee Monters was een alive at Alexandria in AEgypt, and after it's Death, it's Carcas was embalmed and ent to Antioch for the Emperor to ee it; Yet I hall plainly prove that this Satyr was nothing ele but that ort of Monkey I am now dicouring about.

This Story I find often mentioned; but Philotorg. Hit. Eccleiatic. lib. 3. cap. 11. Philotorgius gives us the mot particular Account of it, and therefore I hall inert his own words; < in non-Latin alphabet > . i.e. This Ape-form is mixt with other Species of Animls; and this is plain, erveral being ent over to us; as that which is called Pan, which in its Head had a Goat's face and Goat's horns, from it's Loins downwards Goat's Legs; but in it's Belly, Breats, and Hands was a pure Ape. Such an one the King of India ent to Contantius. This Animal lived for ome time, and was carried about incloed in a Cage, being very wild. When it died, thoe that looked after it, having embalmed it to make a hew of this unuual ight, ent it to Contantinople. Now I am apt to believe the ancient Greeks had een this Animal, and being urpried at the trangenes of the ight, fancied it to be a God; it being uual for them to make a God of any thing that they admired or wondered at: as they did the Satyr.

'Tis evident therefore by this Relation, that the Satyr is of the Ape or Monkey-kind: For < in non-Latin alphabet > here is generical, and includes both. But there being everal Species of them, they received a denomination according to the reemblance they had to other Animals; as in Philotorgius are mentioned before, the Leontopithecus, the Arctopithecus, the Cynocephalus and Aegopithecus, which lat eems to be our Satyr, from the reemblace it hath in it's Head and Legs to a Goat. That their Legs and Face are like a Goat's, is eaie enough to be believed: but the Horns that they clap upon his Head, eem to me as an addition of the Poets, or the Painters, or both. But what gave a foundation to this Invention, poibly may be the largenes
of their Ears tanding off from their Head, and which are very remarkable. And this Phurnutus Phurnutus de Nat. De • rum. cap. de Pane. P.m. 71. gives as the reaon of it. Horace Horace Odarum, Lib. 2. Ode 19. takes notice of their Ears, but ill decribes them in making them harp pointed, whereas they are round.
—& aures
Capripedum Satyrorum acutas.

But by this Account it likewie appears, that Pan was a Name of this ort of Monkey; and Philotorgius's Remark at the Concluion of this Paage, I think is very jut: for 'tis certain that this Animal was Worhipped in India as a Deity, as a Dog was by the AEgyptians; and 'twas Death for any Body to kill one of them: For thus aith Diodor. Sicul. Biblioth. Hit. l. 20. p.m. 793. Diodorus Siculus,
< in non-Latin alphabet > . i.e. Eadem enim domus Simiae quas Homines frequentant; & pro Diis habentur ap •• illos, ut apud AEgyptios Canes; paratos etiam in Cellis penariis cibos, quando libet, • emine prohibente, hae betiae umunt, nominaque ut plurimùm à Simiis, ut apud nos à Diis, Parentes Liberis uis imponunt. Qui Animal hoc interfe
• erint, in eos, ut nefariae Impietatis reos, upplicio capitis animadvertitur. Ideo apud nonnullos Proverbij vicem obtinuit, quod in magnifice e efferentes dicitur; Simiae Cruorem bibiti. And in another place Diodor. Sicul. Ibid. l. 1. p.m. 16. Diodorus tells us, that Pan was in the greatet Veneration amongt the AEgyptians, and his Statue was in every Temple. And Juven. Satyr. 15. v. 4. Juvenal remarks, Effigies Sacri nitet aurea Cercopitheci.

The Supertition of worhipping this Animal obtained not only amongt the Ancients, but there are Intances likewie of a later date, and what J. Linchoten apud • heod • de By Indiae Orient. part. 2. cap. 46. p.m. 111. Johannes Linchoten relates, is very remarkable. How that in the Year 1554. the Portuguee having taken the Iland of Ceylon, they propoed to rob a Temple on the top of Adam's Pike; but they found nothing there, but a little Cabinet adorned with Gold and Jewels, in which was kept the Tooth of an Ape, which they took away, to the great grief of the Kings of that Place; who ent Ambaadors to the Portuguee, and offered them Seventy thouand Ducats for the Tooth; which the Portuguee were willing enough to take, but were ditwaded from it by their Bihop Gapar, who told them, that it was a Crime, thus to encourage the Idolatry of the Indians; whereupon he burnt the Tooth, and lung the Ahes into the River. Joh. Eueb. Nierembergius J. Eu. Nieremberg. Hit. Nat. l. 9. cap. 46. p. 180. hath the
ame Story, but varies in the Account of ome Particulars. And Joh. Petrus Maffeius Joh. Pet. Maffeij Hit. Indic. lib. 1. p.m. 36. gives us a Relation of one of their Temples, which for Magnificence, might vie with any at Rome: His words are thee; Sanè fanum et Simiae dicatum: Cujus duntaxat Pecori in victimarum uum cutodiendo, Porticus miram in longitudinem excurrit, Columnarum Septingentarum è Marmore, tantae magnitudinis, ut Agrippae Columnas, quae in celeberrimo quondam omnium Deorum Templo Romae viuntur, ine dubio adaequent. Now thee Animals being worhipped by the Indians as Gods, 'tis natural to believe (as Lucretius uggets) that they would invent and relate prodigious things concerning them; and no doubt this gave the occaion to the Poets and Hitorians of making uch fabulous Repreentations of them. How far the latter might be concerned in the addition of Horns to the Satyrs Heads, I hall not at preent enquire: I call it an Addition, becaue there is no Account from any credible Author, that there were ever oberved any of the Ape-kind to have Horns. Poibly ome ancient Statues or Paintings might give ome light into this matter: for • he ancient Statuaries and Painters were curious in repreenting them; and Pliny recommends, as excellent in this kind, the Satyr of Mylo, of Lucippus, Antiphalus, Protogenes, Ariton, and Nicomachus, as Pieces admired in thoe days.

Albertus Magnus Albert. Magnus de Animalib. lib. 22. p.m. 223. Pilous et Animal Compoitum ex homine uperious, & Capra inferius; ed Cornua habet in fronte; & et de genere Simiarum; ed multùm montruoum; & aliquotiens incedit erectum, & efficitur d • mitum. Hoc aerunt in Diertis habitare AEthiopiae; & aliquotiens captum & in Alexandriam deductum, & mortuum ale infuum & in Contantinopolin delatum. who was happier in gueing, than in proving or decribing what he meant; tells us indeed, that the Satyr (whom he calls Pilous) was of the Ape-kind; but he makes uch an odd Compoition of him, that one would take it to be rather a Chimaera, than a real Being: You may ee his words in the Citations.

div.head: Of the SPHINGES of the Ancients.
