div.p: WE come now in the lat place to dicoure of the Sphinges of the Ancients, where I hall not relate all that is aid of them; nor concern my elf with the Mythology or Interpretation of the everal Fables that have been invented about them; but I propoe rather to hew, that there were indeed uch Animals which the Ancients call'd Sphinges; and that they were not Men, but Brutes; and that they were of the Ape or Monkey-kind.

If we conult the fabulous Decriptions that are given of the Sphinx, we hall find it a very montrous Compoition. Apollodorus Apoll • dori Bibliothec. l. 3. c. 5. § 8. p.m. 170. tells us, < in non-Latin alphabet > . That Sphinx was the daughter of Echidna and Typho, he had the face of a Woman, the Breat, Feet, and Tail of a Lion, and the Wings of a Bird. And Auonius in Grypho Ternarij. Anonius,
Terruit Aoniam, Volucris, Leo, Virgo triformis
Sphinx, volucris pennis, pedibus fera, fronte Puella.
But as their Fanies govern'd them, o they made their decription. Clearchus (as I find him quoted in Natalis Comes Mytholog. l. 9. c. 18. Natalis Comes) has out-done them all; At Clearchus (aith he) Caput & Manus Puellae, Corpus Canis, vocem Hominis, Candam Draconis, Leonis ungues, Alas Avis, illam habuie cripit. Palaephatus Palephatus de incredibilibus Hitoriis Cap. de Sphinge. p.m. 14. is omewhat different in his Account, where he tells us, < in non-Latin alphabet > i. e. They ay that the Cadmean Sphynx was a wild Beat, having the Body of a Dog, the Head and Face of a Virgin, the Wings of a Bird, and the Voice of a Man. But for the mot part they make the Sphinx Biformis with a Maiden's Face and Lion's Feet; as the Scholiat upon Eurip. in Phaeniis. Euripides gives it, < in non-Latin alphabet > . So the Scholiat upon Aritophan. in Ra • is. Aritophanes,
< in non-Latin alphabet > And Euripides himelf, as he is quoted by AElian. de Animal. l. 12. c. 7. AElian, makes her to have the Tail and Feet of a Lion, in that Vere,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
Caudam remulcens ad Leoninos pedes.
Where we may oberve that AElian tells us here that the AEgyptian Statuaries, and the Theban Fables, made the Sphinx to be only Biformis: Biformem nobis conantur repreentare, ipam ex Corpore Virginis & Leonis cum gravitate compoitam architect antes, as Gener there tranlates him: But the Greeks repreented the Sphynx with wings; for as AElian. de Animal. l. 12. cap. 38. AElian in another place tells
us, Sphingem quicunque vel Picturae vel Platicae operam dant, fingere alatam olent.

But our chief Buines is to enquire, how Nature hath formed them; and not how the Poets, Painters, or Statuaries have, according to the Luxuriancy of their Fancie, feigned or figured them; to hew what they really are in themelves, and not what Hieroglyphically the Ancients might intend or undertand by them; and we hall find, that they are only a ort of Ape or Monkey, that is bred in AEthiopia and amongt the Troglodytes, of a comely Face, with long Breats, thence up to their Neck not o hairy as on the ret of their Body; and are of a mild and gentle Nature. For thus Plinij Hit. Nat. lib. 8. cap. 21. p.m. 168. Pliny, Lyncas vulgo frequentes, & Sphinges, fuco Pilo, mammis in Pectore geminis AEthiopia generat. And o Solinus Polyhit. cap. 27. p.m. 39. Solinus, Inter Simias habentur & Sphinges, villoae comis (Salmaius reads it villoae omnes) mammis prominulis ac profundis, dociles ad feritatis obli •• ionem. AElian AElian. de Animal. lib. 16. cap. 15. places them amongt the wild Beats of India, whe • he tells us, Naturali quodam Ingenio & Prudentia valent etiam apud nos Anima ••• , non totidem tamen, quot unt in India: illic enim hujumodi unt, Elephantus, Pittacus, Sphinges & nuncupati Satyri, & Indica Formica. And Artemidorus in Strabo Geograph. lib. 16. p. 533. Strabo tells us, that the Sphinges, Cynocephali and Cepi are bred amongt the Troglodytes. Agatharchides Agatharchides apud Photij Biblioth. p.m. 1362. cap. 38. confirms the ame, and gives us this Account of them; < in non-Latin alphabet > . i.e. The Sphinges, Cynocephali and Cepi are ent to Alexandria from the Country of the Troglodytes and AEthiopia. The Sphinges are like to what they are painted, only they are all hairy, and mild and gentle in their Nature: they have a great deal of Cunning, and a Method of Learning what they attain to, that one would wonder at their aptnes to any thing. Diodorus Siculus Diodorus Siculus Biblioth. lib. 3. p.m. 167. gives us much the ame Relation, and 'tis likely Agatharchides borrowed his from him: for he tells us, < in non-Latin alphabet > . i. e. Sphinges circa Troglodyticam & AEthiopiam exitunt, formâ his non abimiles, quae Arte Pictorum exhibentur, nii quòd hirutia tantummodò differunt. Placidi illis unt Animi, & veruti, artique quae compendio tradi olet, admodum capaces. But Philotorgius Philotorgius Hit. Eccleiast. l. 3. c. 11. p. 41. is o particular in his Decription, and he is the more to be credited, becaue he declares he had een them himelf, that I think I need
no more Authorities to prove what I have here laid down, that thee Sphinges were only a ort of Ape or Monkey. I will therefore give you his own words, which are thee; < in non-Latin alphabet > . i. e. A Sphinx is a ort of Ape (I hall write what I aw my elf) all the ret of whoe Body is • air <…> ike other Apes. But it's Sternum or Breat is mooth without hair up <> the • hroat. It has Mammae or Breats like a Woman; little reddih Pi <…> les like Millet Seeds, running round that part of the Body that is bare; very prettily uiting with the Fleh colour in the middle. It's Face is roundih, and reembles a Woman's. It's Voice is very much like the Humane, only it is not articulate, but praecipitate; and like one that peaks unintelligibly thro' Anger and Indignation. When 'tis incened, it's Voice is deeper. This Animal is very wild, and crafty, and not eaily tamed. And Pierius, as I find him quoted by Phil. Camerarij Operae ubciivae iv • Meditat. Hit. Cent. 1. Cap. 71. p. m. 325. Philip Camerarius, gives us much the ame decription of one he aw at Verona. Harum ego unam (faith he) Veronae quum effem vidi; Mammis illi & Glabris & Candidis, à Pectore propendentibus. Circumducebat eam circulator quidam Gallus, ex ignotis antea Inulis recens advectam. And a little after adds, Ipa verò Sphinx toto erat pectore glabello, facie & auribus humanis proprioribus, doro hipido upra modum, fuco & oblongo Pilo, eoque deniimo.

What has been aid, I think fully makes out, that the Sphinx is not a meer Figment of the Poets, but an Animal bred in Africa, of the Ape or Monkey-kind. 'Tis different from our Orang-Outang in the colour of it's Hair; in the roundnes and comelines of it's Face; in it's Breats, being pendulous and long; and the red Pimples it hath on the naked part of it's Body. Pliny tells us (as I have elewhere remarked) that the Sphinges have Pouches in their Chops as Satyrs and Monkeys have; and the Poets decribing them with a Lion's Tail, make me apt to think, that they are of the Monkey-kind.
